chunks.target_manual: <P007>It were more proper indeed, said I, that no footsteps should be seen here but those of Lovers, that is to say, your Name and Characters engraven upon the Barks of Trees by the hands of your Adorers. Pray, says she, leave off your Adorers, and let us talk of the Sun; I understand well how we imagine he describes the Circle, that we describe our selves: but that Course is not performed but in a year, and that which he makes every day over our heads, how is that perform'd? Have you observ'd, said I, that a Bowl running upon the earth has two motions? it moves towards the end of its course where it is directed, and at the same time turns it self many times about, so that the upper parts descend and those below ascend; the Earth does the like: While she advances in her annual Circle about the Sun, she turns about her self in four and twenty hours; so that in four and twenty hours every part of the Earth loses and recovers the Sun; and as we turn toward that side where the Sun is, he seems to rise, and as we begin to remove from him, he seems to descend. This, says she, is pleasant enough, the Earth takes all upon it self, and the Sun does nothing, and when the Moon and the other Planets, and the fixed Stars roll about our heads, is that likewise imagination? Nothing else, says I, but pure imagination, from the same cause: the Planets only make their revolutions about the Sun in unequal times, according to their unequal distances, and that which to day we see answering to a certain point of the Zodiack, or of that Circle of fixed Stars, to morrow we shall find answering to another point, both because it has advanc'd in its own Circle, and we have advanc'd likewise in ours: 'tis that that puts us in different points of sight in respect of them, and makes us seem to be in their course of extravagance, of which it is not necessary to tell you: it may suffice you to know, that all that seems irregular in the Planets, proceeds only from the different manner of our meeting them in our motion, when really they are all extremely regular. I agree, said the Marchioness, that they may be so; but I would willingly that their Regularity should be less troublesome to the Earth. She is not easily movable, and for a great lump so weighty as she is, it will require a good proportion of Agility. But, says I, would you rather that the Sun and all the Stars, which are vastly greater Bodies, should make every day in four and twenty hours an immense circuit of an infinite number of Leagues about the Earth? for so they must needs do, unless the Earth move about her self in four and twenty hours.</P007>
source_segments: le but où elle est envoyée
target_segments: the end of its course where it is directed
explanations: The French 'le but' (the goal/aim) is general. The translation 'the end of its course' explicitly specifies that this 'goal,' in the context of a rolling bowl's motion, refers to its physical destination or the termination point of its path, a meaning implied by the physical description but not directly stated by 'but'.

Fontenelle uses the accessible French term 'leurs Cercles' (their Circles) for planetary paths. The translation 'their revolutions' makes the specific astronomical meaning explicit by using a more precise term, clarifying that 'Cercles' here denotes orbital revolutions.

The French 'on ne l'a guere ménagée' (one has hardly spared it/her) describes the demanding role of the Earth, implying its mass makes this difficult. The translation 'She is not easily movable' makes explicit an inherent physical property of the Earth (its inertia due to mass) which is the implied reason for this difficulty, thus shifting from describing a demand to stating an explicit characteristic.

The French 'un tour immense' (an immense turn/revolution) is a general term for the apparent celestial movement. The translation 'an immense circuit' explicitly clarifies that 'tour' here signifies a complete, continuous (apparent) orbital path, specifying the nature of the large-scale movement being described.

chunks.source_manual: <P010>Oh! repliqua-t-elle, le Soleil & les Astres sont tout de feu, le mouvement ne leur coúte rien; mais la Terre ne paroît guere portative. Et croiriez-vous, repris-je, si vous n'en aviez point l'experience, que ce fust quelque chose de bien portatif, qu'un gros Navire monté de cent-cinquante pieces de Canon, chargé de plus de trois mille hommes, & d'une tres-grande nombre de Marchãdises? Cependant il ne faut qu'un petit soufle de vent pour le faire aller sur l'eau, parce que l'eau est liquide, & que se laissant diviser avec facilité, elle résiste peu au mouvement du Navire. Ainsi la Terre, toute massive qu'elle est, est aisément portée dans la matiere celeste, qui est mille fois plus fluide que l'eau, & qui remplit tout ce grand espace où nagent les Planetes. Et où faudroit-il que la Terre fust cramponnée pour résister au mouvement de cette matiere celeste, & ne s'y pas laisser emporter? C'est comme si une petite boule de bois pouvoit ne pas suivre le courant d'une Riviere.</P010>
chunks.target_manual: <P008>Oh, says she, the Sun and Stars consist of fire, their motion costs them little; but the Earth seems not easily manageable. And would you believe, said I, if you did not know it by experience, that a great Ship mounted with an hundred and fifty pieces of Artilery, man'd with above three thousand men, and well laden with Merchandise, would be a thing easily portative? in the mean time a little puff of Wind suffices to drive it upon the Water; because the Water being liquid, is easily divided, and makes no resistance to the motion of the Ship; so the Earth, though an unweildy mass, is easily carried through the celestial matter, which is ten thousand times more fluid than Water, and fills all that vast space where the Planets swim. And where is it necessary that the Earth should be riveted to resist the motion of that Celestial matter? 'Tis as if a little Boul of Wood could be able not to follow the Current of a River.</P008>
explanations: The French 'pieces de Canon' (literally 'pieces of cannon') in the context of 'un gros Navire monté de cent-cinquante pieces de Canon' (a great Ship mounted with 150 pieces of Cannon) refers to 150 cannons. The translation 'pieces of Artilery' makes explicit two aspects: first, it clarifies that these are whole weapon units ('artillery pieces') rather than mere 'parts of cannons', and second, it explicitly states their classification as 'Artilery', a military category for such heavy weaponry. This information is implied in the French but is spelled out in the English translation.

The French 'toute massive qu'elle est' translates to 'as massive as it is' or 'however massive it is', emphasizing the Earth's great size and weight. The translation 'though an unweildy mass' makes explicit an implied consequence of this great mass: its unwieldiness, meaning it is difficult to move or manage. The adjective 'unweildy' directly states this characteristic, which was only suggested by 'massive' in the original phrase within the context of discussing the Earth's movement.

chunks.source_manual: <P011>Mais, repliqua-t-elle encore, comment la Terre avec tout son poids se soûtient-elle sur vostre matiere celeste, qui doit estre bien legere, puis qu'elle est si fluide? Ce n'est pas à dire, répondis-je, que ce qui est fluide, soit plus leger. Que dites-vous de nostre gros Vaisseau, qui avec tout son poids est plus léger que l'eau, puis qu'il y surnage? Je ne veux plus vous dire rien, dit-elle comme en colere, tant que vous aurez le gros Vaisseau. Mais m'assurez-vous bien qu'il n'y ait rien à craindre sur une piroüette aussi legere que vous me faites la Terre? Et bien, luy repondis-je, faisons porter la Terre par quatre Elephans, comme font les Indiens. Voicy bien un autre Systême, s'écria-t-elle. Du moins j'aime ces Gens-là d'avoir pourveu à leur seureté, & fait de bons fondemens, au lieu que nous autres Coperniciens, nous sommes assez inconsiderez pour vouloir bien nager à l'avanture dans cette matiere celeste. Je gage que si les Indiens sçavoient que la Terre fust le moins du monde en peril de se mouvoir, ils doubleroient les Elephans.</P011> <P012>Cela le meriteroit bien, repris-je, <NCP>en riant de sa pensée</NCP>, il ne faut point s'épargner les Elephans pour dormir en assurance, & si vous en avez besoin pour cette nuit, nous en mettrons dans nostre Systême autant qu'il vous plaira; ensuite nous les retrancherons peu à peu, à mesure que vous vous rassurerez. Serieusement, reprit-elle, je ne croy pas dés à present qu'ils me soient fort necessaires, & je me sens assez de courage pour oser tourner. Vous irez bien-tost encore plus loin, repliquay-je, vous tournerez avec plaisir, & vous vous ferez sur ce Systême des idées réjoüissantes. Quelquefois, par exemple, je me figure que je suis suspendu en l'air, & que j'y demeure sans mouvement pendant que la Terre tourne sous moy en vingt-quatre heures, & que je vois passer sous mes yeux tous ces visages differens, les uns blancs, les autres noirs, les autres bazannez, les autres olivâtres, que je voy d'abord des Chapeaux, & puis des Turbans, & puis des Testes cheveluës, & puis des Testes rases; tantost des Villes à clochers, tantost des Villes à longues aiguilles qui ont des Croissans, tantost des Villes à Tours de Porcelaine, tantost de grands Païs qui n'ont que des Cabanes; icy, des vastes Mers; là des Deserts épouvantables; enfin toute cette variesté infinie qui est sur la surface de la Terre.</P012>
chunks.target_manual: <P009>But, says she again, how is the Earth with all its weight supported in your Celestial matter, which being so fluid must needs be very light? That's not to be allow'd, said I, that what is more fluid is more light. What do you say to your great Vessel; which with all its weight must needs be lighter than the Water, because it swims upon it. Ile say no more to you, says she, as though angry, as long as you have that great Vessel. But can you assure me that there's nothing to be fear'd upon such a Shuttlecock or Whirligigg, as you make the Earth? Well, says I, let us carry the Earth upon four Elephants, as the Indians do. See, says she, another kind of System; yet truly, I like those people that provide for their security, and lay a good foundation; whereas we Copernicans in my opinion are rash enough to attempt to swim at a venture in that Celestial matter. Ile hold a Wager, that if the Indians knew the Earth were in the least danger in the world of being mov'd, they'd double their Elephants 'Twill be worth the while, said I, laughing at her Fancy, never spare an Elephant to sleep in security, and if you have occasion for them this night, we'l put as many in our System as you please, and afterward take them out again by little and little, as you begin to be more and more assured. Seriously, says she, I believe from this time forward I shall not much need them; for I find my self couragious enough to turn. You shall presently, says I, go yet farther, and have delightful Idea's of this System. Sometimes, for example, I fancy with my self that I hang in the Air, and continue there without motion while the Earth turns under me four and twenty hours, and I see pass under me all these different appearances, some white, some black, some swarthy, others tawny, now Hats, then Turbants, some Heads with Hair, others bald, by and by Towns with Steeples, then Towns with long Spires and Crescents, next Towns with Towers of Porcelain, then a large Country that has nothing but Cabins, here a vast Sea, there a frightful Desart, and in fine, all the infinite variety upon the face of the Earth.</P009>
target_segments: in my opinion are rash enough
explanations: The French 'une piroüette' (a pirouette/spin) is a general term for a light, spinning movement. The translation 'a Shuttlecock or Whirligigg' makes this more explicit by offering two concrete examples of objects known for such characteristics (lightness, spinning, potentially erratic movement). This provides the reader with a more vivid and specific image than the general term 'piroüette', clarifying the nature of the movement being discussed by adding illustrative examples not present in the source.

The French 'nous sommes assez inconsiderez' (we are quite inconsiderate/thoughtless), part of a statement by the Marquise, is a direct assertion. The English translation renders this as 'are rash enough' but prefaces it with 'in my opinion'. This addition explicitly frames the assertion as the Marquise's subjective viewpoint, spelling out a layer of meaning (the subjectivity of a character's statement) that was only implicitly understood from the context of character dialogue in the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P013>En verité, dit-elle, tout cela meriteroit bien que l'on donnast vingt-quatre heures de son temps à le voir. Ainsi donc dans le mesme lieu où nous sommes à present, je ne dis pas dans ce Parc, mais dans ce mesme lieu à le prendre dans l'air, il y passe continuellement d'autres Peuples qui prennent nostre place, & au bout de vingt-quatre heures nous y revenons.</P013>
chunks.target_manual: <P010>Truly, says she, it would be four and twenty hours well spent to see all this; so that in the same place where we are, I do not mean in this Park, but in the same place in the Air, other people are continually passing, and take our place, and in four and twenty hours we return here again.</P010>
explanations: The French 'meriteroit bien' (would well deserve/merit), in the context of 'que l'on donnast vingt-quatre heures de son temps à le voir' (that one might give twenty-four hours of one's time to see it), implies that the time invested would be worthwhile or used to good purpose. The English translation makes this implicit positive quality of the time explicit by using the phrase 'well spent,' directly characterizing the nature of the time invested rather than merely the deservingness of the action.

The French verb 'revenons' (from 'revenir,' meaning 'to return' or 'to come back') contains the prefix 're-,' which inherently signifies repetition or a movement back to a previous state or location. The English translation adds the adverb 'again' after 'return,' explicitly spelling out this repetitive aspect which is more compactly encoded within the morphology of the French verb.

chunks.source_manual: <P014>Copernic, luy répondis-je, ne le comprendroit pas mieux. D'abord il passera par icy des Anglois qui raisonneront peut-estre de quelque dessein de Politique avec moins de gayeté que nous ne raisonnons de nostre Philosophie; ensuite viendra une grànde Mer, & il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau qui n'y sera pas si à son aise que nous. Après cela Paroistront des <IIM>Iroquois</IIM>, qui mangeront tout vif quelque prisonnier de guerre, qui fera semblant de ne s'en pas soucier; des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso, qui n'employeront tout leur temps qu'à préparer le Repas de leurs Maris, & à se peindre de bleu les lévres & les sourcils, pour plaire aux plus <IIM> vilains Hommes du monde</IIM>; des Tartares qui iront fort devotement en Pelerinage vers ce Grand Prestre, qui ne sort jamais d'un lieu obscur où il n'est éclairé que par des Lampes, à la lumiere desquelles on l'adore; de belles Circassiennes qui ne feront aucune façon d'accorder tout au premier venu, horsmis ce qu'elles croyent qui appartient essentiellement à leurs Maris; de petits Tartares qui iront voler des Femmes pour les Turcs & pour les <IIM>Persans</IIM>; enfin, nous qui debiterons peut-estre encore des <NCE>resveries</NCE>.</P014>
chunks.target_manual: <P011>Copernicus himself, says I, could not apprehend it better; by and by you'l see some English men pass this way debating some point of Policy, but not so airily as we do our Philosophy; then comes a great Sea, where you'l see a Ship that possibly will not be so much at case as we are; afterward appear the Irroquoi's eating alive some Prisoner of War, who seems not much to heed it; then Women of the Land of Iesso, who spend their whole time in preparing Food for their Husbands, and painting their Lips and Eyebrows blue, to please the most villanous sort of men in the world; next Tartars going in Pilgrimage with great Devotion to that great Priest, who lives always shut up in a Hole where he has no Light, but a Lamp, by which they adore him; then come the fair Circassians, who make no scruple of granting all at first sight? only what they think belongs essentially to their Husbands. Then the little Tartars, who steal Women for the Turks and Persians; and lastly, we who possibly shall yet find other extravagant Inventions.</P011>
source_segments: D'abord il passera par icy des Anglois
il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau
des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso
qui ne sort jamais d'un lieu obscur
target_segments: by and by you'l see some English men pass this way
then Women of the Land of Iesso
who lives always shut up in a Hole
possibly shall yet find other extravagant Inventions.
explanations: The French "il passera" (they will pass/there will pass) is an impersonal construction indicating an event. The English "you'l see" explicitly casts the interlocutor (the Marquise) as the direct observer of this event, making her perceptual role explicit where it was only implied in the French.

The French "il se pourra trouver" (it might be found / one might find) is an impersonal phrasing suggesting the possible presence of a ship. The English "you'l see a Ship" again personalizes the observation, making the Marquise the explicit viewer, thereby making an implicit potential act of observation explicit and direct.

The French source lists "des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso" as an item in an unfolding series of visions. The English translation prefaces this phrase with "then," explicitly marking its sequential position in the narrative flow. This transition was implied by the list structure in the source, which followed an introductory phrase ("Après cela Paroistront des Iroquois") for a previous item.

Following the women of Jesso, the French text introduces "des Tartares" as the next group in the narrated sequence. The English translation explicitly reinforces this progression by adding the sequential marker "next" before "Tartars," making the link overt where it was implied by enumeration in French.

The French "qui ne sort jamais d'un lieu obscur" (who never leaves a dark place) describes the Great Priest's condition. The English "who lives always shut up in a Hole" makes this description more explicit and vivid by: 1) specifying "un lieu obscur" (a dark place) as "a Hole," a more concrete, confined, and potentially harsher image, and 2) rephrasing "ne sort jamais" (never leaves) as "lives always shut up," emphasizing the continuous state of confinement rather than just the action of not leaving.

The French source continues its list of visions with "de belles Circassiennes." The English translation introduces this group with "then come," which explicitly spells out their arrival and their place in the sequence, making the narrative connection more overt than the French list implies.

The French source presents "de petits Tartares" as the subsequent item in its enumerated list of visions. The English translation prefaces this with "Then," explicitly marking its sequential position in the narrative progression, a transition that was previously implied by list order in the source.

The French "debiterons peut-estre encore des resveries." (we will perhaps still utter/recount daydreams/fantasies) is translated as "possibly shall yet find other extravagant Inventions." The English rendering makes several implicit aspects explicit: "Inventions" is more concrete and suggests active creation compared to the more passive "resveries"; "extravagant" adds an explicit qualitative judgment; and the phrase "find other" implies a deliberate process of generating new, distinct ideas, and characterizes their current conversation (as "other" implies previous ones) in this specific light, thus altering the nuance from mere musing to active, perhaps wild, fabrication.

chunks.source_manual: <P015>Il est assez plaisant, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, d'imaginer ce que vous venez de me dire; mais si je voyois tout cela d'en haut, je voudrais avoir la liberté de hâter ou d'arrêter le mouvement de la Terre, selon que les objets me plairoient plus ou moins, & je vous assure que je ferais passer bien viste ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique, ou qui mangent leurs Ennemis; mais il y en a d'autres pour qui j'aurois de la curiosité. J'en aurais pour ces Belles Circassiennes, par exemple, elles ont un usage qui me paroist assez particulier. C'est qu'elle sont si belles, luy dis-je, que leurs Maris trovent dans leurs faveurs un superflu qu'ils abandonnent aux Etrangers. Les Femmes de ces Païs-cy sont donc bien laides aux prix d'elles, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, car le Maris ne relâchent rien. Cela est cause qu'on prend davantage, repliquay-je, au lieu que...Taisez-vous, interrompit-elle, je ne veux plus dire de folies, aussi bien il me vient une difficulté sérieuse. Si la Terre tourne, nous changeons d'air à chaque moment, & nous respirons toûjours celuy d'un autre Païs. Nullement, Madame, répondis-je, l'air qui environne la Terre ne s'étend que jusqu'à une certaine hauteur, peut-estre jusqu'à 20 lieües, il nous suit, & tourne avec nous. Vous avez veu mille fois l'ouvrage d'un Ver à Soye, ou ces Coques que ces petits animaux travaillent avec tant d'art pour s'y emprisonner. Elles sont d'une soye fort serrée, mais elles sont couvertes d'un certain duvet fort leger & fort lâche. C'est ainsi que la Terre, qui est assez solide, est couverte depuis sa surface jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur tout au plus, d'une espece de duvet, qui est l'air, & toute la Coque de Ver à Soye tourne en mesme temps. Au-delà de l'air est la matiere celeste, incomparablement plus pure, plus subtile, & mesme plus agitée que luy.</P015> <P016>Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. C'est pourtant sur cette Coque de Ver à Soye qu'il se fait de si grands Travaux, de si grandes Guerres, & qu'il regne de tous costez une si grande agitation. Oüy, répondis-je, & pendant ce temps-là la Nature qui n'entre point en connoissance de tous ces petits mouvemens particuliers, nous emporte tous ensemble d'un mouvement général, & se joüe de la petite boule.</P016> <P017>Il me semble, reprit-elle, qu'il est ridicule d'estre sur quelque chose qui tourne, & de se tourmenter tant; mais le malheur est qu'on n'est pas assez assuré qu'on tourne; car enfin, à ne vous rien celer, toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'apperçoive du mouvement de la Terre, me sont un peu suspectes. Est-il possible qu'il ne laissera pas quelque petite marque sensible à laquelle on le reconnoisse?</P017> <P018>Les mouvemens les plus naturels, répondis-je, & les plus ordinaires sont ceux qui se font le moins sentir, & cela est vray jusque dans la Morale. Le mouvement de l'Amour propre nous est si naturel, que le plus souvent nous ne le sentons pas, & que nous croyons agir par d'autres principes. Ah! vous <IIM>moralisez</IIM>, dit- elle, quand il est question de <RW>Phisique</RW>, cela s'appelle baailler. Retirons-nous, aussi bien en Voila assez pour la premiere fois. Demain nous reviendrons icy, vous avec vos Systêmes, & moy avec mon Ignorance.</P018>
chunks.target_manual: <P012>'Tis pleasant enough, says the Marchioness, to imagin all this you tell me; but if I saw it all from an height, I should wish to have the liberty to hasten or stop the motion of the Earth, according as the Objects pleas'd or displeas'd me; and, I assure you, I should presently turn away those that trouble their Heads with Policy, or eat their Enemies; but for some others I should have a curiosity; particularly for those fair Circassians, they have a custom which methinks is very particular. 'Tis, says I, because they are so fair that their Husbands find in their favours a superfluity, which they allow to strangers. Then the Women of this Country, says the Marchioness, are very ugly, compared with them, for the Husbands here give no liberty at all. That's the reason, says I, they take more, whereas-Hold your peace, says she, I'le talk no more follies; besides I have a serious difficulty come in my head, If the Earth turn, we change Air every moment, and breath that of another Contry. Not at all, Madam, says I, the Air which surrounds the Earth extends but to a certain height, it may be twenty leagues or so, and it follows and turns along with us. You have a thousand times seen the Work of a Silkworm, or those Cods of Silk which those little Animals work with so much Art for their own Prison, they are of a close wrought Silk, but are covered with a certain Down very light and loose. Just so the Earth. which is solid enough, is cover'd from the surface about twenty leagues high at most, with a kind of Down, which is the Air; This and all the other Cod of the Silkworm turns at the same time. Beyond the Air is the Celestial matter incomparably more pure, more subtil, and likewise more in motion than it. You give me, said the Marchioness, Idea's of the Earth contemptible enough; is it then upon this shell of a Silkworm that we labour and toil, and fight, and make such a noise on all hands as we do? 'Tis even so, said I, and in the mean time Nature that takes no notice of those little tle particular motions, carrys us altogether with one general movement, and sports her self with the lit-Ball. To me, says she, it seems something ridiculous to be seated upon a thing that turns? and torment ones self so much; but the mischief is, we are not fully assur'd that we turn; for to tell you truth, notwithstanding all those precautions you have us'd, that a man should not perceive the motion of the Earth, I am still very doubtful. Is it possible it should not be discover'd by some little mark or other? The most natural motions, said I, and the most ordinary, are those which are least perceiv'd, and this is true even in Morality it self. The motion of Self-love is so natural to us, that most commonly we are not at all sensible of it, and think that we are acted by some other principle. Ah! says she, when there's a Question in <NCE>Natural Philosophy</NCE>, you begin to moralize, and that's call'd Bantring. Let us now retire, for this is enough for once. To morrow we'l come here again, you with your Systems, and I with my Ignorance.</P012>
source_segments: toute la Coque de Ver à Soye
qu'il regne de tous costez une si grande agitation
target_segments: This and all the other Cod of the Silkworm
make such a noise on all hands as we do?
explanations: The French "ne relâchent rien" (literally "don't release/give up anything"), in the context of husbands' control over wives' "faveurs," is made more explicit by "give no liberty at all." The target text clarifies that "rien" (nothing) specifically refers to "liberty" concerning their wives' conduct, a meaning implied by the preceding discussion on Circassian customs but not overtly stated in "rien."

The French "Coques" (cocoons), used in conjunction with "Ver à Soye" (Silkworm), implicitly refers to cocoons made of silk. The translation "Cods of Silk" makes the material component "Silk" explicit, thereby providing clarifying information about the nature of the "Cods" (cocoons) that was only implied in the original.

The French "toute la Coque de Ver à Soye" (the whole silkworm cocoon), which in the phrase "toute la Coque de Ver à Soye tourne" refers metaphorically to the Earth-atmosphere system turning, is translated and expanded to "This and all the other Cod of the Silkworm" (which then precedes 'turns'). The translation re-writes the original by adding "all the other Cod of the Silkworm" as an explicit co-subject alongside "This" (the Earth system). This addition spells out that literal silkworm cocoons are also considered to be turning, expanding the original statement by making explicit an additional element of comparison not directly stated as an actor in the French text.

The French impersonal construction "qu'il regne de tous costez une si grande agitation" (that there reigns on all sides such great agitation) is translated into an active construction where humans are the explicit agents: "[we] make such a noise on all hands as we do?". The introduction of "we" as the agent (implied subject of "make" and emphatically reiterated in "as we do") makes explicit the human source of the "agitation" (rendered as "noise"), which was only implied in the French.

The French "Phisique" (Physics) is translated as "Natural Philosophy." In the 17th-century context of Fontenelle's work, "phisique" denoted the broader study of nature, which was termed "Natural Philosophy" in contemporaneous English. The translation makes this implicit historical scope explicit by using the specific English term for that wider field of inquiry, clarifying for the reader that the discussion pertains to this broader domain rather than the more narrowly defined modern science of physics.

chunks.source_manual: <P019>En retournant au Château je luy dis pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes, qu'il y en avoit un troisiéme inventé par Ticho- Brahé qui, voulant absolument que la Terre fust immobile, la plaçoit au centre du Monde, & faisoit tourner autour d'elle le Soleil, autour duquel tournoient toutes les autres Planetes, parce que depuis les nouvelles Découvertes, il n'y avoit pas moyen de faire tourner les Planetes autour de la Terre. Mais la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qui a le discernement vif & prompt, jugea qu'il y avoit trop d'affectation à exempter la Terre de tourner autour du Soleil, puis qu'on n'en pouvait pas exempter tant d'autres grands Corps; que le Soleil n'estoit plus si propre à tourner autour de la Terre, depuis que toutes les Planetes tournoient autour de luy; que ce Systême ne pouvoit estre propre tout au plus qu'à soûtenir l'Immobilité de la Terre, quand on avoit bien envie de la soûtenir, & nullement à la persuader; & enfin il fut résolu que nous nous en tiendrions à celuy de Copernic, qui est plus uniforme & plus riant, & n'a aucun mélange de préjugé. En effet la simplicité dont il est, vous persuade, & sa hardiesse vous fait plaisir.</P019>
chunks.target_manual: <P013>In our return to the Castle, I told her, to carry on the business of Systems, that there was a third sort invented by Tycho Brahe, who being absolutely of opinion that the Earth was immovable, plac'd it in the Center of the World, and made the Sun turn about it, and all the Planets about the Sun; because since the new Discoveries, there was no way left to make the Planets turn about the Earth. But the Marchioness, who is of a quick and lively Judgment, was of opinion that it was too much Affectation to exempt the Earth from turning about the Sun, since so many other great Bodies could not be exempted; That it was not so proper for the Sun to turn about the Earth, since all the Planets turn'd about him. That that System was at best only propet to maintain the Immobility of the Earth, when any one had a mind to maintain it, but not at all to persuade it. In fine, we resolv'd to hold to that of Copernicus, which is more uniform, and more delightful, and has no mixture of prejudice. In effect the Simplicity of it persuades, and the Boldness delights.</P013>
source_segments: voulant absolument que la Terre fust immobile
target_segments: being absolutely of opinion that the Earth was immovable
explanations: The French "voulant absolument que la Terre fust immobile" (absolutely wanting/insisting the Earth to be immobile) conveys Tycho Brahe's strong desire or insistence. The translation "being absolutely of opinion that the Earth was immovable" makes explicit the underlying basis for this insistence: it is presented not merely as a desire, but as a firmly held intellectual conviction or belief ("opinion"). The translator clarifies that Tycho's stance was one of fixed belief, which was only implied by the strength of "voulant absolument" in the source.

The French phrase "il n'y avoit pas moyen" (there was no way, or it was not possible) states a direct impossibility. The English translation "there was no way left" makes explicit an implication that other possibilities might have been considered or might have existed before the "new Discoveries" but were now exhausted or ruled out. The addition of "left" specifies that the set of viable explanations had been depleted by scientific progress, a nuance not explicitly stated in the source.

chunks.source_manual: <P020>SECOND SOIR.</P020>
chunks.target_manual: <P014>THE Second Evening.</P014>
explanations: The French source 'SECOND SOIR.' is a standard, concise title form for what would contextually be 'Le Second Soir' (The Second Evening). In such French titles, the definite article is often omitted for brevity, with definiteness being implied. The English translation 'THE Second Evening.' makes this implied definiteness explicit by adding the article 'THE'. An English title form like 'Second Evening' (omitting the article, similar to 'Chapter One' or 'Act Two') would also have been grammatically acceptable and more structurally parallel to the French. The translator's choice to include 'THE' explicitly states the definiteness that was only implicit in the concise French heading, thereby increasing the level of explicitness.

chunks.source_manual: <P021>Le lendemain au matin dés que l'on pût entrer dans l'Appartement de la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, j'envoyay sçavoir de ses nouvelles, & luy demander si elle avoit pû dormir en tournant. Elle me fit répondre qu'elle estoit déjà toute accoûtumée à cette allûre de la Terre, & qu'elle avoit passé la nuit aussi tranquillement qu'auroit pû faire Copernic luy-mesme. Quelque temps après il vint chez elle du monde qui y demeura jusqu'au soir, selon l'ennuyeuse coutume de la Campagne. Encore leur fut-on bien obligé, car la Campagne leur donnoit aussi le droit de pousser leur visite jusqu'au lendemain, s'ils eussent voulu, & ils eurent l'honnesteté de ne le pas faire. Ainsi la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> & moy nous nous retrouvâmes libres le Soir. Nous allâmes encore dans le Parc, & la Conversation ne manqua pas de tourneraussi-tost sur nos Sistêmes. Elle les avoit si bien conceus, qu'elle dédaigna d'en parler une seconde fois, & elle voulut que je la menasse a quelque chose de nouveau. Et bien donc, luy dis-je, puis que le Soleil, qui est presentement immobile, a cessé d'estre Planete, & que la Terre qui se meut autour de luy, a commencé d'en estre une, vous ne serez pas si surprise d'entendre dire que la Lune est une Terre comme celle-cy, & qu'apparemment elle est habitée. Je n'ay pourtant jamais oüy parler de la Lune habitée, dit-elle, que comme d'une <IIM>folie & d'une vision</IIM>. C'en est peut-estre une aussi, répondis-je. Je ne prens party dans ces choses-là que comme on en prend dans les Guerres Civiles, où l'incertitude de ce qui peut arriver, fait qu'on entretient toûjours des <IIM>intelligences</IIM> dans le party opposé, & <IIM>qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mesmes</IIM>. Pour moy, quoyque je voye la Lune habitée, je ne laisse pas de vivre civilement avec ceux qui ne le croyent pas, <SC></SC> & je me tiens toûjours en estat de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus; mais en attendant qu'ils ayent sur nous quelque avantage considérable, voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté des Habitans de la Lune.</P021>
chunks.target_manual: <P015>NExt Morning, as soon as the Marchioness could be seen, I sent to know how she did, and to ask her if she could sleep well turning? She sent me word, that she was so well accustomed to that sort of motion of the Earth, that she pass'd the night as quietly as Copernicus himself could have done. Soon after she had Company came to her, who, according to the troublesome Custome in the Country, stay'd with her till Evening; and they were obliging in that too; for by the Custom in the Country they had a right to continue their Visits till next morning if they pleas'd; but they were so honest as to be gone. So that the Marchioness and I found our selves at liberty in the Evening. We took our Walk again into the Park, and our Conversation fail'd not to return presently to our Systems. She had apprehended them so well, that she disdain'd to discourse of them a second time, but would needs have me lead her to some new matter.</P015> <P016>Well then, said I, since the Sun, that is now immovable, is no more a Planet, and that the Earth, that moves about him, has begun to be one, you will not be so surpriz'd to hear that the Moon is an Earth like this, and that apparently she is inhabited. Truly, says she, I never yet heard speak of the Moon's being inhabited, but only as a Folly and a Vision. Possibly 'tis such, said I. I do not ingage in things of that nature, but as men ingage in a Civil War, where the incertainty of the event makes them still hold inteligence with the opposite Party, and maintain an Intrigue with the very Enemy. For my part, though I should see the Moon inhabited, yet I would still live civilly with those that do not believe it, and I preserve my self in such a condition, that I may with Honour subscribe to their Opinion, if it prevail. But in the mean while, till they get some considerable advantages over us, see what it is has drawn me to side with the Inhabitants of the Moon.</P016>
target_segments: has drawn me to side with
explanations: The French "ne le pas faire" (not to do it), which implicitly refers to not extending their visit as per the country custom, is translated with the phrase "as to be gone." This makes the positive action of the guests' departure explicit, rather than just stating the negation of overstaying.

The French "a quelque chose de nouveau" (to something new) is translated as "to some new matter." The general term "chose" (thing) is rendered as "matter," which explicitly clarifies that the "something new" refers to a new subject or topic for their intellectual discussion, information that was only implied by context in the original.

The French adjectival phrase "de la Lune habitée" (of the inhabited Moon) is expanded in the English translation to "of the Moon's being inhabited." This gerund construction more explicitly spells out the *concept* or *proposition* of the Moon being inhabited as a topic of discussion, rather than simply describing the Moon with an attribute.

The French "des ménagemens," a nuanced term which can mean tactful dealings, careful handling, or arrangements, is translated as "an Intrigue." The English word "Intrigue" explicitly denotes a specific type of clandestine, possibly manipulative, interaction. This makes a potential, contextually implied aspect of "ménagemens" (especially in the philosopher's analogy of dealing with enemies in a civil war) explicit and more defined.

The French "ranger à leur opinion" (to align with/adopt their opinion) is translated as "subscribe to their Opinion." The English verb "subscribe to" makes the nature of the agreement more explicit, suggesting a more formal, conscious, and intellectual commitment to the opinion, whereas the French "se ranger à" is more general and can simply mean to come around to or side with.

The French "m'a mis du côté" (literally, "has put me on the side") primarily states the result of adopting a particular stance. The English translation "has drawn me to side with" makes the process or underlying cause more explicit by using "drawn me," suggesting an element of attraction, persuasion, or intellectual pull leading to this alignment, which was only implicit in the French phrasing.

chunks.source_manual: <P022>Suposons qu'il n'y ait jamais eu nul commerce entre <NCE>Paris & Saint-Denis</NCE>, & qu'un Bourgeois de Paris qui ne sera jamais sorty de sa Ville, soit sur les Tours de <NCE>Nostre Dame</NCE>, & voye <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE> de loin, on luy demandera s'il croit que <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE> soit habité <SC>comme Paris</SC>. Il répondra hardiment que non; car, dira- t-il, je voy bien les Habitans de Paris, mais ceux de Saint Denis, je ne les voy point, & on n'en a jamais entendu parler. Il y aura quelqu'un qui luy representera qu'à la verité quand on est sur les <NCE>Tours de Nostre Dame</NCE>, on ne voit pas les Habitans de Saint Denis, mais que l'éloignement en est cause; que tout ce qu'on peut voir de Saint Denis ressemble fort à Paris: que Saint Denis a des Clochers, des Maisons, des Murailles, & qu'il pourroit bien encore ressembler à Paris pour ce qui est d'estre habité. Tout cela ne gagnera rien sur mon Bourgeois, il s'obstinera toûjours à soûtenir que Saint Denis n'est point habité, puis qu'il n'y voit personne. Nostre Saint Denis c'est la Lune, & chacun de nous est ce Bourgeois de Paris, qui n'est jamais sorty de sa Ville.</P022>
chunks.target_manual: <P017>Let us suppose that there was never any Commerce between Paris and St. Denis (a Town about three miles from Paris) and that a Burgess of Paris, who never stirr'd out of the Town, should from the top of Nostre Dame see Saint Denis at a distance, the question is put him, whether he believes that Saint Denis is inhabited as Paris is or not, he'l confidently say no; for, says he, I see plainly the Inhabitants of Paris, but those of Saint Denis I do not see at all, nor ever heard speak of them. Some standerby may tell him, that 'tis true indeed that from the top of Nostre Dame the Inhabitants of Saint Denis are not seen, but that 'tis the distance is the cause, that all that can be seen of Saint Denis is very like Paris, that Saint Denis has Steeples, and Houses and Walls, and possibly may likewise resemble Paris in being inhabited, all this will not prevail with my honest Burgess, he's still obstinate that Saint Denis cannot be inhabited, because he sees not a man in it. Our Saint Denis is the Moon, and every one of us is just such a Burgess of Paris that never stirr'd out of the Town.</P017>
target_segments: St. Denis (a Town about three miles from Paris)
just such a Burgess of Paris
explanations: The French 'Saint-Denis' refers to a specific town. The translator makes its geographical context and relationship to Paris explicit for an English audience by adding the descriptive phrase '(a Town about three miles from Paris)', information assumed as implicit knowledge for the original French readership, thus clarifying the analogy.

The French 'mon Bourgeois' (my Burgess/citizen) implies a certain character type through context and narrative tone. The translator makes a specific interpretation of this character explicit by adding the adjective 'honest'. In the period's English, 'honest' could connote simplicity or unpretentiousness, thereby adding a descriptive layer to the character that was more subtly implied in the original.

The French 'ce Bourgeois de Paris' (this/that Burgess of Paris) uses a demonstrative adjective 'ce' to link to the previously described character. The English translation 'just such a Burgess of Paris' expands on this by using 'just such a' to explicitly emphasize the exact nature and degree of the resemblance ('of that very kind'), making the identification more forceful and precise than the simple demonstrative 'ce' might convey alone.

chunks.source_manual: <P023>Ah! interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous nous faites tort, nous ne sommes point si sots que vostre Bourgeois. Puis qu'il voit que Saint Denis est tout fait comme Paris, il faut qu'il ait perdu la raison pour ne le pas croire habité; mais la Lune n'est point du tout faite comme la Terre. Prenez garde, Madame, repris-je, car s'il faut que la Lune ressemble en tout à la Terre, vous Voila dans l'obligation de croire la Lune habitée. J'avoüe, répondit-elle, qu'il n'y aura pas moyen de s'en dispenser, & je vous vois un air de confiance qui me fait déjà peur. Les deux mouvemens de la Terre dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée, me <IIM>rendent timide sur tout le reste</IIM>, mais pourtant seroit-il bien possible que la Terre fût lumineuse comme la Lune? Car il faut cela pour leur ressemblance. Helas! Madame, repliquay-je, estre lumineux n'est pas si grand-chose que vous pensez. Il n'y a que le Soleil en qui cela soit une qualité considérable. Il est lumineux par luy-mesme, & en vertu d'une nature particuliere qu'il a, mais les Planetes n'éclairent que parce qu'elles sont éclairées de luy. Il envoye sa lumiere à la Lune, elle nous la renvoye, & il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumiere du Soleil; il n'y a pas plus loin de la Terre à la Lune, que de la Lune à la Terre.</P023>
chunks.target_manual: <P018>Oh! said the Marchioness, you do us wrong, we are not so dull as your Burgess; he that sees Saint Denis wholly made like Paris, must needs have lost his Reason, not to believe that 'tis inhabited; but the Moon is not at all made like the Earth. Have a care, Madam, said I, for if I prove that the Moon must resemble the Earth, you are then downright oblig'd to believe that the Moon is inhabited. I acknowledge, says she, there will be no way to avoid it; and I observe in your looks an air of confidence that makes me half afraid. The two motions of the Earth, of which I shall never make any doubt, make me timorous in all the rest; but however, is it possible that the Earth should be luminous as the Moon is? for that must be to make up the resemblance. Alas, Madam, said I, to be luminous is not so a great matter as you imagine; there is only the Sun in which that quality is considerable; he is luminous in himself, by vertue of a nature peculiar to him, but the Planets give no Light, but as they are inlighten'd by him. He sends his Light to the Moon, she returns it to us, and it must needs be likewise, that the Earth sends the Light of the Sun to the Moon; for 'tis no farther from the Earth to the Moon, than from the Moon to the Earth.</P018>
explanations: The French impersonal construction 's'il faut que' (if it is necessary that / if it must be that) is translated as 'if I prove that'. This change makes explicit the philosopher's active role ('I prove') in establishing the premise of the argument. This agency, while implied in the overall dialogic context of the work where the philosopher is persuading the Marquise, is spelled out here, clarifying his argumentative stance.

The French prepositional phrase 'pour leur ressemblance' (for their resemblance) indicates purpose or condition. The English translation 'to make up the resemblance' is more explicit about the nature of this relationship. It specifies that the preceding condition ('cela' - that) is a constituent part or a necessary factor that actively forms or completes ('make up') the resemblance, rather than just being generally 'for' it or a prerequisite for it.

The French 'aussi' (also), appearing in 'il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumiere du Soleil', indicates that the Earth, in addition to other celestial bodies or phenomena previously discussed (like the Moon reflecting light to Earth), performs a similar action. The English translation uses 'likewise' in the construction 'it must needs be likewise, that the Earth sends...'. This placement and choice of 'likewise' explicitly frames the entire subsequent clause about the Earth as an analogy to the preceding discussion. This makes the analogical reasoning, which is more subtly implied by 'aussi', overt and structurally prominent.

chunks.source_manual: <P024>Mais, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, la Terre est-elle aussi propre que la Lune à renvoyer la lumiere au Soleil? Je vous vois toûjours pour la Lune, repris-je, un reste d'estime dont vous ne sçauriez vous défaire. La lumiere est composée de petites balles qui bondissent sur ce qui est solide <UP></UP>, & retournent d'un autre costé, au lieu qu'elles passent au travers de ce qui leur presente des ouvertures en ligne droite, comme l'air ou le verre. Ainsi ce qui fait que la Lune nous éclaire, c'est qu'elle est un Corps dur & solide, qui nous renvoye ces petites balles. Or je croy que vous ne contesterez pas à la Terre cette mesme dureté & cette mesme solidité. Admirez donc ce que c'est que d'estre posté avantageusement. Parce que la Lune est éloignée de nous, nous ne la voyons que comme un Corps lumineux, & nous ignorons que ce soit une grosse masse, toute semblable à la Terre. <IIM>Au contraire,</IIM> parce que la Terre a le malheur que nous la voyons de trop prés, elle ne nous paroist qu'une grosse masse, propre seulement à fournir de la pasture aux Animaux, & nous ne nous apercevons pas qu'elle est lumineuse, faute de nous pouvoir mettre à quelque distance d'elle. Cela va de la mesme maniere, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que quand nous sommes frapez de l'éclat des Conditions élevées au-dessus des nostres, & que nous ne voyons pas qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extremement.</P024> <P025>C'est la mesme chose, répondis-je. Nous voulons juger de tout, & nous sommes toûjours dans un mauvais point de veüe. Nous voulons juger de nous, nous en sommes trop près; nous voulons juger des autres, nous en sommes trop loin. Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place pour les bien voir. Il faudroit estre simplement Spectateur du Monde, & non pas Habitant. Je ne me consoleray jamais, dit-elle, de l'injustice que nous faisons à la Terre, & de la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune, si vous ne m'assurez que les Gens de la Lune ne connaissent pas mieux leurs avantages que nous connoissons les nostres, & qu'ils prennent nostre Terre pour un Astre, sans sçavoir que leur habitation en est un aussi. Pour cela, repris-je, je vous le garantis. Nous leur paroissons faire assez regulierement nos fonctions d'Astres. Il est vray qu'ils ne nous voyent pas décrire un Cercle autour d'eux, mais il n'importe, voicy ce que c'est. La moitié de la Lune qui se trouva tournée vers nous au commencement du Monde, y a toûjours esté tournée depuis; elle ne nous presente jamais que ces yeux, cette bouche, & le reste de ce visage que nostre imagination luy compose sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre. Si l'autre moitié opposée se presentoit à nous, d'autres tâches differemment arrangées, nous feroient sans doute imaginer quelque autre figure. Ce n'est pas que la Lune ne tourne sur elle-mesme, elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois; mais lors qu'elle fait une partie de ce tremblement <RW></RW>, & de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient.</P025>
chunks.target_manual: <P019>But, says the Marchioness, is the Earth as proper as the Moon to reflect the Light of the Sun? I observe, said I, that you have still a good thought for the Moon, which you cannot part with. The Light is composed of little Balls, that rebound from any thing that is solid, whereas they pass in a straight line through any thing that opens to them, as the Air, or Glass. So that hence it is that the Moon gives us Light, because she is a hard solid body that reflects those little Balls upon us. Now I believe you will not at all contest the solidity of the Earth. Admire then what it is to be advantagiously plac'd. The Moon being so far distant from us, we only behold it as a luminous body, and know not that 'tis a great mass like the Earth. On the contrary, because the Earth has the ill luck to be seen by us near at hand, she appears to us a great mass fit for nothing but to feed Cattel, and cannot discern that she is luminous, because we cannot set our selves at distance enough from her. Just so, said she, we are dazl'd with the lustre of Conditions more elevated than our own, and never discern that in the bottom they are extremely alike.</P019> <P020>'Tis even so, said I we would judge of all, but are still ill placed to take our view; in judging of our selves we are too near, and in judging of others too far off. The middle place between the Moon and the Earth is the best to take a right prospect of both; and better it would be, to be simply a Spectator of the World than an Inhabitant. I shall never be comforted, says she, for the Injustice we do the Earth, and our too much partiality to the Moon, unless you assure me that the people of the Moon, have no more knowledge of their Advantages than we have of ours, and that they take our Earth for a Star, without knowing that their own Habitation is so likewise. I'le warrant you for that, said I, we appear to them to perform our function of a Star regularly enough: 'tis true they do not see us describe a Circle about them; but 'tis no matter, the thing is this; The half of the Moon which was turn'd towards us at the beginning of the World, has continued so ever since, she still shews the same Eyes, the same Mouth, and all the rest of the Face, which those Spots we discern in her, frame in our Imagination; if we saw the other half, other kind of Spots, in different posture, would doubtless create in our Imagination other kind of Figures. 'Tis not that the Moon does not turn about her self, 'tis certain she turns in just so much time as she turns about the Earth, that is, in a month. But when she has made one part of that turn about her self, and that she ought to hide, for example, one Cheek of that pretended Face from us, and appear some other thing, she makes the like part of her Circle about the Earth, and putting her self in a new point of sight, shews us still the same Cheek. So that the Moon, that in respect of the Sun and other Stars, turns about her self, in respect of us turns not all. She sees them all rise and set in the space of fifteen days, but our Earth she sees daily hanging in the same place of Heaven. This seeming Immobility agrees not well with a body which ought to pass for a Star; but 'tis true likewise that she her self is not perfect. The Moon has a certain wavering motion <RW>(motus libratorius)</RW> which is the cause that a little corner of her Face is sometimes hid, and a little corner of the opposite side appears. Now I'le undertake, that she imputes that wavering to us, and imagines that we have a movement to and fro in the Heavens like a Pendulum.</P020>
source_segments: propre seulement à fournir de la pasture aux Animaux
nous sommes toûjours dans un mauvais point de veüe.
de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient.
target_segments: fit for nothing but to feed Cattel
are still ill placed to take our view;
a certain wavering motion (motus libratorius) which is the cause that a little corner of her Face is sometimes hid, and a little corner of the opposite side appears.
Now I'le undertake, that she imputes that wavering to us, and imagines that we have a movement to and fro in the Heavens like a Pendulum.
explanations: The translator changes the general term "Animaux" (animals) to the more specific "Cattel" (livestock) and renders the phrase "propre seulement à fournir de la pasture" (fit only to provide pasture) as the more emphatic "fit for nothing but to feed." This specification narrows the scope of animals implied by "pasture" and intensifies the description, making the Earth's perceived limited utility more explicitly defined and vivid than in the source text.

The French "dans un mauvais point de veüe" (in a bad point of view/from a bad vantage point) is translated as "ill placed to take our view." The addition of the clause "to take our view" makes explicit the implied action or purpose (the act of observing or forming a judgment) for which the "point de veüe" is relevant and inadequate, which was only implicit in the French.

The French declarative statement "elle y tourne..." (it turns there...), referring to the Moon's rotation, is rendered by the translator as "'tis certain she turns...". The addition of the phrase "'tis certain" explicitly marks the certainty of the information, an emphasis not directly present in the French phrasing.

The French term "ce tremblement" (this trembling/quivering), which refers to the Moon's libration, is translated as "a certain wavering motion." The translator then significantly expands on this by: 1) adding the specific technical Latin term "(motus libratorius)"; and 2) appending an explanatory clause, "which is the cause that a little corner of her Face is sometimes hid, and a little corner of the opposite side appears." This clause details the nature and observable effects of libration, information that was only alluded to by the concise French term.

The French infinitive phrase "de s'imaginer que nous avons..." ([for the Moon] to imagine that we have...) is introduced in the English translation by the added framing: "Now I'le undertake, that she imputes that wavering to us, and imagines that...". The clause "she imputes that wavering to us" explicitly articulates the psychological mechanism (imputation) and specifies that the Moon projects its own previously detailed "wavering" motion (libration) onto the Earth as the reason for its perceived pendulum-like movement. This detailed causal link and interpretation are spelled out, whereas they are at best implied in the provided French fragment. The phrase "Now I'le undertake" also adds a distinct authorial interjection from the narrator.

chunks.source_manual: <P026>Toutes ces Planetes, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, sont faites comme nous, qui rejettons toûjours sur les autres ce qui est en nous-mesmes. La Terre dit, Ce n'est pas moy qui tourne, c'est le Soleil. La Lune dit, Ce n'est pas moy qui tremble, c'est la Terre. Il y a bien de l'erreur par tout. Je ne vous conseille pas d'entreprendre d'y rien réformer, répondis-je; il vaut mieux que vous acheviez de vous convaincre de l'entiere ressemblance de la Terre & de la Lune. Representez-vous ces deux grandes Boules suspendües dans les Cieux. Vous sçavez que le Soleil éclaire toûjours une moitié des Corps qui sont ronds, & que l'autre moitié est dans l'ombre. Il y a donc toûjours une moitié, tant de la Terre que de la Lune, qui est éclairée du Soleil, c'est à dire, qui a le jour, & une autre moitié qui est dans la nuit. Remarquez d'ailleurs que comme une Balle a moins de force & de vistesse aprés qu'elle a esté donner contre une muraille qui l'a renvoyée d'un autre costé, de mesme la lumiere s'affoiblit lors qu'elle a esté réfléchie par quelque Corps. Cette lumiere blanchâtre qui nous vient de la Lune, est la lumiere mesme du Soleil, mais elle ne peut venir de la Lune à nous que par une réflexion. Elle a donc beaucoup perdu de la force & de la vivacité qu'elle avoit lors qu'elle estoit receüe directement sur la Lune, & cette lumiere éclatante que nous recevons directement du Soleil & que la Terre reflechit sur la Lune, ne doit plus estre qu'une lumiere blanchâtre quand elle y est arrivée. Ainsi ce qui nous paroit lumineux dans la Lune, & qui nous éclaire pendant nos nuits, ce sont des parties de la Lune qui ont le jour, & les parties de la Terre qui ont le jour, lors qu'elles sont tournées vers les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit, les éclairent aussi. Tout dépend de la maniere dont la Lune & la Terre se regardent. Dans les premiers jours du mois que l'on ne voit pas la Lune, c'est qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & qu'elle marche de jour avec le Soleil. Il faut necessairement que toute sa moitié qui a le jour, soit tournée vers le Soleil, & que toute sa moitié qui a la nuit, soit tournée vers nous. Nous n'avons garde de voir cette moitié qui n'a aucune lumiere pour se faire voir. Mais cette moitié de la Lune qui a la nuit, estant tournée vers la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, nous voit sans estre veüe, & nous voit sous la même figure que nous voyons la Pleine Lune. C'est alors pour les Gens de la Lune Pleine Terre, s'il est permis de parler ainsi. Ensuite la Lune qui avance sur son Cercle d'un mois, se dégage de dessous le Soleil, & commence à tourner vers nous un petit coin de sa moitié éclairée, & voila le Croissant. Alors aussi les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit, commencent à ne plus voir toute la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, & nous sommes en Decours pour elles.</P026>
chunks.target_manual: <P021>All these Planets, says the Marchioness, I find are made like us, who are still charging others with what is in our selves; the Earth says, 'Tis not I that turn, 'tis the Sun: The Moon says, 'Tis not I that waver, 'tis the Earth: there's faults enough every where. I would not advise you, said I, to attempt a Reformation: 'Tis better that you fully convince your self of the perfect resemblance of the Earth and Moon. Represent to your self those two great Bouls hanging in the Heavens. You know that the Sun always enlightens one half of a Spherical body, and that the other half is in the Shadow. Then the Sun daily enlightens one half both of the Earth and the Moon, viz. in one half 'tis day, in the other night. Observe moreover, that as a Ball loses its force when reverberated from a Wall, so likewise the light grows weak when reflected from another body. That pale Light which we receive from the Moon, is the very Light of the Sun, but it cannot come to us but by Reflection. It must therefore lose much of the force and vivacity it had when it fell directly upon the Moon. So that glittering Light which we receive directly from the Sun, and is reflected from the Earth to the Moon, must needs be but a pale Light when it reaches thither. So that which appears to us luminous in the Moon, and which enlightens us in our nights, is the parts of the Moon where it is then day, and the parts of the Earth where it is day being turn'd towards the parts of the Moon where it is night, inlightens them likewise; all depends upon the manner of the Moon and Earths regarding one another. In the first days of a month, when the Moon is not seen, she is then between the Sun and us, and moves by day along with the Sun. It must needs be, that the half of her where it is day is turn'd toward the Sun, and her other half that is benighted is turn'd towards us. We do not look to see that half that has no Light to shew it self, but that half of the Moon that is benighted being turn'd toward the half of the Earth where it is day, sees us without being seen, and sees us in the same figure as we see the full Moon. 'Tis then, with the Inhabitants of the Moon, full Earth, if I may be permitted the expression. Afterward the Moon, which advances in her monthly Circle, disingages from under the Sun, and begins to shew us a little corner of her inlighten'd half; and that's the Crescent: and then likewise the parts of the Moon that are benighted begin not to see all the half of the Earth that is inlighten'd, and we are running from them.</P021>
source_segments: toute sa moitié qui a la nuit
nous sommes en Decours pour elles
target_segments: I find are made like us
her other half that is benighted
and we are running from them
explanations: The French "sont faites comme nous" (are made like us) is a direct assertion by the Marquise. The English translation "I find are made like us" adds the phrase "I find," explicitly articulating the Marquise's subjective process of discovery or realization, which was only implied in the original French statement.

The French "des Corps qui sont ronds" (of bodies that are round) uses a general descriptive term. The English translation "of a Spherical body" employs a more precise, scientific term. This explicitation clarifies the specific geometric shape implied by "ronds" in an astronomical context, enhancing the scientific register for the reader.

The French phrase "est éclairée du Soleil" (is lit by the Sun), part of a clause describing a state of illumination, corresponds functionally to the English active verb phrase. The translation renders this concept as "daily enlightens" (where 'the Sun' is the subject). The key explicitation is the addition of "daily," which specifies the cyclical, recurring nature of this enlightenment as experienced on the celestial body (resulting in "day"). This temporal frequency is implied by the broader context of "jour" (day) in the French text but is not explicitly attached to the sun's action itself.

The French "toute sa moitié qui a la nuit" (all its half that has the night) describes the unilluminated portion factually. The English translation "her other half that is benighted" uses "benighted" to explicitly and more vividly describe the state of being enveloped in darkness, adding a descriptive layer to the condition of the Moon's dark side not present in the simpler French phrasing.

The French "les Gens de la Lune" (the People of the Moon) is a somewhat general term. The English translation "the Inhabitants of the Moon" explicitly defines these "people" as residents or dwellers of the Moon. This specification of their relationship to the celestial body provides a clearer, more formal denotation than the original.

The French "son Cercle d'un mois" (its circle of a month) links the circle to a month's duration using a prepositional phrase. The English translation "her monthly Circle" rephrases this by using the adjective "monthly," which explicitly and more directly attributes the characteristic of a month's duration to the circle itself, making the connection more immediate.

The French "nous sommes en Decours pour elles" translates to "we are in a waning phase for them," describing the observed astronomical phenomenon of the Earth's decreasing illuminated portion as seen from the Moon. The English translation "and we are running from them" explicitly suggests a physical action or movement ("running from them") as the cause of this waning appearance. This rephrasing attempts to make the reason for the visual change more concrete and understandable for the reader by providing a dynamic, albeit metaphorical, explanation of the underlying celestial mechanics.

chunks.source_manual: <P027>Il n'en faut pas davantage, dit brusquement la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je sçauray tout le reste quand il me plaira, je n'ai qu'à y penser un moment, & qu'à promener la Lune sur son Cercle d'un mois. Je vois en gennral que dans la Lune ils ont un mois à rebours du nostre, & je gage que quand nous avons pleine Lune, c'est que toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune est tournée vers toute la moitié obscure de la Terre; qu'alors ils ne nous voyent point du tout, & qu'ils content Nouvelle Terre. Je ne voudrois pas qu'il me fust reproché de m'estre fait expliquer tout au long une chose si aisée. Mais les Eclipses comment vont-elles? Il ne tient qu'à vous de le deviner, répondis-je. Quand la Lune est Nouvelle, qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & que toute sa moitié obscure est tournée vers nous qui avons le jour, vous voyez bien que l'ombre de cette moitié obscure se jette vers nous. Si la Lune est justement sous le Soleil, cette ombre nous le cache, & en mesme temps noircit une partie de cette moitié lumineuse de la Terre qui estoit vûë par la moitié obscure de la Lune. Voila donc une Eclipse de Soleil pour nous pendant nostre jour, & une Eclipse de Terre pour la Lune pendant sa nuit. Lors que la Lune est pleine, la Terre est entre elle & le Soleil, & toute la moitié obscure de la Terre est tournée vers toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune. L'ombre de la Terre se jette donc vers la Lune; si elle tombe sur le Corps de la Lune, elle noircit cette moitié lumineuse que nous voyons, & à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour, elle luy dérobe le Soleil. Voila donc une Eclipse de Lune pour nous pendant nostre nuit, & une Eclipse de Soleil pour la Lune pendant le jour dont elle joüissoit. Ce qui fait qu'il n'arrive pas des Eclipses toutes les fois que la Lune est entre le Soleil & la Terre, ou la Terre entre le Soleil & la Lune, c'est que souvent ces trois Corps ne sont pas tres exactement rangez en ligne droite, & que par consequent celuy qui devroit faire l'Eclipse, jette son ombre un peu à costé de celuy qui en devroit estre couvert.</P027>
chunks.target_manual: <P022>'Tis enough, said the Marchioness briskly, I shall know all the rest when I please, I need but think on it a moment and walk the Moon about her monthly Circuit. I see in general that in the Moon they have a month reverse to ours, and I'le hold a Wager, that when 'tis full Moon with us, 'tis the inlighten'd half of the Moon turn'd towards the obscure part of the Earth, and 'tis then they see us not at all, and count it New Earth. I would not be reproch'd to have requir'd so minute an explication of a thing so easie. But pray how happen the Ecclipses? That, said I, belongs to you to judge. When 'tis New Moon, that she is between us and the Sun, and that all her obscure part is turn'd towards us in our day time; you see well that the Shadow of that obscure half is cast towards us. If the Moon be directly under the Sun, that Shadow hides him from us, and at the same time darkens all that luminous part of the Earth that was seen by the obscure part of the Moon. See there an Eclipse of the Sun for us in our day time, and an Eclipse of the Earth for the Moon in their night. When the Moon is full the Earth is between her and the Sun, and all the obscure half of the Earth is turn'd towards the inlighten'd half of the Moon; The Shadow of the Earth is then cast towards the Moon, and if it fall upon the body of the Moon it darkens that luminous half waich we saw, and hides the Sun from that luminous half in the Moon where it was day. See there an Eclipse of the Moon for us in our night, and an Eclipse of the Sun for the Moon in her day The reason why Eclipses do not happen every time that the Moon is between the Sun and the Earth, or the Earth between the Sun and the Moon, is because those three bodies are not always in a right line one to the other, and by consequence that Body that ought to make the Eclipse casts its Shadow a little on one side of that which should be obscured by it.</P022>
source_segments: une partie de cette moitié lumineuse de la Terre qui estoit vûë par la moitié obscure de la Lune
à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour
target_segments: all that luminous part of the Earth that was seen by the obscure part of the Moon
from that luminous half in the Moon where it was day
in a right line one to the other
that Body that ought to make the Eclipse
explanations: The French 'une partie de... qui estoit vûë' (a part of... which was seen) is translated as 'all that luminous part... that was seen'. The translator makes explicit that the entirety of the specific portion of the Earth visible from the Moon's dark side is affected by the shadow, whereas the French 'une partie' (a part) is less definitive about the extent, implying only 'some part' of what was visible.

The French phrase 'à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour' (from/to this luminous half which had the day) contextually refers to the Moon's luminous half. The English translation 'from that luminous half in the Moon where it was day' explicitly adds 'in the Moon', spelling out the location of 'that luminous half' for greater clarity, which was only implicitly understood from the surrounding context in the source text.

The French 'rangez en ligne droite' (arranged in a straight line) describes the alignment of celestial bodies. The English translation 'in a right line one to the other' makes the relational aspect of this alignment explicit by adding 'one to the other,' clarifying that the straight line is formed by the bodies relative to each other.

The French pronoun 'celuy' (that one/the one) is used to refer to the celestial body causing the eclipse. The English translation 'that Body that ought to make the Eclipse' makes this reference explicit by adding the noun 'Body,' thereby clarifying the previously implicit referent of the pronoun.

chunks.source_manual: <P028>Je suis fort étonnée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qu'il y ait si peu de mystere aux Eclipses, & que tout le monde n'en devine pas la cause. Ah! vraiment, répondis-je, il y a bien des Peuples qui de la maniere dont ils s'y prennent, ne la devineroient encore de long-temps. Dans toutes les Indes Orientales on croit que quand le Soleil & la Lune s'éclipsent, c'est qu'un certain Démon qui a les Griffes fort noires, les étend sur ces Astres dont il veut se saisir; & vous voyez pendant ces temps-là les Rivieres couvertes de Testes d'Indiens qui se sont mis dans l'eau jusqu'au cou, parce que c'est une situation tres-devote, selon eux, & tres-propre à obtenir du Soleil & de la Lune qu'ils se défendent bien contre le Démon. En Amerique, on estoit persuadé que le Soleil & la Lune estoient fâchéz quand ils s'éclipsoient, & Dieu sçait ce qu'on ne faisoit pas pour se raccommoder avec eux. Mais les Grecs qui estoient si raffinez, n'ont-ils pas creu long-temps que la Lune étoit ensorcelée, & que des Magiciennes la faisoient descendre du Ciel pour jeter sur les Herbes une certaine écume malfaisante? Mais nous, n'eûmes-nous pas belle peur il n'y guere plus de trente ans, à une certaine Eclipse de Soleil, qui arriva? Une infinité de Gens ne se tinrent-ils pas enfermez dans des caves, & <IIM>les Philosophes</IIM> <NCE></NCE> qui écrivirent pour nous rassurer,n'écrivirent-ils pas en vain?</P028>
chunks.target_manual: <P023>I am very much astonished, said the Marchioness, that there should be so little Mystery in Eclipses, and yet all the World so ignorant of their Causes. Ah! said I, there are enough in the World, that as they go to work, will never understand them. The East Indians believe that when the Sun and Moon are in Eclipse, it is a certain Demon that with his black Paws stretch'd out towards those Stars, endeavours to lay hold on them, and you shall see at that time the Rivers cover'd with Heads of Indians, who plunge themselves up to the neck in Water, as the most devout posture, in their opinion, to prevail with the Sun and Moon to protect them from the Paws of the Demon. The Americans think the Sun and Moon are angry with them when they are eclips'd, and God knows what they do not, to reconcile themselves with them. The Greeks, who were so refin'd, did they not believe a long while that the Moon was then inchanted, and that she was brought down from Heaven by Magicians, to cast a malignant froth upon Herbs? And we our selves were we not very fairly frighten'd at an Eclipse of the Sun not above thirty years since? When an infinite number of people shut themselves up in Caves, and the Philosophers that imploy'd their Pens to incourage us, writ in vain.</P023>
source_segments: ne la devineroient encore de long-temps
target_segments: from the Paws of the Demon
explanations: The French conjunction 'et' (and) simply links two clauses. The English translation uses 'and yet,' which explicitly signals an adversative or contrasting relationship between the 'little Mystery' in Eclipses and the widespread ignorance of their causes. This spells out a logical connection that was only implied by juxtaposition in the French.

The French 'n'en devine pas la cause' (doesn't guess the cause of them/it) describes a lack of success in figuring out the cause. The English 'so ignorant of their Causes' explicitly states the resulting condition or state (ignorance) and intensifies it with 'so.' This makes the implied consequence of not 'guessing the cause' explicit as a state of being.

The French phrase 'ne la devineroient encore de long-temps' (would still not guess it/the cause for a long time) suggests a prolonged, possibly indefinite, period before understanding would be achieved. The English 'will never understand them' makes this potential indefiniteness absolute and explicit by using 'never', thereby strengthening the assertion of difficulty.

The French text states the explicit desire of the Indians is for the Sun and Moon 'qu'ils se défendent bien' (to defend themselves well) against the Demon. The English translation rephrases this as the Sun and Moon 'to protect them' (i.e., the Indians). This explicitation rewrites the immediate object of the prayer, making the implied ultimate benefit for the worshippers (their own protection) the direct, explicit goal of the celestial bodies' action.

The French text earlier described the Demon as having 'les Griffes fort noires' (very black Claws/Paws). When later referring to the need for defense 'contre le Démon' (against the Demon), the English translation specifies 'from the Paws of the Demon.' This makes the specific means of the Demon's threat (his paws/claws) explicit by reintroducing it, drawing on information implied from the earlier description.

The French 'la Lune étoit ensorcelée' (the Moon was bewitched) describes a past belief held by the Greeks. The English translation 'the Moon was then inchanted' adds the adverb 'then.' This explicitly links the state of being 'inchanted' to that specific past time or those specific circumstances (e.g., during eclipses, or in that historical period of belief), a temporal specificity that was only implied by the context in the source text.

The French pronoun 'nous' (we), part of 'Mais nous', is translated as 'we our selves' in 'And we our selves.' The addition of the reflexive pronoun 'our selves' explicitly emphasizes the subject, highlighting that the speaker's own group or contemporaries are being referred to, in contrast to other groups previously discussed. This intensifies the self-referential aspect, which was only implicitly conveyed by the simple pronoun in French.

The French verb 'écrivirent' (wrote) is a general term for the act of writing. The English translation 'imploy'd their Pens' expands this by explicitly mentioning the instrument of writing ('Pens'). This makes the physical act of writing more vivid and formal, adding a layer of detail about the means of action that was implicit in the French verb.

chunks.source_manual: <P029>En verité, reprit-elle, tout cela est trop honteux pour les hommes, il devroit y avoir un Arrest du Genre humain qui défendît qu'on parlast jamais d'Eclipse, de peur que l'on ne conserve la memoyre des sotises qui ont esté faites ou dites sur ce Chapitre-là. Il faudrait donc, repliquay-je, que le mesme Arrest abolist la memoire de toutes choses, & défendist qu'on parlast jamais de rien, car je ne sçache rien au monde qui ne soit le monument de quelque sotise des hommes.</P029>
chunks.target_manual: <P024>Truly, says she, all this is very much to the shame of Men; there ought to be a general Edict prohibiting, That none should ever speak of an Eclipse, for fear of preserving the memory of those Follies that have been said and done upon that account. Then 'twill be likewise necessary, said I, by the same Edict to abolish the memory of all things, and forbid ever speaking of any thing; for I know nothing in the World that is not a monument of the Folly of mankind.</P024>
explanations: The French 'un Arrest du Genre humain' (a decree/judgment of humankind) implies a decree of universal scope, applicable to all people. The translator makes this implicit universality explicit by adding the adjective 'general' to 'Edict,' thereby spelling out the wide-ranging nature of such a decree which was otherwise conveyed by the phrase 'du Genre humain' (of humankind).

The French 'Il faudrait donc' uses 'donc' (therefore/then) to indicate a logical continuation or consequence. The translator adds 'likewise,' which explicitly spells out the parallel or additive nature of the philosopher's argument (i.e., 'in the same way' or 'also'), making a specific type of inferential link more overt than the more general 'donc' would on its own.

The French 'quelque sotise des hommes' (literally 'some folly of men' or 'a folly of men') refers to an indefinite instance or type of foolishness.
