The French "nous le verrions tomber mort sur la Terre" (we would see him fall dead on the Earth) implies observation by "nous" (we). The English translation "we should see him tumble down dead before us" adds "before us," explicitly stating the spatial perspective of the observers in relation to the event. This clarifies that the event would happen in their direct presence or view, a detail that was only implied in the source text.

chunks.source_manual: <P043>Oh, que j'aurois d'envie, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <UP></UP> qu'il arrivast quelque grand naufrage <UP></UP> qui répandist icy bon nombre de ces Gens-là, dont nous irions considerer à nostre aise les figures extraordinaires! Mais,repliquay-je, s'ils estoient assez habiles pour naviger sur la surface exterieure de nostre Air, & que de là par la curiosité de nous voir, ils nous peschassent comme des Poissons, cela vous plairoit-il? Pourquoy non, répondit-elle en riant? Pour moy, je me mettrois de mon propre mouvement dans leurs Filets, seulement pour avoir le plaisir de voir ceux qui m'auroient peschée.</P043>
chunks.target_manual: <P039>Oh! cry'd the Marchioness, how I should rejoyce at a Shipwrack that would lay before us a good number of those people. We might then consider those extraordinary Figures at our leisure. But, said I, if they were expert enough to sail upon the exteriour surface of our Air, and should lay Nets and Hooks for us as we do for Fishes, would that please you? Why not, says she, laughing? for my part I would willingly put my self into their Nets, only to have the satisfaction of seeing them that caught me.</P039>
source_segments: qui répandist icy bon nombre de ces Gens-là
ils nous peschassent comme des Poissons
target_segments: that would lay before us a good number of those people
should lay Nets and Hooks for us as we do for Fishes
explanations: The French "qui répandist icy bon nombre de ces Gens-là" (that would spread here a good number of those people) describes the action of the shipwreck scattering people in a location. The English translation "that would lay before us a good number of those people" makes explicit the implied consequence of this action for the observers – that the people would be presented *to them* for viewing. This rephrasing incorporates the observer's perspective and the purpose of observation (implied by the following clause in the source text, "dont nous irions considerer") directly into the description of the shipwreck's effect, which is less direct in the source.

The French "ils nous peschassent comme des Poissons" (they would fish us like Fish) uses a general verb "peschassent" (would fish) for the act of fishing. The English translation "should lay Nets and Hooks for us as we do for Fishes" expands this by explicitly stating the *method* of fishing by adding "Nets and Hooks," which are specific instruments not mentioned in the source text. This addition clarifies how the hypothetical fishing might occur and alters the original rhetorical style by having the philosopher introduce these specifics, whereas in the French text, the Marquise later independently refers to "Filets" (Nets).

chunks.source_manual: <P044>Songez, repliquay-je, que vous n'arriveriez que bien malade au haut de nostre Air, il n'est pas respirable pour nous dans toute son étenduë, il s'en faut bien, il ne l'est déjà presque plus au haut de certaines <UP></UP> Montagnes, & je m'étonne bien que ceux qui ont la folie de croire que des Genies corporels habitent l'air le plus pur, ne disent aussi que ce qui fait que ces Genies ne nous rendent que des visites & tres-rares & tres-courtes, c'est qu'il y en a peu d'entre eux qui sçachent plonger, & que ceux-la mesme ne peuvent faire jusqu'au fond de cet air épais où nous sommes, que des plongeons de tres-peu de durée <UP></UP>. Voila donc bien des barrieres naturelles qui nous défendent la sortie de nostre Monde, & l'entrée de celuy de la Lune. Tâchons du moins pour nostre consolation à deviner ce que nous pourrons de ce Monde-là. Je croy, par exemple, qu'il faut qu'on y voye le Ciel, le Soleil, & les Astres d'une autre couleur que nous ne les voyons. Tous ces objets ne nous paroissent qu'au travers d'une espece de Lunette naturelle qui nous les change. Cette Lunette, c'est nostre Air, mêlé comme il est de vapeurs & d'exhalaisons, & qui ne s'étend pas bien haut. Quelques Modernes pretendent que de luy-mesme il est bleu aussi bien que l'eau de la Mer, & que cette couleur ne paroist dans l'un & dans l'autre qu'à une grande profondeur. Le Ciel, disent-ils, où sont attachées les Etoiles Fixes, n'a de luy-mesme aucune lumiere, & par consequent il devroit paroistre noir; mais on le voit au travers de l'Air, qui est bleu, & il paroist bleu. Si cela est, les rayons du Soleil & des Etoiles ne peuvent passer au travers de l'Air sans se teindre un peu de sa couleur, & prendre autant de celle qui leur est naturelle. Mais quand mesme l'Air ne seroit pas coloré de luy-mesme, il est certain qu'au travers d'un gros broüillard, la lumiere d'un flambeau qu'on voit un peu de loin paroist toute rougeâtre, quoy que ce ne soit pas sa vraye couleur, & nostre Air n'est non plus qu'un gros broüillard, qui nous doit alterer la vraye couleur & du Ciel, & du Soleil, & des Etoiles. Il n'appartiendroit qu'à la matiere celeste de nous apporter la lumiere & les couleurs dans toute leur pureté <UP></UP>, & telles qu'elles sont. Ainsi, puis que l'Air de la Lune est d'une autre nature que nostre Air, ou il est teint en luy-mesme d'une autre couleur, ou du moins c'est un autre broüillard qui cause une autre alteration aux couleurs des Corps celestes. Enfin, à l'égard des Gens de la Lune, cette Lunette au travers de laquelle on voit tout, est changée.</P044>
chunks.target_manual: <P040>But bethink your self, said I, that you may be ill when you arrive at the top of our Air, we cannot breath in all its extent, it must needs be so, for we cannot breath upon the tops of some Mountains; and I much wonder that those that have the folly to believe that certain corporeal Genii inhabit the purest Air, do not likewise say, that the reason why those Genii come so seldom to us, and make such short Visits, is because few among them are expert in Diving, and those that are, cannot dive to the bottom of our thick Air, to stay any long time. So that here you see three natural Barricades to prevent our going out of our World or entring that of the Moon. Yet let us try for our satisfaction, to guess what we can of that World. I believe, for example, that we might see the Heaven, Sun and Stars of another colour than we see them here. We behold all those Objects here through a kind of natural Perspective which shews them otherwise than they are, that Perspective is our Air, mixt as it is with Vapours and Exhalations, which extend not very high. Some Moderns pretend that in it self it is of a blue colour, as well as the Sea, and that that colour appears not either in the one or the other, but in a great depth. The Heaven of the fixed Stars, say they, has of it self no light, and consequently it would appear black; but we see it through the Air which is blue, and represents it blue to us. If that be so, the Rays of the Sun and Stars cannot pass through the Air. without receiving a little tincture of that colour, and losing some of their own; but were it so that the Air had no colour of its own, it is certain that the Light of a Flambeau seen through a thick mist appears red, though it be not its natural colour, and our Air is no more than a thick mist that changes the colour of the Heaven, Sun and Stars. So that the Air of the Moon being of another nature than our Air, or having in it self a tincture of another colour, or at least being another mist that causes that change of colour in the celestial bodies, the Perspective through which all is seen, in respect of the people of the Moon is changed.</P040>
source_segments: une autre alteration aux couleurs des Corps celestes
target_segments: that change of colour in the celestial bodies
explanations: The French phrase "il s'en faut bien," an idiomatic intensifier meaning "far from it" or "not by a long shot," emphasizes the degree of the air's unbreathability as stated in the preceding clause ("il n'est pas respirable pour nous dans toute son étenduë"). The English translation "it must needs be so" (meaning "it is necessarily the case" or "it inevitably follows") makes explicit a sense of logical necessity or inevitability for this unbreathability. This shifts the emphasis from the degree of the quality to the certainty of the statement based on an implied underlying necessity, thus adding a layer of explicit justification not directly formulated in the French intensifier.

The French "bien des barrieres naturelles" translates to "many natural barriers" or "a good number of natural barriers," indicating an unspecified quantity. The translator has made this explicit by specifying "three natural Barricades." This quantification to "three" is an addition not present in the source text and represents the translator's deliberate act of enumerating previously implied or generally referenced obstacles, thereby transforming general information into explicit, specific information.

The French "une autre alteration aux couleurs des Corps celestes" means "another alteration" or "a different alteration" to the colors of celestial bodies. This phrasing leaves some ambiguity as to whether this alteration is simply a new instance of the same kind of phenomenon (color change due to atmosphere) or potentially a qualitatively different type of alteration. The English translation "that change of colour in the celestial bodies" uses the demonstrative pronoun "that" to anaphorically link this alteration specifically to the general mechanism of atmospheric color distortion that has been the subject of the preceding discussion. This explicitly spells out the connection, clarifying that the alteration caused by the Moon's air is understood as another instance of the *same type* of previously discussed phenomenon, rather than just 'another' alteration which might be of an undefined nature.

chunks.source_manual: <P045>Cela me fait préférer nostre sejour à celuy de la Lune, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne saurois croire que l'assortiment des couleurs celestes y soit aussi beau qu'il l'est icy. Mettons, si vous voulez, un Ciel rouge, & des Etoiles vertes, l'effet n'est pas si agreable que des Etoiles couleur d'or sur du bleu. On diroit à vous entendre, <UP></UP>, repris-je, que vous assortiriez un habit, ou un meuble; mais, croyez-moy, la Nature a bien de l'esprit; laissez-luy le soin d'inventer un assortiment de couleurs pour la Lune, & je vous garantis qu'il sera bien entendu. Elle n'aura pas manqué de varier le Spectacle de l'Univers à chaque point de veüe diferent <UP></UP>, & de le varier d'une maniere toûjours agreable.</P045>
chunks.target_manual: <P041>That, says the Marchioness, makes me prefer our abode before that of the Moon; sor I cannot believe that the Appearance of the celestial colours is so pleasant there as here. Let us suppose a red Sky and green Stars, they will not agree so well together as Stars of a pure Gold-colour upon blue. Any that heard you, says I, would think you were dressing up a Suit of Clothes, or furnishing a Room; but believe me, Nature understands well enough what she does, leave it to her to invent a mixture of Colours for the Moon, and I'le undertake it shall be well approved. She fail'd not to work variety of Prospects in the Universe at every turn of the eye, and yet the variety is still pleasing.</P041>
source_segments: que vous assortiriez un habit, ou un meuble
la Nature a bien de l'esprit
je vous garantis qu'il sera bien entendu.
target_segments: they will not agree so well together
you were dressing up a Suit of Clothes, or furnishing a Room
Nature understands well enough what she does
I'le undertake it shall be well approved.
explanations: The French "l'effet" (the effect) refers to the resulting visual impact of the color combination. The translation "they [the colors] will not agree so well together" makes explicit the *reason* for the unpleasant effect by specifying the disharmony between the colors themselves, a cause-and-effect relationship that was only implied by "l'effet" in the context of an "assortiment de couleurs" (assortment of colors).

The French "assortiriez un habit" (you would match/coordinate an outfit) and "un meuble" (a piece of furniture/furnishings) refers to the act of selecting items that go well together. The English "dressing up a Suit of Clothes, or furnishing a Room" expands these somewhat condensed expressions by explicitly naming the broader, more elaborate activities (preparing an entire outfit, outfitting an entire room) in which such matching or coordination takes place.

The French "la Nature a bien de l'esprit" conveys that Nature is witty, intelligent, or clever. The translation "Nature understands well enough what she does" makes explicit a key implication of Nature possessing "esprit" in this context: her intelligence results in competence and a purposeful understanding of her own creative actions, rather than just abstract cleverness.

The French "il sera bien entendu," referring to Nature's "assortiment de couleurs," signifies that it will be well-conceived, skillfully arranged, or in good taste. The English "it shall be well approved." makes explicit the anticipated positive human or observer reception (approval) that such a well-designed and tasteful arrangement would naturally elicit, a consequence implied by its inherent quality.

chunks.source_manual: <P046>Je reconnois son adresse, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle s'est épargné la peine de changer les objets pour chaque point de veüe, elle n'a changé que les Lunettes, & elle a l'honneur de cette grande diversité, sans en avoir fait la dépense. Avec un air bleu, elle nous donne un Ciel bleu, & peut-estre avec un Air rouge, elle donne un Ciel rouge aux Habitans de la Lune, c'est pourtant toûjours le mesme Ciel. Il me paroist qu'elle nous a mis aussi dans l'imagination certaines Lunettes, au travers desquelles on voit tout, & qui changent fort les objets à l'égard de chaque homme. Alexandre voyoit la Terre comme une belle place bien propre à y établir un grand Empire. Celadon ne la voyoit que comme <RW>le sejour d'Astrée</RW>. Un Philosophe la voit comme une grosse Planete qui va par les Cieux, toute couverte de fous. Je ne croy pas que le Spectacle change plus de la Terre à la Lune, qu'il fait icy d'imagination à imagination.</P046>
chunks.target_manual: <P042>I know her Artifice, said the Marchioness, she spar'd her self the pains of making variety of Objects, and only chang'd the Perspectives; so that she has the Honour of that great Diversity without being at the Expence. With a blue Air she gives us a blue Sky, and possibly with a red Air she gives the Inhabitants of the Moon a red Sky, but still 'tis the same Sky. In my opinion she has likewise plac'd in our imagination certain Perspectives, through which we see all, and which change the Objects in respect of every particular man. Alexander saw the Earth a fair place fit for the Seat of a great Empire; Celadon sees it only as the abode of his Astrea, and a Philosopher sees it only as a great Planet moving in the Heavens and throng'd with Fools. I do not believe that the prospect is more different between the Earth and the Moon, than between Imagination and Imagination.</P042>
source_segments: une belle place bien propre à y établir un grand Empire
target_segments: a fair place fit for the Seat of a great Empire
explanations: The French "changer les objets" (to change the objects) implies that Nature would have to alter or create different objects for different viewpoints. The English translation "making variety of Objects" makes this explicit by specifying the act of creation ("making") and the resulting diversity ("variety"), which were only implied in the original's general term "changer."

The French "les Lunettes," literally "the eyeglasses" or "spectacles," is used metaphorically by Fontenelle to refer to the means by which perception is shaped. The translation to "the Perspectives" makes this metaphorical meaning explicit, clarifying that it refers to conceptual viewpoints or ways of seeing rather than literal optical devices, thereby ensuring the abstract meaning is conveyed.

The French "certaines Lunettes" (certain eyeglasses/spectacles), described in the context of being placed "in our imagination," is used metaphorically for individual, internal modes of perception. The translation "certain Perspectives" makes this metaphorical meaning explicit by using a term that directly signifies conceptual viewpoints, thus clarifying the abstract nature of these imagined 'lenses'.

The French phrase "une belle place bien propre à y établir un grand Empire" means "a fine place very suitable for establishing a great empire there." The English translation "a fair place fit for the Seat of a great Empire" explicitates an implied characteristic by adding "the Seat of," which specifies the place's suitability as a central hub of power for the empire, a specific function not explicitly stated by the more general "établir" (to establish).

The French "le sejour d'Astrée" (the abode/sojourn of Astrea) refers to Celadon's view of Earth in relation to Astrée, characters from Honoré d'Urfé's contemporary romance "L'Astrée." The English translation "the abode of his Astrea" adds the possessive pronoun "his," thereby making Celadon's personal, amorous connection to Astrée explicit. This relationship, assumed as shared cultural knowledge for French readers, is spelled out for the English audience.

The French "toute couverte de fous" translates to "all covered with fools." The English translation "throng'd with Fools" explicitates the nature of this 'covering' by using "throng'd," which means densely crowded or packed. This adds a specific clarifying detail about the multitude and density of fools, intensifying the image in a way that was only implied by the more general "couverte de" (covered with).

chunks.source_manual: <P047>Le changement de Spectacle est plus surprenant dans nos imaginations, repliquay-je, car ce ne sont que les mesmes objets qu'on voit si diferemment; du moins dans la Lune on peut voir d'autres objets, ou ne pas voir quelques-uns de ceux qu'on voit icy. Peut-estre ne connoissent-ils point en ce Pays-là l'Aurore, ny les Crepuscules, avant que le Soleil se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. L 'Air qui nous environne, & qui est élevé au dessus de nous, reçoit des rayons qui ne pourroient pas tomber sur la Terre, & parce qu'il est fort grossier, il en arreste une partie, & nous les renvoye, quoy qu'ils ne nous fussent pas naturellement destinez. Ainsi l'Aurore & les Crepuscules sont une grace que la Nature nous fait; c'est une lumiere que régulierement nous ne devrions point avoir, & qu'elle nous donne par dessus ce qui nous est dû. Mais dans la Lune, où apparemment l'Air est plus pur, il pourroit bien n'estre pas si propre à renvoyer en bas les rayons qu'il reçoit du Soleil avant qu'il se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. Vous n'avez donc cette lumiere de faveur <NCP></NCP>, qui en se fortifiant peu à peu, vous prepare agreablement à l'arrivée du Soleil, ou qui en s'affoiblissant comme de nuance en nuance, vous accoûtume à sa perte. Vous estes dans des tenebres profondes <NCP></NCP>, & tout d'un coup il semble qu'on tire un rideau, voila vos yeux frapez de tout l'éclat qui est dans le Soleil; vous estes dans une lumiere vive & éclatante, & tout d'un coup vous voila tombés dans des tenebres profondes. Le jour & la nuit ne sont point liez par un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre. L'Arc-en-ciel est encore une chose qui manque aux Gens de la Lune, car si l'Aurore est un effet de la grossiereté de l'air & des vapeurs, l'Arc-en-ciel se forme dans les nuages d'où tombent les pluyes, & nous devons les plus belles choses du monde à celles qui le sont le moins. Puis <UP></UP> qu'il n'y a autour de la Lune ny vapeurs assez grossieres, ny nuages pluvieux, adieu l'Arc-en-ciel avec l'Aurore, & à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là? Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!</P047> <P048>Je n'aurois pas grand regret à ces comparaisons là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, & je trouve qu'on est assez bien recompensé dans la Lune <UP></UP>, de n'avoir ny Aurore ny Arc-en- ciel, car on ne doit avoir par la mesme raison ny Foudres ny Tonnerres, puisque ce sont aussi des choses qui se forment dans les nüages. On a de beaux jours toûjours serains pendant lesquels on ne perd point le Soleil de veuë <NCE></NCE>. On n'a point de nuits où toutes les Etoiles ne se montrent <UP></UP>; on ne connoist ny les orages ny les tempestes, ny tout ce qui paroist estre un effet de la colere du Ciel, trouvez-vous qu'on soit tant à plaindre? Vous me faites voir la Lune comme un séjour enchanté, répondis-je; cependant je ne sçay s'il est si délicieux d'avoir toûjours sur la teste, un Soleil ardent dont aucun nüage ne modere la chaleur. Peut-estre aussi est-ce à cause de cela que la Nature a creusé dans la Lune des especes de Puits, qui sont assez grands pour estre apperceus par nos Lunettes; car ce ne sont point des Vallées qui soient entre des Montagnes, ce sont des creux que l'on voit au milieu de certains lieux plats. Que sçait-on si les Habitans de la Lune, incommodez par l'ardeur perpetuelle du Soleil, ne se refugient point dans ces grands Puits? Ils n'habitent peut-estre point ailleurs, c'est-là qu'ils bâtissent leurs Villes. Nous voyons icy que la Rome soûterraine estoit presque aussi grande que la Rome qui estoit sur Terre. Il ne faudroit qu'oster celle-cy, le reste seroit une Ville à la maniere de la Lune. Tout un Peuple est dans un Puits, & d'un Puits à l'autre il y a des chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples. Vous vous mocquez de cette vision, j'y consens de tout mon cœr; cependant, à vous parler tres serieusement, vous pourriez vous tromper plûtost que moy. Vous croyez que les Gens de la Lune doivent habiter sur la surface de leur Planete, parce que nous habitons sur la surface de la nostre: c'est tout le contraire, puisque nous habitons sur la surface de nostre Planete, ils pourroient bien n'habiter pas sur la surface de la leur. D'icy là il faut que toutes choses soient bien differentes. <UP></UP></P048>
chunks.target_manual: <P043>The change of the Prospect, says I, is more surprizing in our Imaginations, for they are but the same Objects which we see differently; but in the Moon other Objects are to be seen, or none of those that are seen here, possibly in that Country they know not Aurora nor the Twilight, before the Sun rises and after he sets; the Air that surrounds us and is rais'd above us, receives Rays which cannot fall upon the Earth, and being very thick, it stops some of them & reflects them upon us, tho they were not naturally design'd for us. So that Aurora and the Twilight is a particular favour of Nature, a Light which regularly we ought not to have, and which she gives us over and above our due. But it may not be so proper in •he???, where the Air is apparently more pure to beat down the Rays of the Sun before he rises or after he is set. You have not there that favourable Light, which growing upon you by degrees prepares you easily for the Arrival of the Sun, and which by the same degrees declining prepares you for his absence. You are in a profound Darkness, and all or a suddain, as though a Curtain were drawn, you find your eyes struck with the Light of the Sun; again you are in a bright and vigorous Light, and all on a suddain you drop into a profound Darkness, the day and night are not joined with a middle light that participates both of the one and the other. The Rainbow is likewise a thing wanting to the people of the Moon; for as the Aurora is an effect of the grossness of the Air and Vapours; so the Rainbow is form'd in Clouds from whence falls the Rain, so that we are oblig'd for the most beautiful thing in the World, to that which is the least so. Since then there are no gross Vapours about the Moon, nor rainy Clouds, farewell Rainbow, farewel Aurora, to what now must we resemble the fair ones of that Country? What a fource of comparisons is there lost! I am not much concern'd, said the Marchioness, for those comparisons, and I find recompence enough in the Moon for the want of the Rainbow and Aurora; for by the same reason there is neither Thunder nor Lightning, both which are form'd in the Clouds, the days are still fair and serene, and the Sun in the day time never out of sight, the Stars are visible all night, no Storm or Tempest is ever known, nor any thing that is an effect of an angry Heaven. What reason do you find then of Complaint? You represent the Moon to me, said I, as an inchanted abode, but in the mean time I know not whether it be so pleasant to have daily a scorching Sun over a mans head, and not a Cloud to moderate the Heat, it may be likewise 'tis therefore Nature has made certain kind of Pits in the Moon big enough to be discern'd by our Glasses; for they are not mountains? but hollow places which appear in the midst of certain plains. How do we know but the Inhabitants of the Moon shelter themselves there from the extremity of the Heat? possibly they live no where else but there, and 'tis there they build their Towns. We see here that the Subterranean Rome was almost as big as Rome above the Earth; there needs no more than to take away this, the rest will be a Town like those in the Moon; a whole Populace is together in one of those Cavities, and from one to another they communicate by subterraneous ways. You laugh now at this Vision, and I heartily agree you should, but in the mean time to tell you seriously, you may be deceived sooner than I. You think the people of the Moon ought to inhabit upon the surface of their Planet as we do upon ours. 'Tis quite contrary; though we live upon the surface of our Planet, they may not at all live upon the surface of theirs, all things ought to be very different here from what they are there.</P043>

explanations: The French "sa perte" (its/his loss, referring to the Sun) is made more explicit in the target "his absence." While "perte" can mean disappearance, "absence" specifically clarifies the temporary nature of the Sun's state, rather than a more general or permanent "loss," thus spelling out an implication about the Sun's cycle.

The French "un milieu" (a middle/medium), in the context of the transition between day and night ("Le jour & la nuit ne sont point liez par un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre"), implicitly refers to a state of intermediate light. The translator makes this explicit by rendering the concept as "a middle light", directly specifying the nature of this transitional "milieu".

The French phrase "on ne perd point le Soleil de veuë" (one does not lose sight of the Sun) appears in the context of "jours" (days). The translation adds "in the day time" to the corresponding English phrase "the Sun [...] never out of sight", making explicit the implied temporal specificity (daylight hours) of when the Sun is visible.

The French "sur la teste" (on the head/overhead) is generalized. The translation "over a mans head" makes the implicit human-centric perspective explicit by specifying "a mans", clarifying for whom the sun is overhead in a generic sense.

The French "l'ardeur perpetuelle du Soleil" (the perpetual ardour/heat of the Sun) is translated as "the extremity of the Heat". "Ardeur" conveys intensity, but "extremity" explicitly spells out the severe degree of the heat, making an implied aspect of "ardeur" (its potent or extreme nature) more direct.

The French "chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples" (subterranean paths for the communication of the Peoples) describes infrastructure with an intended purpose. The translation "they communicate by subterraneous ways" makes the implied action of people actually using these paths to communicate explicit, shifting from describing the potential function of the paths to the realized activity.

The French "j'y consens de tout mon cœr" (I consent to it with all my heart) uses the pronoun "y" (to it), implicitly referring to the Marquise's mockery mentioned just before ("Vous vous mocquez de cette vision"). The translation "I heartily agree you should" makes this reference explicit by incorporating the implied object and nature of the consent (that the Marquise should mock/laugh), changing "consent" to the more conversationally specific "agree you should."

The French "D'icy là" (From here to there) is a concise expression implying a comparison between conditions on Earth ("icy" - here) and the Moon ("là" - there). The translation "here from what they are there" explicitly spells out the comparative nature and clarifies the second element of the comparison ("what they are there"), which was only gestured towards by "là" in the source, thus expanding the condensed phrase.

chunks.source_manual: <P049>Il n'importe, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne puis me resoudre à laisser vivre les Habitans de la Lune dans une obscurité perpetuelle. Vous y auriez encore plus de peine, répris-je, si vous sçaviez qu'un grand Philosophe de l'Antiquité a fait de la Lune le séjour des Ames qui ont merité icy d'estre bien-heureuses. Toute leur felicité consiste en ce qu'elles y entendent l'Harmonie que les Corps Celestes font par leurs mouvemens; mais comme il pretend que quand la Lune tombe dans l'ombre de la Terre, elles ne peuvent plus entendre cette Harmonie <UP></UP>; alors, dit-il, ces Ames crient comme des desesperées, & la Lune se haste le plus qu'elle peut de les tirer d'un endroit si facheux. Nous devrions donc, repliqua-t-elle, voir arriver icy les Bienheureux de la Lune, car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi, & dans ces deux Planetes on croit avoir assez pourveu à la felicité des Ames, de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde. Serieusement, répris-je, ce ne seroit pas un plaisir mediocre de voir plusieurs Mondes differens. Ce Voyage me réjoüit quelquefois beaucoup à ne le faire qu'en imagination, & que seroit-ce, si on le faisoit en effet? Cela vaudroit bien mieux que d'aller d'icy au Japon, c'est à dire de ramper avec beaucoup de peine d'un point de la Terre sur un autre, pour ne voir que des hommes. Eh bien, dit-elle, faisons le Voyage des Planetes, comme nous pourrons; qui nous en empesche? Allons nous placer dans tous ces differens points de veuê, & de là considerons l'Univers. N'avons-nous plus rien à voir dans la Lune? Je croy que non, répondis-je, du moins je vous y ay fait voir tout ce qui estoit de ma connoissance. Au sortir de la Lune en tirant vers le Soleil, on trouve Venus. Sur Vénus je reprens le <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE>. Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, & autour du Soleil <UP>comme la Lune</UP>, on découvre avec les <NCP><IIM>Lunettes d'approche</IIM></NCP>, que Venus aussi-bien que la Lune, est tantost en Croissant, tantost en Décours, tantost pleine selon les diverses situations où elle est à l'égard de la Terre. La Lune selon toutes les apparences est habitée, pourquoy Vénus ne le sera-t-elle pas aussi? Mais, interrompit-elle, en disant toûjours Pourquoy non, vous m'allez mettre des Habitans dans toutes les Planetes? N'en doutez pas, répliquay-je, ce Pourquoy a une vertu qui suffira pour peupler tout. Nous voyons que toutes les Planetes sont de la mesme nature, toutes des Corps <IIM>opaques</IIM> qui ne reçoivent de la lumiere que du Soleil, qui se la renvoyent les uns aux autres, & qui n'ont que les mesmes mouvemens, jusque là tout est égal. Cependant il faudroit concevoir que ces grands Corps auroient esté faits pour n'estre point habitez, que ce seroit là leur condition naturelle, & qu'il y auroit une exception justement en faveur de la Terre toute seule. Qui voudra le croire, le croye; pour moy, je ne m'y puis pas resoudre? Je vous trouve, dit-elle, bien affermy dans vôtre opinion depuis quelques instans. <UP></UP> Je viens de voir le moment que la Lune seroit deserte, & que vous ne vous en souciïez pas beaucoup, & presentement si on osoit vous dire que toutes les Planetes ne sont pas aussi habitées que la Terre, je voy bien que vous vous mettriez en colere. Il est vray, répondis-je, que dans le moment où vous venez de me surprendre, si vous m'eussiez contredit sur les Habitans des Planetes, non seulement je vous les aurois soutenus, mais je crois que je vous aurois dit comment ils estoient tous faits. Il y a des momens pour croire, & je ne les ay jamais si bien crûs que dans celuy là; mais presentement que je suis un peu plus de sens froid, je ne laisse pas de trouver qu'il seroit bien étrange que la Terre fust aussi habitée qu'elle l'est, & que les autres Planetes ne le fussent point du tout; car ne croyez pas que nous voyions tout ce qui habite la Terre; il y a autant d'especes d'Animaux invisibles que de visibles. Nous voyons depuis l'Elephant jusqu'au <UP></UP> Ciron; là finit nostre veuë; mais au Ciron commence une multitude infinie d'Animaux, dont il est l'Elephant, & que la simple veuë ne sçauroit appercevoir. On a vu avec des <RW>Lunettes</RW> beaucoup de Liqueurs toutes remplis de petits Animaux que l'on n'auroit jamais soupçonnez d'y estre, & il y a quelque apparence que le goût qu'elles font sentir, sont les piqueures que ces petits Animaux font à la langue & au palais. Meslez de certaines choses dans quelques-unes de ces Liqueurs, ou exposez-les au Soleil, ou laissez-les se corrompre, voilà aussi-tost de nouvelles especes de petits Animaux.</P049>
chunks.target_manual: <P044>'Tis no matter, said the Marchioness, I cannot resolve to let the Inhabitants of the Moon live in perpetual obscurity. But you would be yet more concern'd, said I, if you knew that an ancient and great Philosopher has made the Moon the abode of blessed Souls. All their Happiness consists in hearing there the Harmony which the celestial bodies make in their motions; but he pretends that when the Moon falls in the Shadow of the Earth, they cannot then hear that Harmony, and 'tis then those poor Souls cry out desperately, and the Moon makes what haste she can to deliver them out of that trouble. We may then, says she, expect to see the happy Souls of the Moon here; for 'tis certain they are sent likewise to us, as to their Paradice, and between those two Planets, the Moon and Earth, 'tis thought sufficient provision is made for the happiness of Souls by mutually transporting them into each others World. Seriously, said I, it would be no small pleasure to see many different Worlds; 'tis a pleasure to make the Voyage in imagination only, 'twould surely be much more so in effect. It would be much better than to go from hence to Iapan, that is to say, than to take the pains to run from one corner of the Earth to another, and all to see nothing else but men. Well, says she, let us take a Voyage about the Planets, as well as we can. What should hinder us? Let us place our selves in all those different points of sight, and from thence consider the World. Have we no more to see in the Moon? I think not, said I, at least I have shewn you all that is within my knowledge. Leaving the Moon and bending our Course toward the Sun, we meet Venus, and in Venus I return again to Saint Denis. Venus turns about her self and about the Sun, as the Moon doth; and it is found by the Telescope that Venus, as well as the Moon, has her Increases and Decreases, and is full, according to her diverse scituation in respect of the Earth.</P044> <P045>The Moon according to all appearance is inhabited, why not Venus as well? But, says she, in saying still, Why not, you seem to design Inhabitants for all the Planets. Doubt it not, said I, that Why has a vertue in it sufficient to people all. We see that the Planets are all of the same nature, all opaque bodies that receive no Light but the Suns, which they reflect from one to another, & have all the same motions; thus far all are equal. In the mean time we must conceive that those great bodies are made to be uninhabited, that that's their natural Condition, and that the Earth only was exempted from it. He that will believe so, let him believe; for my part I cannot concur with him. I find, says she, that you are very very much confirm'd in your opinion within this little while; it is not long since the Moon was made a Desert, and you were not much concern'd at it, and now should any one venture to tell you that all the Planets are not inhabited as the Earth is, I find you would be angry. 'Tis true, said I, at that moment when you surpriz'd me, had you contradicted me about the Inhabitants of the Planets, I should not only have maintain'd them against you, but I believe I should have told you how they are all made. There are moments for believing, and I never believ'd it so much as at that moment. But now in a cooler Judgment, I think it would be very strange that the Earth should be so well inhabited as it is, and the other Planets not at all; for I would not have you think that we see all that inhabits the Earth, there are as many species of Animals invisible as visible. We see down from the Elephant to <UP>the Mite and</UP> the Cicon, there our sight terminates; but from <UP>the Mite and</UP> the Cicon begins an infinite multitude of Animals to which the Mite is an Elephant, and which are not discernable to our plain sight. Glasses have discover'd to us many Liquors full of little Animals, which we should never have suspected to have been there; and 'tis not improbable that the Tast and Relish of those Liquors proceeds from the biting or sting of those Animals upon the tongue and palate. Do but mix some things with some of those Liquors, or expose them to the Sun, or let them corrupt, and you shall presently see a new species of little Animals.</P045>

explanations: The French "Ames" (Souls), described in context as "desesperées" (desperate ones), implies their pitiable state. The translation "poor Souls" makes this sympathy explicit by adding the adjective "poor", directly attributing this quality to the souls.

The French "on nous les envoye aussi" (they are sent to us also) is expanded in the translation with the phrase "as to their Paradice." This addition makes explicit an interpretation that Earth serves as a form of paradise for these transported souls, a specific concept not directly stated in the source.

The translator makes explicit which "ces deux Planetes" (these two Planets) are being referred to by adding their names, "the Moon and Earth." This information was implicitly understood from the preceding context in the source text but is spelled out in the translation for clarity.

The French "de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde." (having transported them into another World.) is made more specific by the addition of "mutually" and "each others." This explicitation clarifies the reciprocal nature of the soul transport between the worlds, a nuance that was less directly stated in the source.

The general French phrase "d'un point de la Terre sur un autre" (from one point of the Earth to another) is translated as "from one corner of the Earth to another." The use of "corner" instead of a more direct equivalent of "point" makes the imagery more specific and vivid, explicitly suggesting distant or perhaps less significant parts of the Earth.

The French "Lunettes d'approche" (literally "approach glasses" or spyglasses), a somewhat general term for magnifying optical instruments of the era, is translated as "Telescope." This makes the type of instrument more explicit by using the specific term for the scientific apparatus used for astronomical observation, aligning with the scientific context and potentially clarifying for an English readership familiar with the term.

The French "vous m'allez mettre des Habitans dans toutes les Planetes?" (you are going to put/establish Inhabitants for me in all the Planets?) is rendered as "you seem to design Inhabitants for all the Planets." The word "design" explicitates an interpretation of the philosopher's methodical argumentation as a deliberate, systematic, or even contrived plan, a nuance not directly conveyed by the more straightforward "mettre."

The French "qu'il y auroit une exception justement en faveur de la Terre toute seule" (that there would be an exception precisely in favor of Earth all alone) is translated as "and that the Earth only was exempted from it." The phrase "exempted from it" explicitly connects Earth's uniqueness to the previously mentioned "natural Condition" of planets (being uninhabited), thereby spelling out the relationship and the nature of the exception more clearly.

The French intensifier "bien" (well, very) in "bien affermy" (well/very confirmed) is rendered as "very very much confirm'd." This explicit amplification significantly heightens the stated degree of the philosopher's conviction, making the intensity more pronounced and spelled out than in the source.

The French "un peu plus de sens froid" (a little more cool-headedness/composure) is translated as "in a cooler Judgment." The addition of "Judgment" makes explicit the mental faculty or rational process that this cooler state facilitates, an aspect that was merely implied by the state of "sens froid" in the original.

The French "Ciron," a term for a tiny mite (occurring in the phrase "jusqu'au Ciron"), is translated as "Mite" and then expanded to "Mite and the Cicon." The addition of "and the Cicon" (an obscure or possibly interpretative second tiny creature) elaborates on Fontenelle's singular example, making the illustration of minute life more detailed by adding an entity not present in the source.

The French "le goût" (the taste), from "le goût qu'elles font sentir" (the taste they make one feel), is translated as "the Tast and Relish." The addition of "Relish" makes explicit a specific quality or characteristic of the taste (such as piquancy or a distinct, often pleasant, flavor), whereas "goût" is a more general term.

The French "les piqueures" (which can mean pricks, stings, or bites), from "les piqueures que ces petits Animaux font" (the pricks/bites these little Animals make), is translated as "the biting or sting." This expansion spells out two distinct types of actions that could cause the sensation, making the nature of the "piqueures" more explicit by providing specific examples of what they might entail.

chunks.source_manual: <P050>Beaucoup de Corps qui paroissent solides <UP></UP>, ne sont que des amas de ces Animaux imperceptibles, qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut. Une feüille d'Arbre est un petit Monde habité par des Vermisseaux invisibles, à qui elle paroist d'une étenduë immense, qui y connoissent des Montagnes & des Abismes, & qui d'un costé de la feüille à l'autre n'ont pas plus de communication avec les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent, que nous avec nos Antipodes. A plus forte raison, ce me semble, une <RW>grosse</RW> Planete sera-t-elle un Monde habité. On a trouvé jusque dans des especes de pierres tres-dures de petits Vers sans nombre, qui y étoient logez de toutes parts dans des vuides insensibles, & qui ne se nourrissoient que de la substance de ces pierres qu'ils rongeoient. Figurez-vous combien il y avoit de ces petits Vers, & pendant combien d'années ils subsistoient de la grosseur d'un grain de sable; & sur cet exemple, quand la Lune ne seroit qu'un amas de rochers, je la ferois plûtost ronger par ses Habitans que de n'y en pas mettre. Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé <UP></UP>: mettez toutes ces especes d'Animaux nouvellement découvertes, & mesme toutes celles que l'on conçoit aisément qui sont encore à découvrir, avec celles que l'on a toûjours veuës, vous trouverez assurément que la Terre est bien peuplée, & que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vist seulement la moitié. Croirez-vous qu'aprés qu'elle a poussé icy sa fecondité jusqu'à l'excés, elle a esté pour toutes les autres Planetes d'une sterilité à n'y rien produire de vivant?</P050>
chunks.target_manual: <P046>Many bodies that seem solid, are only a heap of those indiscernable Animals, which find as much liberty for motion there, as they need. The Leaf of a Tree is a little World, inhabited by invisible Worms, to whom it seems a place of immense extent, there they find Mountains and Abysses, and the Worms that inhabit on one side of the Leaf, have no more communication with those on the other side, than we have with the Antipodes. With much more reason, in my opinion, a great Planet may be a World inhabited. There has been found even in some kind of exceeding hard Stones innumerable little Worms lodg'd in all parts in insensible vacuities, and were only nourish'd with the substance of the stone; imagine with your self how many little Worms there might be, and how many years they subsisted upon a bit no bigger than a grain of Sand; and according to this example, were the Moon only an heap of Rocks, rather than there should be no Inhabitants, I would make them gnaw upon those Rocks. In fine, all things have Life, all are animated; take you all those species of Animals newly discover'd, and those that we may easily judge are yet to be discover'd, together with those that we daily see, and you will certainly find that the Earth is well peopl'd, and that Nature has been so liberal in Animals, that she never took care that half of them should be seen: do you believe then, that having been so fruitful in her Productions here even to excess, she has been so barren in the other Planets, as to produce nothing living?</P046>
source_segments: qui d'un costé de la feüille à l'autre n'ont pas plus de communication avec les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent
de la grosseur d'un grain de sable
target_segments: and the Worms that inhabit on one side of the Leaf, have no more communication with those on the other side
upon a bit no bigger than a grain of Sand
explanations: The French "d'une étenduë immense" (of an immense extent) is made more concrete in the translation "a place of immense extent". The addition of "a place of" clarifies that "étenduë" (extent, vastness) refers to a physical area or location, information that is implied in the source but spelled out in the target for greater clarity.

The French uses a relative pronoun "qui" (who/which) to refer to the "Vermisseaux invisibles" (invisible worms), with "d'un costé de la feüille à l'autre" (from one side of the leaf to the other) acting as an adverbial phrase describing the context of the communication. The English translation makes the subject of the clause more explicit by rephrasing it as "the Worms that inhabit on one side of the Leaf". This addition of "that inhabit on one side of the Leaf" to define the specific group of worms which are the subject of "have no more communication" spells out information that was more condensed and grammatically distributed in the source, thereby clarifying the agent of the action.

The French "de la grosseur d'un grain de sable" (literally, "of the size/quantity of a grain of sand") describes the amount of substance the worms subsisted on. The English translation "upon a bit no bigger than a grain of Sand" explicitates this by adding "a bit", which specifies that the worms consumed a small piece of material. This clarifies what "grosseur" (size/quantity) refers to in this context of sustenance, which was only implied by the preceding mention of "substance of these stones."

The French "poussé icy sa fecondité" (literally "pushed/developed here her fecundity") describes Nature's action or process. The English translation "fruitful in her Productions here" makes explicit the result or domain of this fecundity by adding "in her Productions." The source implies that fecundity leads to the creation of beings (animals, as discussed in the context), but the target spells this out, clarifying how Nature's fecundity is manifested.

chunks.source_manual: <P051>Ma raison est assez bien convaincuë, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, mais mon imagination est accablée de la multitude infinie des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & embarrassée de la diversité qu'il faut établir entre eux; car je voy bien que la Nature, selon qu'elle est ennemie des repetitions, les aura tous faits différens, mais comment se representer cela? Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter, répondis-je, elle n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux. On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise entre tous ces Mondes. Tous les visages sont en general sur un mesme modele; mais ceux de deux grandes Nations, comme des Européens, si vous voulez, & des Africains, paroissent estre faits sur deux modeles particuliers, & il faudroit encore trouver le modele des visages de chaque Famille. Quel secret doit avoir eu la Nature pour varier en tant de manieres une chose aussi simple qu'un visage? Nous ne sommes dans l'Univers que comme une petite Famille, dont tous les visages se ressemblent; dans une autre Planete, c'est une autre Famille dont les visages ont un autre air. <UP></UP>.</P051>
chunks.target_manual: <P047>I am convinc'd, said the Marchioness, in my reason; but my imagination is overwhelm'd with that infinite multitude of Inhabitants in all the Planets, and confounded with the diversity that must needs be among them; for I well see that Nature, as she is an enemy of repetitions, has made them all different, but how shall we represent it? The Imagination, said I, cannot pretend to represent it, she can go no farther than the Eyes lead her: one certain general view may give a prospect of that diversity that Nature has wrought in all those Worlds. All Faces in general are wrought according to one and the same model, but those of two great Nations, of the Europeans, for example, and Africans seem to be fram'd to two particular models, and we may yet find a particular model in the Faces of every Family. What secret should Nature have in framing such variety in one only thing so simple as a Face? We are in the Universe but as one little Family, where all the Faces resemble; another Planet is another Family, where the Faces have another Air.</P047>
source_segments: sont en general sur un mesme modele
target_segments: are wrought according to one and the same model
explanations: The French "qu'il faut établir" (meaning "that it is necessary to establish" or "that one must establish") implies an active role in creating diversity. The English translation "that must needs be" shifts the emphasis to the inherent and strong necessity of this diversity, with "needs" acting as an intensifier that makes the implicit force of "il faut" (it is necessary) more explicit regarding the state of being diverse.

The French "que les yeux" (than the eyes), in the context "elle n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux" (it [imagination] is not fit to go further than the eyes), implies a limit set by sight. The English translation "than the Eyes lead her" makes this limiting relationship more explicit and dynamic by adding the verb "lead" and the pronoun "her", personifying the eyes as an active guide whose leading action imagination cannot surpass.

The French "apercevoir" (to perceive, to glimpse, to notice), used in "On peut seulement apercevoir... la diversité" (One can only perceive... the diversity), is translated as "give a prospect of" (as in "[a view] may give a prospect of that diversity"). This translation expands the concise French verb, making explicit the idea that the "universal view" doesn't just enable perception by an observer, but actively provides or affords an outlook or potential for understanding the diversity.

In the phrase "la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise," the French "mise" (past participle of 'mettre' - to put/place) suggests Nature having placed or established diversity. The English translation "that Nature has wrought" uses "wrought," which explicitly adds the connotation of skillful, deliberate, and often intricate creation, making the *manner* of Nature's action more explicit than the general term "mise."

The French phrase "sont en general sur un mesme modele" (are generally on the same model/pattern) describes a state of conformity or resemblance of faces to a model. The English translation "are wrought according to one and the same model" makes explicit the idea of active creation or fashioning ("wrought according to") based on this model, a process that is only implied in the French descriptive statement.

Within the context of faces being made according to models ("paroissent estre faits sur deux modeles particuliers"), the French "faits sur" (made on/according to) is translated as "fram'd to" (in "seem to be fram'd to two particular models"). The verb "fram'd" (framed) explicitly suggests a structured, deliberate construction or shaping according to these models, adding a nuance of methodical creation that is more specific and active than the general "faits sur."

The French "pour varier [une chose]" (to vary/diversify [a thing]), indicating Nature's secret purpose for varying something, is translated as "in framing such variety [in one only thing]". The English phrase makes explicit that Nature's secret lies in the *process or act* of "framing" (creating, shaping) variety itself, whereas the French "varier" focuses more on the intended outcome or state of variation.

chunks.source_manual: <P052>Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne, & qui verroit un Habitant de la Lune, & un Habitant de la Terre, remarqueroit bien qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisions qu'un Habitant de la Terre & un Habitant de Saturne. Icy, <NCP>par exemple</NCP>, on a l'usage de la voix, ailleurs on ne parle que par signes, plus loin on ne parle point du tout. Icy le raisonnemét se forme entierement par l'experience; ailleurs l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose, plus loin les Vieillards n'en sçavent pas plus que les Enfants. Icy on se tourmente de l'avenir plus que du passé; plus loin on ne se tourmente ny de l'un ny de l'autre, & ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux. On dit qu'il pourroit bien nous manquer un sixiéme Sens naturel, qui nous aprendroit beaucoup de choses que nous ignorons. Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde, où il manque quelqu'un des cinq que nous possedons. Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il effectivement un grand nombre de Sens naturels; mais dans le partage que nous avons fait avec les Habitans des autres Planetes, il ne nous en est écheu que cinq, dont nous nous contentons faute d'en connoistre d'autres. Nos Sciences ont de certaines bornes que l'Esprit humain n'a jamais pû passer; il y a un point où elles nous manquent tout à coup, le reste est pour d'autres Mondes, où quelque chose de ce que nous sçavons est inconnu. <RW>Cette Planete-cy</RW> joüit des douceurs de l'Amour, mais elle est toûjours desolée en plusieurs de ses parties par les fureurs de la Guerre. Dans une autre Planete on joüit d'une Paix éternelle, mais au milieu de cette Paix on ne connoist point l'Amour, & on s'ennuye. Enfin ce que la Nature pratique en petit entre les hommes pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens, elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué en grand entre les Mondes, & elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a de diversifier toutes choses, & de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations.</P052>
chunks.target_manual: <P048>'Tis most certain that the differences increase in proportion to the distances, and whoever should see an Inhabitant of the Moon and an Inhabitant of the Earth, would easily observe that they were of two Worlds nearer Neighbours than an Inhabitant of the Earth and an Inhabitant of Saturn; here for example we use the Voice, in another place they speak but by Signs, and farther off they speak not at all: Here Reason is wholly form'd by Experience, there Experience contributes little, and farther off old men know no more than children: Here we perplex our selves more for the future than what is past, farther off they concern themselves neither for the one nor the other, and those perhaps are not the most unhappy. It has been thought that we want a sixth natural Sense, by which we might know many things more than we do; that sixth Sense is doubtless in some other World, where possibly they want some one of our five: Nay, perhaps there are really a great number of natural Senses; but in the Distribution made with the Inhabitants of other Planets, only five fell to our share, wherewith we content our selves, because we know no other. Our Knowledge has certain bounds and limits which the Mind of Man cannot exceed, there is a certain point where it wholly fails us, and the rest is for some other World, where likewise something that we know is unknown: This Planet enjoys the Sweets of Love, but in many parts is laid desolate by the fury of War: In another Planet they enjoy perpetual Peace, but know nothing of Love, and are uneasie. In fine, what Nature has done in little among men in her distribution of Happiness or other Talents, she has doubtless done in great among the several Worlds, and did not at all forget that wonderful secret of hers in working a variety in all things, and yet at the same time making them equal by Compensations.</P048>
explanations: The French "Apparemment" (Apparently, Seemingly), at the beginning of the sentence "Apparemment les differences augmentent...", suggests a conclusion based on likelihood or appearance. The translation "'Tis most certain" elevates this to a statement of near-absolute fact, making an assumed high degree of certainty or the intended argumentative force more explicit than the original term, thereby altering the epistemic stance from speculative to assertive.

The French "On dit" (One says, It is said) is a common, somewhat vague attribution. The translation "It has been thought" specifies the nature of this generally held notion as an intellectual or cognitive activity ("thought" rather than just "said"). This explicitation refines the source of the idea, aligning it more closely with a philosophical or reasoned discourse.

The French "apparemment" (apparently, seemingly), used in the phrase "Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde", conveys probability. The translation "doubtless" converts this into a strong assertion of certainty. This explicitation heightens the speaker's expressed confidence in the proposition, making a potential implication of high likelihood into an explicit statement of near certainty.

The French "Peut-estre mesme" (Perhaps even) adds emphasis to the possibility. The English "Nay, perhaps" uses "Nay" as a rhetorical marker. "Nay" often signals a transition, adds emphasis, or introduces a stronger point, sometimes in contrast to an unspoken assumption. This explicitly flags the rhetorical function of the phrase, making the speaker's argumentative progression or emphasis clearer than "mesme" (even) alone might achieve.

The French "tout à coup" in the phrase "où elles nous manquent tout à coup" means "suddenly." The English translation, in the corresponding phrase "where it wholly fails us," effectively replaces the semantic contribution of "tout à coup" with "wholly," meaning "completely." This explicitation shifts the emphasis from the abruptness of the failure of knowledge to the totality of its failure at that point. The translator clarifies an implied consequence of sudden failure (i.e., that it is complete at that juncture) by making the extent of the failure explicit.

The French phrase "en mesme temps que" in "de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations" literally means "at the same time as." The translation renders this, in "making them equal by Compensations," as "by," explicitly introducing compensations as the instrument or means for achieving equality. This instrumental relationship, which is only implied or ambiguous in the original French (which could simply indicate co-occurrence), is thus spelled out by the translator.

The French "on s'ennuye" primarily means "one is bored" or "one becomes weary." The translation "are uneasie" suggests a broader and perhaps deeper state of discomfort, restlessness, or anxiety. Given the philosophical context of a world lacking love despite perpetual peace, the translator may be explicitating an implied existential dissatisfaction or profound "ennui" that goes beyond simple boredom, making the specific nature of this negative state more explicit for the reader.

chunks.source_manual: <P053>Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux? Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres? Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous m'avez donné. Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres. Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire, mais je voy pourtant quelque chose. Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit. Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.</P053>
chunks.target_manual: <P049>Well, Madam, said I, laying aside my serious tone, are you now satisfied? Have I given you Chimera's enough? Truly, says she, I have now less trouble methinks to find out the difference of all those Worlds, my Imagination is now busie about the Plain you have given me. I represent to my self, as well as I can, extraordinary Characters and Customs for the Inhabitants of the Planets, and I frame strange and extravagant figures for them. I cannot well describe them to you, but I see something. As for those figures, says I, I advise you to remit them to the Dreams you will have this night, we shall see to morrow whether they assisted you well in it, and inform'd you of the Shape of the Inhabitants of any Planet.</P049>
explanations: The French "travaille sur" (works on), from "Mon imagination travaille sur le plan", is rendered as "is now busie about" in "my Imagination is now busie about the Plain". The addition of "now" makes explicit the current, ongoing nature of her imaginative activity, which was implied by the preceding "presentement" (presently/now). "Busie about" also elaborates on "travaille sur" by specifying the state of being engaged (busy), an implication made explicit.

The French "tout-à-fait bizarres" (completely bizarre), from "des figures tout-à-fait bizarres", is translated as "strange and extravagant" in "strange and extravagant figures". The single intensified adjective "bizarres" (bizarre/strange), modified by "tout-à-fait" (completely/entirely), is expanded into two distinct adjectives. This explicitation spells out different potential facets of "bizarreness," with "extravagant" adding a layer of excess or being out of bounds that is an interpretation or specification of the more general "bizarre."

The French "pourrois pas décrire" (could not describe / would not be able to describe), from "Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire", is translated as "cannot well describe" in "I cannot well describe them to you." The addition of "well" makes explicit the *manner* or *quality* of the inability to describe. While the original French expresses the impossibility or difficulty, the English translation specifies that the description would lack adequacy or proficiency ("not well").

The French "bien servie" (served you well / been useful/helpful to you), from the phrase "s'ils vous auront bien servie", is translated as "assisted you well in it" in "whether they assisted you well in it." While "assisted" for "servie" (served/been useful) is a contextual choice, the key explicitation is the addition of "in it," which makes explicit the specific context or domain of this assistance (e.g., "in this task" of imagining inhabitants), an aspect that was only implied in the more general French phrasing.

The French "comment sont faits" (how [they] are made/constituted/formed), from "appris comment sont faits les Habitants", is translated by specifying "of the Shape" in "inform'd you of the Shape of the Inhabitants." The original phrase is broad, potentially encompassing physical form, nature, or composition. The translation explicitly narrows this down to "the Shape," focusing solely on physical appearance, whereas the original allowed for a wider range of interpretations.

chunks.source_manual: <P054>QUATRIEME SOIR.</P054>
chunks.target_manual: <P050>THE Fourth Evening.</P050>
explanations: The French heading 'QUATRIEME SOIR.' (Fourth Evening.) omits a definite article, with definiteness being implied by its function as a sequential chapter title. The English translation 'THE Fourth Evening.' makes this implied definiteness explicit by adding the article 'THE'. While English headings can also be formulated without an article (e.g., 'Fourth Evening.'), the translator's choice to include 'THE' formally spells out the definiteness, which subtly alters the original's more stark and unadorned heading style.

chunks.source_manual: <P055><SC>Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit icy. J'eus lieu de reprocher à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> ce que nous reprochent à la veüe de nos Tableaux, de certains Peuples qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques. Bon, nous disent-ils, cela est tout fait comme des hommes, il n'y a pas là d'imagination. Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé.</SC> Nous en estions à Venus. On est bien seur, dis-je à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, <SC>mais on ne sçait pas bien en quel temps</SC>, ny par consequent combien ses jours durent. Pour ses années, elles ne sont que de huit mois, puis qu'elle tourne en ce temps-là autour du Soleil. Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroist une Planete quarante fois plus grande, que Venus ne nous paroist d'icy; & comme la Lune est aussi quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, elle paroist dedans Venus à peu prés de la mesme grandeur dont Venus nous paroist d'icy.</P055>
chunks.target_manual: <P051><UP>Our</UP> Dreams were not successful, they only represented something resembling what we had seen, and I had opportunity of reproching the Marchioness, as those people who never draw any thing but what is extravagant and grotesque reproch us at the sight of our Pictures. Very well, say they, those are men to the life, there's nothing there of fancy, We were fain then to be still ignorant of the Figures of the Inhabitants of the Planets, and content our selves with guessing at them as well as we could, continuing the Voyage we had began about the World: we were in Venus. 'Tis certain, said I to the Marchioness, that Venus turns about her self, but 'tis not well known in what time, nor consequently how long her days are; as for her years, they are but eight months, for in so much time she turns about the Sun. She is forty time less than the Earth, therefore the Earth in Venus seems a Planet forty times bigger than Venus appears to us from hence: and as the Moon is likewise forty times less than the Earth, she seems in Venus very near about the same bigness that Venus appears to us from hence.</P051>
source_segments: Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroist
à ce que l'on voit icy
target_segments: She is forty time less than the Earth, therefore the Earth in Venus seems
explanations: The French "heureux" (happy, fortunate), describing the dreams, is translated as "successful." In the context where the characters were attempting to imagine alien life through their dreams, "not successful" explicitly clarifies that the dreams failed in their intended purpose of revealing novel forms. The original "heureux" is more general, while "successful" makes explicit the specific criterion (achieving an objective) by which the dreams were judged.

The French "bizarres" (bizarre, strange, odd), part of the phrase "peintures bizarres & grotesques" (bizarre and grotesque paintings), is rendered with "extravagant" in the English phrase "extravagant and grotesque." The translation to "extravagant" adds a specific quality of excess or unrestrained imagination, making explicit a particular type of bizarreness that is only one possible implication of the more general French term.

The French sentence structure "Come elle est..." (As/Since she is...), which introduces a reason followed by its consequence, is translated into a structure that explicitly spells out the logical connection using "therefore". The original French implies causality through the conjunction "Comme" and clausal arrangement. The English rendering "She is forty time less than the Earth, therefore the Earth in Venus seems..." rephrases this by stating the premise and then using the strong logical connective "therefore" to introduce the consequence, thus making the relationship more overt.

The French phrase "à ce que l'on voit icy" (literally, 'to what one sees here') uses the impersonal pronoun "l'on" (one) and the present tense "voit" (sees), suggesting a general, contemporary observation. The translation "what we had seen" makes this more specific by shifting to the first-person plural pronoun "we" and the past perfect tense "had seen." This explicitly clarifies that the resemblance is to the characters' own specific, prior experiences, rather than a general or objective present reality, thereby making the subjective basis of their comparison explicit.

chunks.source_manual: <P056>Vous m'affligez, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Je voy bien que la Terre n'est pas pour Vénus l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours, comme Vénus l'est pour la Terre; car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroist trop grande, mais la Lune qui y paroist de la mesme grandeur dont Vénus nous paroist d'icy, est justement taillée comme il faut pour y estre Mere des Amours, & Etoile du Berger <NCE></NCE>. Ces noms ne peuvent convenir qu'à une petite Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant. <UP></UP> C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour nostre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Venus; ces Gens là doivent bien entendre la galanterie. Oh! sans doute, répondis-je, le menu Peuple de Venus n'est composé que de Celadons & de Silvandres, & leurs Conversations le plus communes valent les plus belles de Clesie. <UP></UP> Le climat est tres-favorable aux Amours. Venus est plus proche que nous du Soleil, & elle en reçoit une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur.</P056>
chunks.target_manual: <P052>You vex me, said the Marchioness, I see well that the Earth is not for Venus, the Star of Shepherds and Mother of Love, as Venus is to the Earth; for the Earth in Venus appears too big, but the Moon that appears there of the same bigness that Venus doth to us from hence, is of a just proportion to be the Mother of Love and Star of Shepherds; those names are only fit for a little Planet that is brisk, clear, sparkling, and of a gallant Air. 'Tis certainly a destiny very pleasing to our Moon, to influence the Loves of the Inhabitants of Venus; those people must needs understand Gallantry well. Oh! no question on't, said I, the little people of Venus are made up of none but Celadons, and Sylvanders, and their most ordinary Conversation is beyond the most polite of Clelia, the Climate is extremely favourable for Love; Venus is nearer the Sun than we, and she receives from him a Light more lively and hot.</P052>
source_segments: une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur
target_segments: a Light more lively and hot
explanations: The French "presider aux Amours" (literally "to preside over the Loves") uses a verb that implies a general sense of overseeing or being in charge, which in this metaphorical context of the Moon and love, is somewhat ambiguous. The translation "to influence the Loves" makes explicit the *manner* of this "presiding." It specifies that the Moon's role is one of subtle effect (influence) rather than direct control or governance, thereby clarifying the nature of the metaphorical relationship implied in the original.

The French "les plus belles de Clesie" refers to "the most beautiful [conversations] of Clélie." The adjective "belles" (beautiful) is a general term of praise. The translation "the most polite of Clelia" makes explicit a specific quality—politeness—which was an implied characteristic of "beautiful" conversations within the context of the 17th-century French novel *Clélie*, renowned for its depiction of refined manners and elaborate, courteous discourse. The translator specifies one key aspect that contributes to the "beauty" of these conversations.

The French source states that Venus receives "une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur" (a more vivid light and more heat), listing light and heat as two distinct, though related, things received from the Sun. The English translation "a Light more lively and hot" rephrases this by making "hot" an adjective that directly modifies "Light." This restructuring explicitly presents heat as an intrinsic quality or accompaniment of the light received, thereby spelling out the close physical connection between the sun's light and its heat more directly than the source, which presents them as separate but concurrent effects.

chunks.source_manual: <P057>Je vois presentement, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, comment sont faits les Habitans de Venus. Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins; un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil, plein d'esprit & de feu, toûjours amoureux, faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique, inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois. Permettez-moy de vous dire, Madame, repliquay-je, que vous ne connoissez guere bien les Habitans de Venus. Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient esté auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.</P057>
chunks.target_manual: <P053>I now see, said the Marchioness, interrupting me, how the Inhabitants of Venus are made, they are like the Moors of Granada, a little black people, Sun-burnt, full of spirit and fire, always amorous, given to Poetry and Musick, and every day Feasting, Dancing and Tilting. Let me tell you, Madam, said I, you know but little of the Inhabitants of Venus; our Moors of Granada for the coldness and stupidity of their Temper would be to them but as people of Lapland or Groenland.</P053>
source_segments: pour la froideur & pour la stupidité
target_segments: for the coldness and stupidity of their Temper
explanations: The French verb "interrompit" (interrupted) is used in a context where the Marquise interrupts the narrator (the philosopher). The object of the interruption (the narrator) is implicit in the French. The English translation "interrupting me" makes this previously implicit object explicit by adding "me".

The French phrase "pour la froideur & pour la stupidité" (on account of/for the coldness and stupidity) states the reason for the comparison, implying these qualities are characteristic of the Mores Grenadins. The English translation "for the coldness and stupidity of their Temper" makes this implication explicit by adding "of their Temper", specifying that these qualities are inherent to their disposition or nature.

chunks.source_manual: <P058>Mais que sera-ce des Habitants de Mercure? Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil; il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité. <UP></UP> Je croy qu'ils n'ont point de memoire, non plus que la plupart des Négres; qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien, qu'ils n'agissent qu'à l'aventure, & par des mouvemens subits, & <IIM>qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.</IIM> <NCE></NCE> Ils voyent le Soleil beaucoup plus grand que nous ne le voyons, parce qu'ils en sont beaucoup plus proches. Il leur envoye une lumiere si forte, que s'ils estoient icy, ils ne prendroient nos plus beaux jours que pour de <IIM>tres-foibles</IIM> Crepuscules, & peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets, & la chaleur à laquelle ils sont accoûtumez est si excessive, que celle qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique, suffiroit pour les glacier. Leur année n'est que de trois mois. La durée de leur jour ne nous est point encore connuë, parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu, qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes, & qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur luy, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre; mais sa petitesse fait croire qu'il acheve ce tour en peu de temps; que par consequent le jour de Mercure est fort court, & que les Habitans voyent le Soleil comme un <RW>grand poêle ardent</RW>, peu éloigné de leurs testes, & qui va d'une rapidité prodigieuse. Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent aprés la nuit. Ils sont éclairez pendant ce temps-là de Venus,& de la Terre, qui leur doivent paroistre assez grandes. Pour les autres Planetes, comme elles sont au-delà de la <IIM>Terre vers le Firmament</IIM>, ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons, & n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumiere, peut-estre n'en reçoivent-ils point du tout. Les Etoles Fixes sont aussi plus petites pour eux, & même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement; c'est, selon moy, une perte. Je suis bien fàché de voir cette <RW>grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient</RW>, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée. <SC></SC>.</P058>
chunks.target_manual: <P054>But what are the Inhabitants of Mercury? they are yet nearer the Sun, and therefore certainly must needs be fools with too much vivacity. I believe they have no memory no more than the greatest part of Negro's and that they never consider on any thing, nor act but by chance, and suddain motions; and in fine, that <IIM>Mercury is the Bedlam</IIM> of the Universe. They see the Sun much bigger than we do, because they are much nearer, and he gives them so strong a light, that were they here, they would esteem our fairest days but as weak twilight, and perhaps would not be able to distinguish Objects by it, and they are us'd to so excessive a Heat, that they would freez in the midst of Africa; their year is but three months, the length of their day is yet unknown to us; for Mercury is so little and so near the Sun, in whose Rays he is almost continually lost, that he escapes all observation of Astronomers, and they cannot yet lay hold on him so much as to observe what motion he makes about his Center: but his smalness makes them believe that he performs that Course in a little time, and that therefore the days in Mercury are short, and that the Inhabitants see the Sun like <NCE>a great burning Stove or Kettle</NCE> not far above their heads, and moving with a prodigious rapidity. It is well for them, for 'tis certain they are very desirous of the night, during which time they are inlightened by Venus and the Earth, which ought to appear very big to them.
