As for the other Planets, they being beyond the Earth toward the Firmament, seem less to them than they do to us, and they receive but little or perhaps no Light at all from thence. The fixed Stars likewise seem less to them, and many are not seen at all, which in my opinion is a loss. I am not well pleas'd to see that great Arch adorn'd with lesser Stars, and not to see the rest but in a less proportion and a duller colour.</P054>
source_segments: il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité
n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumiere
& peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets
target_segments: therefore certainly must needs be fools with too much vivacity
a great burning Stove or Kettle
they receive but little or perhaps no Light at all from thence.
and perhaps would not be able to distinguish Objects by it
explanations: The preceding French clause states the cause ('Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil;'). The source segment here is the consequence. The English translation explicitly links this consequence to the cause by adding 'therefore', spelling out a causal connection that was only implied by juxtaposition and a semicolon in the original.

'Les Petites Maisons' was a contemporary French euphemism for lunatic asylums. The translator has replaced this with 'Bedlam,' its well-known English equivalent (referring to Bethlem Royal Hospital in London), making the specific meaning of 'madhouse' explicit for an English audience who might not understand the French idiom.

The French 'poêle' can mean stove, pan, or brazier, referring to a source of strong heat. The English translation 'a great burning Stove or Kettle' expands this single term by offering two specific examples of objects known for intense heat, clarifying the image for the English reader by providing more concrete references.

The French pronoun 'en' ('of/from them/it') in 'n'en reçoivent' implicitly refers to 'les autres Planetes' (the other Planets) as the source from which little light is received. The English translation 'from thence' makes this anaphoric reference explicit by clearly stating the origin of the light.

The French adverbial pronoun 'y' in 'n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets' refers to the previously described hypothetical situation or condition (being on Earth and perceiving its daylight as twilight). The English 'by it' (where 'it' refers to the perceived weak twilight) makes explicit the *means* or *instrument* (the dim light) through which object distinction would be difficult, clarifying an aspect that was more generally implied by 'y'.

chunks.source_manual: <P059>Je ne suis pas si touchée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, de cette perte-là que sont les <IIM>Habitans de Mercure</IIM>, que de l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent de l'excés de la chaleur. Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu. Donnons à Mercure de longues & d'abondantes pluyes qui le rafraischissent, comme on dit qu'il en tombe icy dans les Pays chauds pendant des quatre mois entiers, justement dans les saisons les plus chaudes.</P059>
chunks.target_manual: <P055>I am not, said the Marchioness, so much concern'd at that loss of the Inhabitants of Mercury, as at the inconveniences they suffer by the extremity of Heat. I wish we could procure their ease; therefore pray let us allow in Mercury long and abundant Rain to refresh them, as 'tis said it falls here in hot Countrys for four months together just in the hottest Seasons.</P055>
explanations: The French 'reçoivent' (receive), in the context 'l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent' (the inconvenience they receive), implies a passive experience of something negative. The English 'suffer' makes the negative impact and the experience of hardship more explicit and direct than the more general term 'receive'.

The French text introduces a suggestion with 'Donnons...' (Let's give...). This suggestion implicitly follows as a means to fulfill the wish expressed in the preceding sentence ('Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu.'). The English translation makes this unstated consequential or purposive relationship explicit by prefixing the corresponding clause with 'therefore'. While 'pray let us allow' also rephrases 'Donnons', the addition of 'therefore' is the key explicitation of the logical link.

The French 'entiers' (entire, whole), modifying 'quatre mois', implies that the four months are complete units of time. In the context of a rainy season lasting 'pendant des quatre mois entiers', their consecutiveness is strongly implied. The English translation 'for four months together' uses 'together' to make this implied idea of the months forming one continuous block explicit.

chunks.source_manual: <P060>Cela se peut, repris-je, & mesme nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon. Il y a des Pays dans la Chine qui doivent estre tres-chauds par leur situation, & où il fait pourtant de grands froids pendant les mois de Juillet & d'Aoust, jusque-là que les Rivieres se gelent. C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre; les exhalaisons en sont fort froides, & la force de la chaleur les fait sortir de la Terre en grande abondance. Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM>, & le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire. Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que la Nature ne sçauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre, & que l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement. Ainsi on pourroit même se passer dans Mercure du <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM> & des pluyes.</P060>
chunks.target_manual: <P056>That may be, said I, and we may likewise refresh Mercury another way. Some parts of China, which by their scituation ought to be very hot, are yet so extreme cold in the months of Iuly and August, that the Rivers are frozen: The cause is, those Countrys are full of Saltpeter, the Exhalations whereof are very cold, and the great Heats exhale them from the Earth in great abundance. Mercury, if you please, shall be a little Planet all of Saltpeter, and the Sun shall produce from it self a remedy for the evil that it caused. Most certain it is, that Nature cannot make people live any where but where they can live, and that Custome joyn'd with Ignorance of what is better, makes them live there well enough. So in Mercury they may live well enough without Saltpeter or Rain.</P056>
source_segments: au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire
target_segments: for the evil that it caused
explanations: The French phrase 'C'est que' (literally 'It is that...'), which introduces an explanation or reason, is translated as 'The cause is,'. This makes the implicit causal relationship between the preceding observation (extreme cold in hot regions of China) and the following fact (presence of saltpeter) explicit by specifically naming the relationship as 'the cause'.

The French phrase 'au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire' (for the harm that it could do to it/him) uses the conditional 'pourroit' (could), suggesting a potential harm from the Sun to Mercury. The English translation 'for the evil that it caused' makes this harm explicit as a definite, actualized effect or a characteristic action of the Sun, rather than merely a potential one. It clarifies that the 'harm' is the established problem for which a remedy is being discussed.

The French reflexive verb 'se passer' (from 'se passer de quelque chose', meaning 'to do without something' or 'to manage without something') is rendered as 'live well enough without'. The addition of 'live well enough' makes explicit the implied *manner* or *consequence* of doing without saltpeter and rains on Mercury, linking it to the preceding discussion where custom and ignorance allow inhabitants to 'live there well enough' in various conditions.

chunks.source_manual: <P061>Aprés Mercure vous sçavez qu'on trouve le Soleil. Il n'y a pas moyen d'y mettre d'Habitans. Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là. Nous jugeons par la Terre qui est habitée, que les autres Corps de la mesme espece qu'elle, doivent l'estre aussi; mais le Soleil n'est point un Corps de la mesme espece que la Terre, ny que les autres Planetes. Il est la source de toute cette lumiere que les Planetes ne font que se renvoyer les unes aux autres, aprés l'avoir reçeüe de luy. Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles, mais elles ne la peuvent produire. Luy seul tire de soy-mesme cette pretieuse substance; il la pousse avec force de tous costez; de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide, & d'une Planete à l'autre il s'épand de longues & vastes traisnées de lumieres qui se croisent & se traversent, & s'entrelassent en mille façons diferentes, & forment d'admirables tissus de la plus riche matiere qui soit au monde. Aussi le Soleil est-il placé dans le centre, qui est le lieu le plus commode d'où il la puisse distribuer également, & animer tout par sa chaleur <NCP></NCP>. Le Soleil est donc un Corps <UP>particulier</UP>, mais quelle sorte de Corps? On est bien embarrassé à le dire. On avoit toûjours crû que c'estoit un feu tres-pur, mais on s'en desabusa au commencement de ce <IIM>Siecle</IIM>, qu'on apperceut des taches sur sa surface. Comme on avoit découvert peu de temps auparavant de nouvelles Planetes dont je vous parleray; que tout le <IIM>Monde Philosophe</IIM> n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode, on jugea aussi-tost que ces taches en estoient; <UP>qu'elles avoyent un mouvement autour du Soleil</UP>, & qu'elles nous en cachoient necessairement quelque partie, en tournant leur moitié obscure vers nous. Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à tous les Princes de l'Europe. Les uns leur donnoient le nom d'un Prince, les autres d'un autre, & peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle entre-eux à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...</P061>
chunks.target_manual: <P057>Next after Mercury you know is the Sun, there is no way of making him habitable, the cause is clear. We judge by the Earth that is inhabited, that other bodies of the same species may be so likewise, but the Sun is not a body of the same species with the Earth, nor with the other Planets; he is the Fountain of that Light, which the other Planets only reflect from one to another, after having received it from him. They may exchange it, as we may say, among themselves, but they cannot produce it: he only extracts from himself that precious substance, and emits it with vigour on all sides: where ever it meets with any thing that is solid, it reflects, and from one Planet to another long and vast trains of Light cross and traverse one another in a thousand ways, and form an admirable Tissue of the richest material in the World. The Sun likewise is seated in the Center, as a place the most convenient, from whence he may equally distribute his Heat and animate all things with it. The Sun then is a particular, body, but what sort of body, is hard to say. It was ever believ'd to be a most refined fire, but that opinion vanish'd in the beginning of this Age, when the Spots upon his surface were dicover'd. When the new Planets, whereof I shall tell you more, were discover'd not long before, and all the Philosophick World busied their Brains about nothing else, it was presently judg'd that those Spots were the new Planets, that they had a motion about the Sun, and that necessarily they hid some part of him from us, in turning their obscure half toward us. Presently <IIM>the Virtuoso's began their Flattery</IIM> with these pretended Planets to all the Princes of Europe, some gave them the name of one Prince, some of another, and perhaps there was a quarrel among them what Prince should be Godfather to the chief of those Spots.</P057>
source_segments: de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide,
à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...
target_segments: where ever it meets with any thing that is solid, it reflects,
he may equally distribute his Heat
what Prince should be Godfather to the chief of those Spots.
explanations: The French 'Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là.' (literally, 'The 'Why not' is lacking to us there.') subtly suggests that the reason the Sun is uninhabitable is so fundamental or different that the usual 'why nots' (like those for planets) don't apply, or it's almost beyond simple articulation. The translation 'the cause is clear.' makes explicit the *implication* that the uninhabitability is certain and its reason evident (which Fontenelle subsequently explains), removing the original's philosophical nuance and stating the outcome of the implied reasoning directly.

The French 'de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide,' (from there it [light] comes back to meet/encounters whatever is solid,) describes light's interaction with solid bodies in general terms. The English translation 'where ever it meets with any thing that is solid, it reflects,' makes explicit the physical process of *reflection* ('it reflects'). This optical process is implied when light interacts with solid matter to become visible or be redirected, but Fontenelle uses the more general 'revient à la rencontre' rather than a specific scientific term for the interaction itself.

In the French, 'la' in 'il la puisse distribuer également,' (it can distribute IT equally,) refers to 'cette pretieuse substance' (this precious substance, i.e., light) mentioned earlier in the source text. The translation 'he may equally distribute his Heat' explicitly changes the object being distributed to 'Heat.' While the sun is the source of both light and heat, and Fontenelle mentions heat in the subsequent clause for animation ('animer tout par sa chaleur'), his text here specifies light ('la') as the substance being distributed. The translation makes 'Heat' the explicit object of distribution, altering the specific detail of Fontenelle's description of solar emissions.

The French 'les Sçavans' is a general term for 'the Scholars' or 'Learned men.' The translation 'the Virtuoso's' makes this more specific by using a term current in the 17th and 18th centuries for individuals with a cultivated interest in arts and sciences, often engaged in collecting, experimentation, and discussion within learned societies. This specifies the social and intellectual type of 'Sçavans' Fontenelle refers to in this context, making an implicit aspect of their contemporary character explicit for the English reader.

The French phrase 'faisoient leur Cour' (literally 'made their court') can mean to pay respects or seek favor, but in the context of scholars naming celestial objects after princes, the strong implication is that this act was a form of flattery. The translation 'began their Flattery' makes this implicit motivation or the sycophantic nature of the act explicit, removing the subtlety of the original French and directly stating the scholars' intent.

The French phrase 'à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...' (about who would remain the master of the spots to name them as he wished...) describes a dispute over naming rights. The translation 'what Prince should be Godfather to the chief of those Spots.' rephrases and explicitates this by: 1. Using 'Godfather,' which introduces a specific socio-cultural role associated with naming ceremonies and patronage, making the implied social dynamics of dedicating a discovery more concrete and culturally evocative than the general 'maistre... pour les nommer.' 2. Adding 'the chief of those Spots,' which specifies that the quarrel might concern a particularly prominent or important spot, a detail not explicit in the French general term 'des taches' (of the spots).

chunks.source_manual: <P062>Je ne trouve point cela bon, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Vous me disiez l'autre jour qu'on avoit donné aux differentes parties de la Lune des noms de Sçavans & d'Astronomes, & j'en estois fort contente. Puis que les Princes prennent pour eux la Terre, il est juste que les Sçavans se reservent le Ciel, & y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres. Souffrez, répondis-je, <UP></UP> qu'ils puissent, du moins en cas de besoin, engager aux Princes quelque Astre, ou quelque partie de la Lune. Quant aux taches du Soleil, ils n'en purent faire aucun usage. Il se trouva que ce n'estoient point des Planetes, mais des nuages, des fumées, des écumes, qui s'élèvent sur le Soleil. Elles sont tantost en grande quantité, tantost en petit nombre; tantost elles disparoissent toutes, quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se separent, quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires. Il y a des temps où l'on en voit beaucoup, il y en a d'autres, & mesme assez longs, où il n'en paroist aucune. Il semble que le Soleil soit une matiere liquide, quelques-uns disent de l'Or fondu, qui boüillonne incessamment <NCP></NCP>, & produit des impuretez, qui par la force de son mouvement sont rejettées sur sa surface. Elles s'y consument, & puis il s'en produit d'autres. Imaginez-vous quels Corps étrangers ce sont là. Il y en a tel qui est peut-estre aussi grand que la Terre. Jugez par là quelle est la quantité de cet Or fondu, ou l'étenduë de cette grande Mer de lumiere & de feu qu'on appelle le Soleil. D'autres disent que le Soleil paroît avec des Lunettes tout plein de Montagnes qui vomissent des flâmes, & que c'est comme un million de Monts Etna mis ensemble, mais on dit aussi que ces Montagnes sont une pure vision, causée par quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes. Aquoy se fiera-t-on, s'il faut se défier des Lunettes mesme, ausquelles nous devons la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects. Enfin, quoy que ce puisse estre que le Soleil, il ne paroist nullement propre à estre habité. C'est pourtant dommage, l'habitation seroit belle. On seroit au centre de tout, on verroit toutes les Planetes tourner regulierement autour de soy, au lieu que nous voyons dans leur cours une infinité de bizareries, qui n'y paroissent que parce que nous ne sommes pas en le lieu propre pour en bien juger, c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement. Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable? Il n'y a qu'un lieu dans le Monde, d'où l'étude des Astres puisse estre extremément facile, & justement dans ce lieu-là, il n'y a personne. Vous n'y songez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Qui seroit dans le Soleil, verroit rien, ny Planetes, ny Etoiles Fixes. Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout? Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire seuls dans toute la Nature.</P062>
chunks.target_manual: <P058>I do not approve of that, said the Marchioness, you told me the other day, that the different parts of the Moon were call'd by the names of Virtuoso's and Astronomers, and I was well satisfy'd. For since Princes have the Earth to themselves, it is but just the Virtuoso's should reserve the Heavens to themselves, and govern there without admitting any Rivals. You may allow them, said I, in case of necessity, to ingage a Star or part of the Moon to a Prince; as for the Spots of the Sun, they can make no use of them. It has been found that they are not Planets, but Clouds, or Fumes, or Froth that rises upon the Face of the Sun: sometimes they are many, sometimes few, sometimes they wholly disappear, sometimes many of them crowd together, sometimes they separate, sometimes they appear more clear and sometimes more obscure, sometimes many of them are seen, and at other times for a long while together none appear at all. The Sun seems to be some liquid matter, some think melted Gold that boyls incessantly, and produces those impurities, which by the force of his motion are thrown out upon his surface, where they consume, and he afterward produces more. Imagine with your self what strange bodies those are, some of them are, it may be, as big as the Earth, judge from thence how great is the quantity of that melted Gold, and how large that Sea of Light and Fire which we call the Sun. Others say that the Sun appears in the Telescope full of Mountains that vomit Flame, and it seems a million of Aetna's put together, but they say likewise that those mountains are a meer appearance, caus'd by some accident in the Telescope. But what then shall we trust to, if we must distrust the Telescope, to which we owe the knowledge of so many new Objects? In fine, whatever the Sun be, it appears not at all fit to be inhabited, which certainly is a great loss; for it would be a delicate Habitation: We should be in the Center of all, and should see the Planets move regularly about him, whereas now we see an infinite extravagance in their motions, because we are not in a place proper to judge of them, that is in the Center, is not that a pity? There is but one place in the World where the study of the Stars would be extreme easie, and in that very place there's not a man. You never consider, said the Marchioness, that whoever should be in the Sun would see nothing at all, neither Planets nor fixed Stars. Does not the Sun hide all? So it would be with his Inhabitants, who would indeed have good reason to believe themselves the only Creatures in Nature.</P058>
source_segments: quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes
target_segments: upon the Face of the Sun
upon his surface, where they consume, and he afterward produces more.
explanations: The French 'Sçavans' (learned men/scholars) is translated as 'Virtuoso's'. In the late 17th-century English context, 'virtuoso' specifically denoted a gentleman scholar involved in the new experimental philosophy and natural history. This explicitation clarifies the specific type of learned individual, aligning with contemporary English scientific culture.

The French 'à d'autres' (to others) is translated as 'any Rivals'. This explicitation clarifies the nature of the 'others' by specifying them as competitors, thereby making the implied antagonistic relationship in the context of reserving the Heavens explicit.

The French 'sur le Soleil' (on the Sun) is translated as 'upon the Face of the Sun'. The addition of 'the Face of' makes explicit the common metaphorical understanding of a celestial body's visible disk or surface, clarifying the location of the phenomena being described.

The French phrase 'sur sa surface.' (onto its surface.) describing where sunspot impurities are thrown, is expanded in the English translation to 'upon his surface, where they consume, and he afterward produces more.' This addition explicates a fuller contemporary theory about the lifecycle of sunspots (their consumption and subsequent regeneration by the Sun), information not present in Fontenelle's original sentence.

The French 'avec des Lunettes' (with glasses/lenses), used by Fontenelle to refer to telescopes in an astronomical context, is translated as 'in the Telescope'. This explicitation uses the specific technical term for the instrument, removing any potential ambiguity of 'Lunettes' and clarifying the means of observation.

The French 'quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes' (something that happens in the lenses/telescope) is translated as 'some accident in the Telescope'. Fontenelle's phrasing is vague about the cause of the visual distortion; the translation 'some accident' explicitly interprets this 'something' as an instrumental flaw, artifact, or unintended effect, thereby specifying a cause that was only implicitly possible in the original.

The French 'Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable?' is a standalone rhetorical question following a statement. The English translation 'is not that a pity?' is integrated as a concluding clause directly appended to the preceding statement ('...that is in the Center, is not that a pity?'). This structural change makes the logical connection between the described situation (not being at the center) and the sentiment of pity more syntactically explicit and immediate.

The French 'seuls dans toute la Nature' (alone in all of Nature) is translated as 'the only Creatures in Nature'. The term 'Creatures' explicitly specifies that the inhabitants of the Sun would believe themselves to be the only *living beings* or *sentient entities*, narrowing the more general implication of 'seuls' (alone/the only ones) and clarifying the nature of their perceived uniqueness.

chunks.source_manual: <P063>J'avoüe que je m'estois trompé, répondis-je, je ne songeois qu'à la situation où est le Soleil,& non à l'effet de sa lumiere; mais vous qui me redressez si à propos, vous voulez bien que je vous dise que vous vous estes trompée aussi; les Habitans du Soleil ne le verroient seulement pas. Ou ils ne pourroient soûtenir la force de sa lumiere, ou ils ne la pourroient recevoir, faute d'en estre à quelque distance, & tout bien considéré, le Soleil ne seroit qu'un séjour d'Aveugles; encore un coup, il n'est pas fait pour estre habité; mais voulez-vous que nous poursuivions nostre Voyage des Mondes? Nous sommes arrivéz au centre qui est toûjours le lieu le plus bas dans tout ce qui est rond, il faudroit presentement retourner sur nos pas, & remonter. Nous retrouverons Mercure, Venus, la Terre, la Lune, toutes Planetes que nous avons visitées. Ensuite c'est Mars qui se presente. Mars n'a rien de curieux que je sçache, ses jours ne sont pas d'une heure entiere plus longs que les nostres; ses années valent deux de nos années. Il est plus petit que la Terre, il voit le Soleil un peu moins grand & moins vif que nous ne le voyons; enfin Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine qu'on s'y arreste. Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter avec ses quatre Lunes ou <RW>Satellites</RW>! Ce sont quatre petites Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, comme nostre Lune tourne autour de nous. Mais, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, pourquoy y a-t-il des Planetes qui tournent autour d'autres Planetes qui ne valent pas mieux qu'elles? Serieusement il me paroîtroit plus regulier & plus uniforme que toutes les Planetes, grandes & petites, n'eussent que le mesme mouvement autour du Soleil!</P063>
chunks.target_manual: <P059>I confess, said I. I was mistaken, I only consider'd the Scituation of the Sun, and not the effect of his Light; but you that correct me so aptly, must give me leave to tell you, that you are as much mistaken as my self, the Inhabitants of the Sun would not see him at all. Either they would not be able to suffer the force of his Light, or they could not receive it being not plac'd at a distance from it; all which being well consider'd, the Sun would be only an abode of Blind people: But to prevent all that, it is not made to be inhabited. Will you then that we prosecute our Voyage about the Worlds? We are come to the Center, which is always the lowest place in any thing that is round, we must now return and ascend again, and shall meet in our way Mercury, Venus, the Earth and the Moon, Planets that we have already visited. The next that offers is Mars, who has nothing curious in him, that I know, his days are not a whole hour longer than ours, but his years are as long as two of ours: he is less than the Earth, and sees the Sun neither so big nor so bright as we. In fine, Mars has nothing in him worth the while to detain us. But the jolly Iupiter with his four Moons or Satellits is worth a Visit. They are four little Planets that turn about him as the Moon turns about as. But, says the Marchioness, interrupting me, why! are there Planets that turn about other Planets no better than themselves? Seriously it would seem to me more regular and uniform that all Planets both great and small should have but one and the same motion about the Sun.</P059>
source_segments: Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter avec ses quatre Lunes ou Satellites!
Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine
target_segments: But the jolly Iupiter with his four Moons or Satellits is worth a Visit.
Mars has nothing in him worth the while
explanations: The French "encore un coup" (meaning "once again," "in short," or "another point is") typically serves as a rhetorical marker to emphasize or conclude a point. The English translation "But to prevent all that" re-writes this by introducing an explicit teleological reason—that the Sun is uninhabitable *in order to prevent* the negative consequences (blindness of inhabitants) discussed immediately prior. This makes explicit a cause-and-effect relationship not stated by Fontenelle's phrase.

The French impersonal pronoun "on" in "qu'on s'y arreste" (that one/people/we stop there) is translated as "us" within the phrase "to detain us." While "us" (referring to the narrator and the Marquise) is strongly implied by the conversational narrative, the translator makes this specific reference explicit, shifting from a general or impersonal perspective to one directly involving the characters.

The French "Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter...!" is an exclamation expressing admiration for Jupiter ("What a fine/lovely thing Jupiter is!"). The English translation transforms this exclamation into a statement that Jupiter "...is worth a Visit." This explicitation clarifies the *implication* of the narrator's admiration within the context of their "Voyage des Mondes," effectively spelling out that Jupiter's remarkable qualities make it a destination worthy of attention on their conceptual journey.

The French "Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine" (Mars is not really worth the trouble/effort), part of the larger phrase "enfin Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine qu'on s'y arreste," makes a judgment about the value of stopping at Mars. The English translation "Mars has nothing in him worth the while," from "In fine, Mars has nothing in him worth the while to detain us," explicitly states the *reason* for this lack of value: an absence of interesting features intrinsic to Mars ("nothing in him"). This adds a clarifying explanation for the judgment, making an implied cause explicit.

chunks.source_manual: <P064>Ah! Madame, répliquay-je! Si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les <RW><NCP>Tourbillons</NCP></RW> de Descartes, ces Tourbillons dont le nom est si terrible, & l'idée si agreable, vous ne parleriez pas comme vous faites. La teste me dust-elle tourner, dit-elle en riant, il est beau de sçavoir ce que c'est que les Tourbillons. Achevez de me rendre folle, je ne me ménage plus, je ne connois plus de retenuë sur la Philosophie; laissons parler le monde, & donnons-nous aux Tourbillons. Je ne vous connoissois pas de pareils emportemens, répris-je; c'est dommage qu'ils n'ayent que les Tourbillons pour objet. Ce qu'on appelle un Tourbillon, c'est un amas de matiere dont les parties sont détachées les unes des autres, & se meuvent toutes en un mesme sens; permis à elles d'avoir pendant ce temps-là quelques petites mouvemens particuliers, pourveu qu'elles suivent toûjours le mouvement general. Ainsi un Tourbillon de vent <UP></UP>, c'est une infinité de petites parties d'air, qui tournent en rond toutes ensemble, & enveloppent ce qu'elles rencontrent. Vous sçavez que les Planetes sont portées dans la matiere celeste, qui est d'une subtilité, & d'une agitation prodigieuse. Tout ce grand amas de matiere celeste, qui est depuis le Soleil <UP></UP>jusqu'aux Etoiles fixes, tourne en rond, & emportant avec soy les Planetes <UP></UP>, les fait tourner toutes en un mesme sens autour du Soleil, qui occupe le centre; mais en des temps plus ou moins longs, selon qu'elles en sont plus ou moins éloignées. Il n'y a pas jusqu'au Soleil qui ne tourne; mais il ne tourne que sur luy-mesme, parce qu'il est justement au milieu de toute cette <IIM>matiere celeste</IIM>; & vous remarquerez en passant, que quand la Terre seroit dans la place où il est, elle ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner sur elle-mesme.</P064>
chunks.target_manual: <P060>Ah! Madam, said I, did you but know what the Vortices of Descartes are, Vortices whose name is so terrible and Idea so agreeable, you would not talk as you do. What, says she laughing, must my Head turn round? 'twill be pleasant to know what these Vortices are; pray make an end of fooling me, I can no longer govern my self, nor muse longer upon Philosophy, let us leave talking of the World, and begin with these Vortices. I never knew you so transported, said I, 'tis pity there is any other Objects than Vortices. A Vortex is a mass of matter whose parts are lose one from the other, and move all in conformity to themselves; but in the mean time you must allow them some little particular motions, provided they still follow the general motion. So a Whirlwind is an infinity of little parts of Air, that turn round altogether and inclose all they meet. You know the Planets are carried in the celestial matter, which is of a prodigious subtilty and agitation. All that great mass of celestial matter from the Sun to the fixed Stars turns round and carrying the Planets with it, makes them turn all uniformly about the Sun, which possesses the Center, but in more or less time, according as their distances are more or less from him. All even to the Sun it self turn, but he turns only about himself, because he is just in the Center of that celestial matter, and you must observe by the way, that were the Earth in the Center it could do no less than turn upon its own Axis.</P060>
explanations: The French phrase "permis à elles d'avoir" (literally 'it being permitted to them to have' or 'they are allowed to have') describes a property of the particles in Descartes' vortex model in an impersonal, descriptive manner. The English translation "you must allow them" shifts to a direct address targeting the interlocutor (the Marquise, and by extension, the reader). This change makes explicit the implied cognitive requirement for the listener/reader to accept this premise of the model in order to understand it. The re-writing foregrounds the pedagogical interaction by directly instructing the audience on how to engage with the concept, a dynamic that was only implicit in the original's descriptive phrasing.

The French phrase "tourner sur elle-mesme" translates literally to "to turn upon itself." This is a general description of rotation. The English translation "turn upon its own Axis" makes explicit the specific astronomical mechanism of this self-rotation by adding the term "Axis." While the concept of an axis is implied for a celestial body turning on itself, the translator has chosen to add this technical term, thereby increasing the level of scientific specificity beyond what Fontenelle expressed in the original, simpler phrasing aimed at a lay audience.

chunks.source_manual: <P065>Voila quel est le grand Tourbillon dont le Soleil est comme le Maistre; mais en mesme temps les Planetes se composent de petits Tourbillons particuliers à l'imitation de celuy du Soleil. Chacune d'elles en tournant autour du Soleil, ne laisse pas de tourner autour d'elle-mesme, & fait tourner aussi autour d'elle en mesme sens une certaine quantité de cette matiere celeste, qui est toûjours preste à suivre tous les mouvemens qu'on luy veut donner, s'ils ne la détournent pas de son mouvement general. c'est-là le Tourbillon particulier de la Planete & elle le pousse aussi loin que la force de son mouvement se peut étendre. S'il faut qu'il tombe dans ce petit Tourbillon quelque Planete moindre que celle qui y domine, la voilà emportée par la grande, & forcée indispensablement à tourner autour d'elle, & le tout ensemble, la grande Planete, la petite, & le Tourbillon qui les renferme, n'en tourne pas moins autour du Soleil. C'est ainsi qu'au commencement du Monde nous nous fismes suivre par la Lune, parce qu'elle se trouva dans l'étenduë de nostre Tourbillon, & tout à fait à nostre bienséance. Jupiter dont je commençois à vous parler, fut plus heureux ou plus puissant que nous. Il y avoit dans son voisinage quatre petites Planetes, ils se les assujettit toutes quatre, & <UP></UP> nous qui sommes une Planete principale, croyez-vous que nous l'eussions esté, si nous nous fussions trouvés proches de luy? Il est quatre-vingt-dix fois plus gros que nous, il nous auroit engloutis sans peine dans son Tourbillon, & nous ne serions qu'une Lune de sa dépendance, au lieu que nous en avons une qui est dans la nostre, tant il est vray que le seul hazard de la situation décide souvent de toute la fortune qu'on doit avoir.</P065>
chunks.target_manual: <P061>You see there what is the great Vortex whereof the Sun is Master, but at the same time the Planets make little particular vortices in imitation of that of the Sun. Each of them in turning about the Sun, turns likewise about it self, and turns together with it a certain quantity of the celestial matter, which is apt to comply with any motion that is given it, if they do not divert it from its general motion. This is the particular Vortex of a Planet, and the Planet pushes it forward as far as the force of its motion can extend. If in that little Vortex a Planet less than that which rules there, do incroach, it is carried on by the greater, and forc'd indispensibly to turn about it: yet nevertheless the great and little Planet, and the Vortex that incloses them, turn about the Sun. So at the beginning of the World, we made the Moon follow us, because she was plac'd within the limits and extent of our Vortex, and wholly at our devotion. Iupiter, of whom I began to tell you, was more happy or more powerful than we, there were four little Planets in his Neighbourhood, and he subdu'd them all; don't you think he would have subdu'd us likewise, who are a principal Planet, had we been his Neighbours? He is ninety times bigger than us, and would doubtless with ease have swallow'd us up in his Vortex, and we should have been no more than a Moon attending on him: whereas we now have one of our own attending on us, So true it is, that the chance only of place and situation often decides the whole fortune of a man.</P061>
source_segments: tout à fait à nostre bienséance
une qui est dans la nostre
target_segments: don't you think he would have subdu'd us likewise
one of our own attending on us
explanations: The French "elle le pousse" (it pushes it/extends it) describes the planet's general action of propelling its vortex. The English translation "the Planet pushes it forward" adds the directional adverb "forward," making explicit a likely implied direction of this propulsive action, thereby clarifying the verb "pousse" by specifying the vector of the motion.

The French "l'étenduë" (the extent, range, expanse) refers to the scope of the vortex. The English translation "the limits and extent" makes explicit the implied boundaries or confines of this "étendue" by adding the word "limits," thus clarifying a key spatial characteristic of the vortex's reach that was only suggested by the original term.

The French "tout à fait à nostre bienséance" suggests the Moon's position was entirely suitable or convenient for Earth within the vortex model. The English translation "wholly at our devotion" makes explicit the implied consequence of this suitability, which is the Moon's resultant subservience to Earth's gravitational influence or control. "At our devotion" spells out the power dynamic and the Moon's captured state more directly than the more general term "bienséance" (suitability/convenience).

The French "que nous l'eussions esté" (that we would have been *it*) uses a pronoun "l'" (it) with an implied antecedent related to Jupiter's power to subdue smaller planets or their fate of being captured. The English translation "don't you think he would have subdu'd us likewise" makes this implied fate explicit by clearly stating "subdu'd us," thus spelling out the unstated hypothetical consequence for Earth had it been in Jupiter's vicinity.

The French "une Lune de sa dépendance" (a Moon of its dependence) describes a moon subject to Jupiter's influence or within its sphere of control. The English translation "a Moon attending on him" makes explicit the specific nature of this dependency by portraying an active, hierarchical relationship where the moon serves or accompanies its primary planet. This clarifies the functional role implied by "dépendance" in an astronomical and dynamic context.

The French "une qui est dans la nostre" (one that is in ours) implies "in our sphere of influence/dependence" or "within our vortex." Similar to the previous instance concerning Jupiter, the English translation "one of our own attending on us" makes explicit the active, hierarchical relationship of Earth's Moon attending the Earth. This spells out the specific role and subservient positioning of the Moon, which was more generally implied by being "dans la nostre [dépendance/tourbillon]".

The French phrase "toute la fortune qu'on doit avoir" (all the fortune that one is to have) uses the indefinite pronoun "on" (one, people). The English translation concludes with "the whole fortune of a man," making the general human subject, implicitly referred to by "on," explicit by using "a man." In the 17th-century context, "a man" was a common generic term for humankind or any individual person, thus specifying the referent of "on" in a way that was conventional for the period.

chunks.source_manual: <P066>Et qui nous assure, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que nous demeurerons toûjours où nous sommes? Je commence à craindre que nous ne fassions la folie de nous approcher d'une Planete aussi entreprenante que Jupiter, ou qu'il <IIM>ne vienne</IIM> vers nous pour nous absorber; car il me paroist que dans ce grand mouvement, où vous dites qu'est la matiere Celeste, elle devroit agiter les Planetes irregulierement, tantost les approcher, tantost les éloigner les unes des autres. <UP>Nous pourrions aussi-tost y gagner qu'y perdre, répondis-je</UP>, peut-estre irions-nous soumettre à nostre domination Mercure & Venus, qui sont de petites Planetes, & qui ne nous pourroient résister. Mais nous n'avons rien à esperer ny à craindre; les Planetes se tiennent où elles sont, & les nouvelles conquestes leur sont défenduës, comme elles l'étoient autrefois aux Rois de la Chine. Vous sçavez bien que quand on met de l'huile avec de l'eau, l'huile surnage. Qu'on mette sur ces deux liqueurs un Corps extremement leger <UP></UP>, l'huile le soûtiendra, & il n'ira pas jusqu'à l'eau. Qu'on y mette un autre Corps plus pesant, & qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur, il passera au travers de l'huile, qui sera trop foible pour l'arrester, & tombera jusqu'à ce qu'il rencontre l'eau, qui aura la force de le soûtenir. Ainsi dans cette liqueur composée de deux liqueurs qui ne se mêlent point, deux Corps inégalement pesants se mettent naturellement à deux places differentes, & jamais l'un ne montera, ny l'autre ne descendra. Qu'on mette encore d'autres liqueurs qui se tiennent separées, & qu'on y plonge d'autres corps, il arrivera la mesme chose. Representez-vous que la Matiere Celeste qui remplit ce grand Tourbillon, à differentes couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres, & dont les pesanteurs sont differentes, comme celles de l'huile & de l'eau, & des autres liqueurs. Les Planetes ont aussi differentes pesanteurs; chacune d'elles par consequent s'arreste dans la couche qui a précisément la force necessaire pour la soûtenir, & qui luy fait équilibre, & vous voyez bien qu'il n'est pas possible qu'elle en sorte jamais.</P066>
chunks.target_manual: <P062>And what assurance, said the Marchioness, have we of continuing always where we are? I begin so fear we may commit the folly of approaching too near so bold a Planet as Iupiter, or that he may draw toward us to swallow us up; for it seems to me that that great motion of the celestial matter ought to move the Planets irregularly, and draw them sometime nearer, sometime further off from one another. We should as soon gain as lose by that, said I, perhaps we should bring Mercury and Venus, little Planets which could not resist us, into subjection to us. But we need neither hope nor fear, the Planets still keep their old stations and are forbidden to make new Conquests, as heretofore the Kings of China were. You know that in mixing Oil & Water, the Oil swims above, and if you lay upon those two liquors a body extremely light, the Oil will support it that it shall not touch the Water; but if you add another body more heavy of a certain weight, it will pass through the Oil which will be too weak to support it, and will press till it meets the Water, which will be strong enough to bear it. So in that liquor compos'd of two liquors that do not intermix, two bodies of unequal weight do naturally put themselves in two different places, and the one will never ascend, nor the other descend. Again, put together other liquors that shall continue separate and unmixed, and put in other bodies, it will be still the same. Represent to your self that the celestial matter that fills this great Vortex has several lays that infold one another, and whereof the Weights are different, as those of Oil and Water, and other liquors. The Planets have likewise different Weights, and consequently every one of them floats upon the lay, which has exactly a strength necessary to support it, and makes it of such equal poise, that it is not possible it should ever remove from thence.</P062>
source_segments: qui luy fait équilibre, & vous voyez bien qu'il n'est pas possible qu'elle en sorte jamais
target_segments: that it shall not touch the Water
that shall continue separate and unmixed
and makes it of such equal poise, that it is not possible it should ever remove from thence
explanations: The French "se tiennent où elles sont" (literally "hold themselves where they are" or "stay where they are") is translated as "still keep their old stations." The addition of "old stations" explicitly refers to the established, historical positions of the planets, and "still" emphasizes the continuity of this state. This makes explicit the implication of long-term stability and unchanging positions, which is less directly conveyed by the simpler French phrase.

The French "il n'ira pas jusqu'à l'eau" (literally "it will not go as far as the water") is translated as "that it shall not touch the Water." The translation makes the implicit consequence of being supported by the oil (i.e., not making physical contact with the water below) explicit by using the specific verb "touch." While "n'ira pas jusqu'à" implies not reaching, "shall not touch" clarifies the nature of this non-reaching by specifying the absence of physical contact.

The French "qui se tiennent separées" (which keep themselves separate), when referring to liquids, implies that they do not mix. The translation "that shall continue separate and unmixed" makes this property of non-miscibility explicit by adding "and unmixed." This spells out a defining characteristic of the liquids that is strongly implied by "separées" in this scientific context but is made more direct and unambiguous in the translation.

The French "s'arreste dans la couche" (stops/comes to rest in the layer) is translated as "floats upon the lay." The verb "floats" makes explicit the physical mechanism by which the planet remains in its layer, drawing upon the earlier analogy of liquids and buoyancy (e.g., oil on water). While "s'arreste" indicates the cessation of movement, "floats" clarifies the specific state of being supported and suspended, which is implied by the context of density-differentiated layers but not explicitly stated by "s'arreste."

The French phrase "qui luy fait équilibre, & vous voyez bien qu'il n'est pas possible qu'elle en sorte jamais" (which brings it to equilibrium, and you see clearly that it is not possible it should ever leave it) presents two connected statements. The translation "and makes it of such equal poise, that it is not possible it should ever remove from thence" re-structures this by using the "such...that" construction. This explicitly frames the "equal poise" as the direct cause or sufficient condition leading to the impossibility of the planet moving, thereby spelling out the logical relationship more forcefully than the original's coordinating conjunction "&".

chunks.source_manual: <P067>Je conçois, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que ces pesanteurs-là reglent fort bien les rangs. Plust à Dieu qu'il y eust quelque chose de pareil qui les reglast parmi nous, & qui fixast les Gens dans les places qui leur sont naturellement convenables. Me voila fort en repos du costé de Jupiter. Je suis bien-aise qu'il nous laisse dans nostre petit Tourbillon <SC>avec nostre Lune unique</SC>. Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément, & je ne luy envie point les quatre qu'il a.</P067>
chunks.target_manual: <P063>I understand very well, said the Marchioness, that those weights do well regulate those lays, I wish to God we had some such Regulation among us, that might fix people in the places that are naturally fit for them. You see me now well satisfy'd as to Iupiter, and very well pleas'd that he will let us alone in our little Vortex with our one only Moon; for I am of a humour that easily confine my self, and do not envy him his four.</P063>
source_segments: quelque chose de pareil qui les reglast
explanations: The French phrase "quelque chose de pareil qui les reglast" (something similar that would regulate them) describes a hypothetical entity somewhat vaguely by its function and similarity. The English translation "some such Regulation" makes this entity more concrete and explicit by naming it a "Regulation". This transforms a descriptive clause about an unspecified "something" that regulates into a specific noun, adding a level of conceptual definiteness that was only implied in the original's more open phrasing.

The French "fort en repos" indicates a general state of being "very much at ease" or "calm" concerning Jupiter. The English translation "well satisfy'd" offers a more specific interpretation of this state. It makes explicit the implied reason for her calmness: that her intellectual curiosity or potential concerns about Jupiter have been successfully addressed by the philosopher's explanations. This spells out a cognitive and emotional resolution (satisfaction with the information received) which is only implied by the broader term "en repos" in the source text.

chunks.source_manual: <P068>Vous auriez tort de les luy envier, repris-je, il n'en a point plus qu'il ne luy en faut. Dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil, les Lunes ne reçoivent & ne luy renvoyent, qu'une lumiere assez faible. Il est vray que comme il tourne sur luy-mesme en dix heures, & que ses nuits, qui par consequent <IIM>n'en durent que cinq</IIM>, sont fort courtes, quatre Lunes ne paroîtroient pas si necessaires, mais il y a autre chose à considerer. Icy sous les Pôles, on a six mois de jour, & six mois de nuit. C'est que les Pôles sont les deux extremitez de la Terre les plus éloignées des lieux où le Soleil donne à plomb, & sur lesquels il paroit faire sa course. La Lune ne tient, ou paroist tenir la même route à peu prés que le Soleil, & si les Habitans des Pôles voyent le Soleil pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un an, & pendant toute l'autre moitié ne le voyent point, ils voyent aussi la Lune pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un mois, c'est à dire, pendant quinze jours, & ils ne la voyent point pendant toute l'autre moitié. <IIM>Les années de Jupiter</IIM> en valent douze des nostre, & il doit y avoir dans cette Planete deux extremitez opposées, où l'on ait des jours & des nuits de six ans entiers. <IIM>Des nuits</IIM> de six ans sont bien longues, aussi est ce principalement pour elles que je crois que les quatre Lunes sont faites. Celle qui à l'egard de Jupiter est la plus élevée, fait son cercle autour de luy en dix-sept jours, la seconde en sept, la troisiéme en trois jours & demy, la quatrième en quarante-deux heures. Leurs courses estant coupées justement par la moitié pour ces malheureux <UP></UP> Pays qui ont six ans de nuit, il ne se peut passer vingt & une heures, qu'on ne voye paroistre au moins la derniere Lune. C'est quelque consolation pendant des tenebres d'une durée si ennuyeuse; mais quelque lieu que l'on habite dans Jupiter, ces quatre Lunes vous y donnent les plus jolis Spectacles <UP></UP> du monde. Tantost elles se lèvent toutes quatre ensemble, & puis se separent selon l'inégalité de leur cours; tantost elles sont toutes à leur Midy rangées l'une au dessus de l'autre, tantost <RW>on les</RW> voit toutes quatre sur l'Horizon à des distances égales; tantost quand deux se levent, deux autres se couchent; sur tout j'aimerois à voir ce jeu perpetuel d'Eclipses qu'elles font, car il ne se passe point de jour qu'elles ne s'éclipsent les unes les autres, ou qu'elles n'éclipsent le Soleil, & asseurément les Eclipses s'estant renduës si familieres en ce Monde-là, elles y sont un sujet de divertissement, & non pas de frayeur, comme en celuy-ci.</P068> <P069><SC>Gens de nostre Lune</SC>, me fait douter que Jupiter en ait beaucoup sur le Habitans de siennes, & je croy qu'un des avantages ausquels ils puissent le plus raisonnablemént pretendre, c'est de leur faire peur. <UP>Par exemple, dans celle qui est la plus proche de luy, ils le voyent trois cents soixante fois plus gros que nostre Lune ne nous paroist, car il la surpasse autant en grosseur. Il est, je croy, beaucoup plus proche d'eux, qu'elle n'est de nous, sa grosseur en augmente encore. Ils fent comme des Colonies de Jupiter; qu'elles eussent receu de luy, s'il estoit possible, leurs Loix & leurs Coûtumes; que par consequent elles luy redissent quelque sorte d'hommage, & ne regardassent la grande Planete qu'avec respect. Ne faudroit-il point aussi, luy dis-je, que les quatre Lunes envoyassent de temps en temps des Députez dans Jupiter, pour luy prester ferment de fidelité? Pour moy, je vous avoüe que le peu de superiorité que nous avons sur les Gens.</UP></P069>
chunks.target_manual: <P064>You would do him wrong to envy him, says I, he has no more than he has need of, at the distance he is from the Sun his Moons receive and reflect upon him a very weak Light. 'Tis true that he turning about himself in ten hours, his nights, which continue but five, are very short, and it may seem that he has no necessity of four Moons; but there are other things to be consider'd, here under the Poles we have six months day and six night; for the Poles are the two extremities of the Earth farthest distant from those places through which the Sun seems to make his course. The Moon holds or seems to hold the same course very near that the Sun doth, and as the Inhabitants of the Pole see the Sun for one half of his annual course, and the other half see him not at all; so they likewise see the Moon during one half of her monthly course, that is, for fifteen days, and see her not the other fifteen. The years of Iupiter are twelve of ours, and there ought to be in that Planet two opposite extremities, where the days & nights are of six years continuance: Nights of six years are very long, therefore I believe it was for their sakes that those four Moons were design'd. That which in respect of Iupiter is the highest, makes its course round him in seventeen days, the second in seven, the third in three days and a half, and the fourth in forty hours; their courses being cut just in half for the unhappy <UP>people of that</UP> Country, who have six years night, they cannot pass one and twenty hours, without seeing at least the last of those Moons 'Tis a Consolation during a Darkness of so tedious a continuance: but in whatever place of Iupiter you inhabit, those four Moons will give you the most pleasant Spectacle in the World. Sometimes they rise all at once, and then separate themselves according to the inequality of their motions, sometimes they are all <RW>in their Meridian</RW> rang'd the one above the other, sometimes they appear all four above the Horizon at equal distances, sometimes when two of them rise, the other two set, but above all, I should delight to see their Eclipses, for there's not a day passes but they eclipse one another or eclipse the Sun, and certainly Eclipses being so familiar in that World, they are a great subject of Divertisement, and not of Fear as they are here.</P064>
target_segments: the unhappy people of that Country
explanations: The French 'ces malheureux Pays' (these unfortunate lands/countries) can refer to the geographical areas themselves or, through metonymy, their inhabitants. The translation 'the unhappy people of that Country' explicitly identifies 'people' as the experiencers of the long nights and the subject of unhappiness, clarifying information that was implied in the source.

The French 'six ans entiers' (six whole/entire years) emphasizes the completeness of the six-year period. The translation 'six years continuance' makes the implied concept of uninterrupted duration explicit by using the noun 'continuance', thereby foregrounding the aspect of the state lasting for the full duration, which is implied by 'entiers' but not directly stated as an abstract quality.

chunks.source_manual: <P070>Et vous ne manquerez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, à faire habiter ces quatre Lunes, quoy que ce ne foient que de petites Planetes subalternes, destinées seulement à en éclairer une autre pendant ces nuits? N'en doutez nullement, répondis-je. Ces Planetes n'en sont pas moins dignes d'estre habitées pour avoir le malheur d'estre asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante.</P070> <P071>Je voudrais donc, reprit-elle, que les Habitans des quatre Lunes de Jupiter <UP></UP>, fussont donc toûjours cette monstrueuse Planete suspédüe sur leurs testes à une distance assez petite. En verité, si les Gaulois craignaient anciennement que le Ciel ne tombast sur eux, les Habitans de cette Lune auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre une chute de Jupiter <UP></UP>. C'est peut-estre là aussi la frayeur qu'ils ont, dit- elle, au lieu de celle des Eclipses, dont vous m'avez asseuré qu'ils sont exempts, & qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise? Il le faut de necessité absolüe, répondis-je. L'Inventeur du troisième Systême dont je vous parlois l'autre jour, le celebre Ticho-Brahé <UP></UP>, un des plus grands Astronomes qui furent jamais, n'avoit garde de craindre les Eclipses, comme le Vulgaire les craint, il passoit sa vie avec elles. Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place? Si en sortant de son logis, la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit estoit une Vieille, si un Lievre traversoit son chemin, Ticho-Brahé croyoit que la journée devoit estre malheureuse, & retournoit promptement se renfermer chez luy, sans oser commencer la moindre chose.</P071>
chunks.target_manual: <P065>And you will not fail, said the Marchioness, to people those four Moons likewise, though they are but little subalternate Planets, design'd only to inlighten the nights of another. No doubt on't, said I, those Planets are not at all less worthy to be inhabited for being subjected to turn about another more important. I would then, says she, have it, that the Inhabitants of the four Moons of Iupiter, should be Colonies drawn from him, and that they should receive from him, if possible, their Laws and Customs, and consequently should render him some sort of Homage, and never look upon the great Planet without Respect. And must it not be likewise, said I, that the four Moons should from time to time send their Deputies to Iupiter, to make their Oath of Fidelity? for my part, I assure you that the little Superiority we have over the people of our Moon, makes me doubt whether Iupiter has much over the Inhabitants of his, and I believe the advantage he can most reasonably pretend to, is to frighten them; for example, in that which is nearest to him, he appears to them three hundred and sixty times bigger than our Moon appears to us; for he is so much bigger than she is: he is, I believe, nearer to them than she is to us, which still increases the bigness. They have then that monstrous Planet daily hanging over their heads at a very little distance, and truly if the Gauls of old were afraid the Heavens would fall upon them, the Inhabitants of that Moon have much more cause to fear the fall of Iupiter. That is, possibly, says she, the fear they have instead of that of Eclipses, which you tell me they are free from, but must pay for it by some other folly. That is of absolute necessity, said I; the Inventor of the third System, whom I told you of the other day, the famous Tycho Brahe, the greatest Astronomer that ever was, he fear'd not Eclipses as the vulgar do; <IIM>for his daily Conversation was with them</IIM>; but would you believe what he fear'd instead of them? When he went at any time out of his Lodging, if the first person he met were an old Woman, or if a Hare cross'd his way, he believ'd it would be an unlucky day to him, and would presently return and shut himself up, and not dare to take in hand the least matter.</P065>
source_segments: que les Habitans des quatre Lunes de Jupiter, fussont donc toûjours cette monstrueuse Planete suspédüe sur leurs testes à une distance assez petite.
Ces Planetes n'en sont pas moins dignes d'estre habitées pour avoir le malheur d'estre asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante.
target_segments: that the Inhabitants of the four Moons of Iupiter, should be Colonies drawn from him, and that they should receive from him, if possible, their Laws and Customs, and consequently should render him some sort of Homage, and never look upon the great Planet without Respect.

for example, in that which is nearest to him, he appears to them three hundred and sixty times bigger than our Moon appears to us; for he is so much bigger than she is: he is, I believe, nearer to them than she is to us, which still increases the bigness.

And must it not be likewise, said I, that the four Moons should from time to time send their Deputies to Iupiter, to make their Oath of Fidelity? for my part, I assure you that the little Superiority we have over the people of our Moon, makes me doubt whether Iupiter has much over the Inhabitants of his, and I believe the advantage he can most reasonably pretend to, is to frighten them;
explanations: The translator significantly alters the Marquise's expressed wish. In the source (P071), the Marquise wishes that the inhabitants of Jupiter's moons would always see 'cette monstrueuse Planete suspédüe sur leurs testes' (this monstrous Planet suspended over their heads). The target text replaces this with a detailed socio-political speculation attributed to the Marquise: that these inhabitants 'should be Colonies drawn from him,' receive 'Laws and Customs,' and 'render him some sort of Homage.' This addition explicitly spells out a colonial-style hierarchical relationship, drawing on the general implication of the moons being 'subalternes' and 'asservies' (from source P070), but re-writing the Marquise's specific dialogue to explore these unstated political dimensions.

The source text (P071) refers to Jupiter as 'cette monstrueuse Planete' (this monstrous Planet) as seen from its moons, implying its vast apparent size without providing details. The translator adds a new segment, spoken by the philosopher, which provides a specific scientific explication for this monstrosity: 'for example, in that which is nearest to him, he appears to them three hundred and sixty times bigger than our Moon appears to us; for he is so much bigger than she is: he is, I believe, nearer to them than she is to us, which still increases the bigness.' This addition makes the implicit notion of Jupiter's 'monstrous' appearance explicit by adding clarifying astronomical details and calculations not present in the original sentence.

The source text (P070) describes Jupiter's moons as 'asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante' (subjected to turn around another more important one), implying a power imbalance and hierarchical relationship. The translator introduces an entirely new speech for the philosopher that explicitly elaborates on the political and relational consequences of this subservience. The added lines about sending 'Deputies to Iupiter, to make their Oath of Fidelity' and the discussion about 'Superiority' spell out potential manifestations of the master-subject dynamic that Fontenelle left unstated, thus re-writing the dialogue to explore these themes of governance and fealty more overtly.

chunks.source_manual: <P072>Il ne seroit pas juste, <IIM>reprit-elle</IIM>, aprés que cet homme-là n'a pû se delivrer impunément de la crainte des Eclipses, que les Habitans de cette <UP></UP> Lune de Jupiter, dont nous parlions, en fussent quittes à meilleur marché. Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune <UP></UP>, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques momens. Si la Terre est si petite à l'égard de Jupiter, Jupiter nous voit-il? Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus.</P072>
chunks.target_manual: <P066>It would not be just, said she, since that Man could not deliver himself from the fear of Eclipses, without paying for it by some folly, that the Inhabitants of that Moon of Iupiter, which we speak of, should free themselves with less trouble, we'l give them no Quarter, they shall undergo the Common Law, and fall into some other Errour, but-how, I trouble not my head to guess. Therfore pray explain to me another difficulty has possess'd me within this little while, if the Earth be so little in respect of Iupiter, doth Iupiter see us? I fear we are unknown to him.</P066>
source_segments: mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner
target_segments: without paying for it by some folly
but-how, I trouble not my head to guess
explanations: The French adverb 'impunément' (with impunity, without punishment/consequence) is translated with the clause 'without paying for it by some folly.' The translator makes explicit the *nature* of the implied 'payment' or 'consequence' that is avoided if one acts 'impunément.' This addition of 'by some folly' specifies the negative outcome as falling into a new error, a clarification linked to Fontenelle's theme of replacing old superstitions with new ones, which is not directly lexicalized in the single adverb 'impunément.'

The French phrase 'mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner' (literally, 'but as I do not pride myself on being able to guess it [the error]') is rendered as 'but-how, I trouble not my head to guess.' The translator’s introduction of 'how' (in 'but-how') specifies the *aspect* of the error the Marquise is refraining from guessing—namely, the manner or details of its manifestation. The original French is more general ('guess it'), while the translation makes explicit this focus on the 'how,' altering the level of specificity.

chunks.source_manual: <P073>De bonne foy, je croy que cela est, répondis-je. Il faudroit qu'il vist la Terre quatre-vingt-dix fois plus petite que nous ne le voyons. C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point. Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous. Il y aura dans Jupiter des Astronomes, qui aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer des Lunettes excellentes, aprés avoir choisy les plus belles Nuits pour observer, auront enfin découvert dans les Cieux une petite Planete qu'ils n'avoyent jamais veüe. D'abord le <NCE>Journal des Sçavans</NCE> de ce Pays-là en parle; le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres-raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter. On observe encore, on revoit la petite Planete, on s'asseure bien que ce n'est point une vision, on commence même à soupçonner qu'elle a un mouvement autour du Soleil; on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce <RW>mouvement</RW> est d'une année; & enfin, grace à toutes les peines que se donnent les Sçavans, <NCP></NCP> on sçait dans Jupiter que nostre Terre est un Monde. Les Curieux vont la voir au bout d'une Lunette, & la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper.</P073>
chunks.target_manual: <P067>Truly, says I, I believe that, he must needs see the Earth ninety times less than we see him, that's too little, he sees it not all: But here's that which we may better believe for our advantage, there may be Astronomers in Iupiter, who having taken pains to make excellent Telescopes, and choosing the fairest nights for Observation, may at last have discover'd in the Heavens a little Planet which they never saw before, presently the Iournal des Scivans of that Country speaks of it; the people of Iupiter either hear nothing of it, or only laugh at it. The Philosophers, whose Opinions it destroys, are resolved not to believe it; none but the most reasonable doubt of it Observations are repeated, and the little Planet is reviewed; people are certain that 'tis no Vision, and begin to suspect that it moves about the Sun, after a thousand Observations 'tis discover'd that that motion is annual, and at last, thanks to the pains and studies of the Virtuoso's, 'tis known in Iupiter that our Earth is a World, the curious run to gaze on it with their Telescopes, and scarcely is it discernable.</P067>
explanations: The French "Lunettes" (from "composer des Lunettes excellentes"), while contextually implying telescopes when used by astronomers for celestial observation, is literally a more general term (e.g., 'glasses', 'lenses'). The translation uses the specific English term "Telescopes" (in "to make excellent Telescopes"), making the precise nature of the optical instrument explicit for the English reader, thereby removing potential ambiguity with ordinary spectacles or less specific viewing devices.

The French phrase "on s'asseure bien" (from "on s'asseure bien que ce n'est point une vision") describes the process of verification or making oneself sure. The English translation "people are certain" (in "people are certain that 'tis no Vision") makes the resulting state of conviction explicit, shifting the focus from the act of ascertaining to its definite outcome.

The French "les peines" (from "toutes les peines que se donnent les Sçavans"), meaning 'the efforts' or 'labors' of scholars, implies various activities inherent in scientific discovery. The translation "pains and studies" (in "the pains and studies of the Virtuoso's") makes the intellectual work of "studies" explicit, adding it to "pains" (efforts) to spell out a key component of the scholars' endeavors that was only implied by the broader term "peines" in the original.

The French "Lunette" (singular, from "au bout d'une Lunette"), used in the context of astronomical observation by "Les Curieux" (the curious ones, plural), refers to a telescope. The translation uses the specific term "Telescopes" (plural, in "with their Telescopes"), making the type of instrument explicit. The shift from a singular "Lunette" to plural "Telescopes," associated with the plural observers, also makes explicit the translator's interpretation that multiple such instruments are involved or possessed by the observers.

chunks.source_manual: <P074>Si ce n'estoit, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de sçavoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me representerois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nostres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considerent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce-là? Quelles Gens l'habitent?</P074>
chunks.target_manual: <P068>If it were not, said the Marchioness, that it is not very satisfactory to know that from Iupiter they cannot discover us without a Telescope. I should take pleasure in representing to my self those Telescopes of Iupiter planted toward us as ours are to behold him, and that mutual curiosity of the two Planets in considering one another, and asking What World is this? What People inhabit here?</P068>
source_segments: comme les nostres le sont vers luy
target_segments: as ours are to behold him
explanations: The French term 'Lunettes d'approche' (literally 'approach glasses' or spyglasses) is a somewhat general term for magnifying optical instruments. While in the astronomical context of observing Jupiter, it strongly implies a telescope, the English translation 'a Telescope' explicitly names the specific, more advanced instrument, removing potential ambiguity and specifying the nature of the 'lunettes' as astronomical viewing devices suitable for interplanetary observation.

The French phrase 'comme les nostres le sont vers luy' literally translates to 'as ours are towards him'. This implies that 'our' instruments are directed towards Jupiter for observation. The English translation 'as ours are to behold him' makes the purpose of this direction explicit by adding the infinitive phrase 'to behold him,' spelling out the action of observation which was only implied in the source text by the context of using optical instruments.

The French 'les Planetes' (the Planets) in this context implicitly refers to Earth and Jupiter, which are the two celestial bodies being discussed in terms of mutual observation. The English translation 'the two Planets' makes this specific reference explicit by adding the quantifier 'two,' thereby clarifying for the reader that the 'mutual curiosity' is specifically between Earth and Jupiter, information that the reader of the original would infer from context but is not overtly stated in the phrase 'les Planetes'.

chunks.source_manual: <P075><IIM>Cela ne va pas si viste que vous pensez</IIM>, repliquay-je. Quand on verroit nostre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoistroit, nostre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse estre habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sçait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-estre mesme sommes-nous cause qu'on y <UP>a fait le procés</UP> à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous estions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, asseurément <UP>leurs Cristophles Colombs ne sçauroient manquer d'employ</UP>. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, <NCP>qui est fort petit</NCP>, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne <RW>avec les siennes</RW>. Voila assez de Planetes pour embarasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.</P075>
chunks.target_manual: <P069>Hold, said I, that's not so soon done as you imagine: should the Inhabitants of Iupiter see our Earth, and know it, yet our Earth is not our selves; there would not be the least suspicion that 'tis inhabited: and should any one chance to entertain such a thought, God knows how the whole World of Iupiter would mock him. Nay possibly we have already been the cause of arraigning some of their Philosophers for holding that we have a Being in Nature. In the mean time I rather believe, that the Inhabitants of Iupiter have imployment enough in making discoveries in their own Planet, without ever dreaming of us; it is so big, that if they have the Art of Navigation, their Christopher Columba's have most certainly imployment enough. It must needs be that the people of that World do not know the hundredth part of it; whereas in Mercury, which is very little, they are all Neighbours, live very familiarly together, and count it but a Walk, to make a turn about their World. If they do not see us from Iupiter, you will easily judge that the people of that Planet do much less see Venus and Mercury, which are both lesser Worlds, and more distant from him. But to make amends, his inhabitants see Mars, and their own four Moons, and Saturn with his. These are Planets enough to perplex their Astronomers, and Nature has been so kind to conceal the rest of the Universe from them.</P069>
target_segments: that we have a Being in Nature
if they have the Art of Navigation
explanations: The French "repliquay-je" (I replied) is a neutral reporting of speech. The translator’s addition of "Hold," (not present in the source) before "said I" explicitly conveys a tone of immediate caution or interruption by the philosopher, a nuance that was only implied by the subsequent content of his French reply ("Cela ne va pas si viste").

The French indefinite pronoun "on" (from "Quand on verroit nostre Terre") is rendered specifically as "the Inhabitants of Iupiter" (from "should the Inhabitants of Iupiter see our Earth"). This translation makes explicit the agent performing the action, which was only generally implied by "on" in the French text.

The French indefinite pronoun "on" (from "quand on l'y connoistroit") is effectively translated as "the Inhabitants of Iupiter" (acting as the elided subject of "know it", carried over from "should the Inhabitants of Iupiter see..."). This explicitation clarifies that the same specific agents previously identified are performing the action, whereas "on" in French remains general.

The French "tout Jupiter" (all of Jupiter) could ambiguously refer to the planet itself or its populace. The translation "the whole World of Iupiter" explicitly clarifies the reference is to the collective society or inhabitants of Jupiter, making an implied meaning in the source explicit.

The concise French "que nous estions" (that we existed/were) is expanded in the translation to "that we have a Being in Nature." The addition of "in Nature" makes explicit a philosophical or natural philosophy framing for the concept of existence, a layer of meaning not directly expressed in the simpler French phrase.

The French "s'ils navigent" (if they navigate) refers to the act of navigation. The translation "if they have the Art of Navigation" expands this by making explicit the underlying requirement of possessing a developed skill, system, or established practice ("Art") for navigation, which was only implied in the original verb.

The French indefinite pronoun "on" (from "Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter") is translated as "they" (from "If they do not see us from Iupiter"). In the English rendering, "they" clearly refers back to "the Inhabitants of Iupiter" (as established by the translator earlier in the same paragraph), thus making the agent explicitly specific, whereas the French "on" could allow for a more general interpretation.

The French indefinite pronoun "on" (from "qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure") is translated as "the people of that Planet" (from "that the people of that Planet do much less see Venus and Mercury"). This explicitly identifies the viewers as the inhabitants of Jupiter, removing the generality of "on" and specifying the agent directly.

The French "leurs quatre Lunes" (their four Moons) indicates possession. The addition of "own" in the English translation "their own four Moons" explicitly emphasizes this possessive relationship between Jupiter and its moons, making the connection more emphatic than in the original.
