chunks.source_manual: <P076>Quoy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous comptez cela pour une grace? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand <RW>Tourbillon</RW> seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres, qui avoient esté cachees; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.</P076>
chunks.target_manual: <P070>How, said the Marchioness, do you count that a kindness? Without doubt it is, said I, there are in all this great Vortex sixteen Planets. Nature, who would save us the trouble of studying all their motions, has let us see but seven of them, is not that a great kindness? But we, who know not how to value it, have taken a course to find out the other nine that were conceal'd, and are punish'd for our pains by the great labour that Astronomy at present requires.</P070>
explanations: The French "Sans doute," an elliptical affirmation meaning "Without a doubt," is expanded in the English translation to "Without doubt it is." The addition of "it is" explicitly completes the philosopher's affirmation, linking it directly to the Marquise's question about whether "cela" (that) is counted "pour une grace" (as a kindness). While "Without doubt" alone is a possible translation, "Without doubt it is" spells out the implied predicate, making the connection more explicit than the concise French.

The French "nous faisons si bien que" (literally "we do so well that" or "we manage so that") suggests effective action leading to the discovery of the other planets. The English translation "have taken a course to" re-writes this by explicitly introducing the idea of a deliberate method or process ("taken a course"). This adds clarifying information about the *manner* in which the discovery was achieved, which was only implied by the efficacy in the French.

In the French "aussi en sommes-nous punis," the pronominal adverb "en" serves as a general anaphoric reference, meaning "for it" or "as a result of it," implicitly linking the punishment to their act of finding the hidden planets or their general over-curiosity. The English translation "and are punish'd for our pains" makes this implicit cause explicit by specifying "for our pains," thus clearly stating that the punishment is a direct consequence of the efforts and troubles they expended in their astronomical pursuits.

chunks.source_manual: <P077>Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, repliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraischement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nostres, & que par consequent il a <IIM>des Pays</IIM>, où une seule nuit dure des quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui estant assez élevé pour estre hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil <RW>dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point</RW>.</P077>
chunks.target_manual: <P071>I find, says she, by that number of sixteen Planets, that Saturn ought to have five Moons. He has so, says I, and of those five, two are but lately discovered; but there is a thing yet much more remarkable, one of his years being thirty of ours, and by consequence there being Countreys in him, whose night is of fifteen years continuance, guess you what Nature has invented to inlighten such terrible nights. She was not satisfy'd with bestowing five Moons upon Saturn, but she has also inclos'd him with a great Circle or Ring, which is high enough raised to be out of the Shadow of the Body of that Planet, and continually reflects the Light of the Sun upon those places that do not see him.</P071>
explanations: The French "bien fraischement découvertes" (very freshly/recently discovered) emphasizes the high degree of recency of the discovery. The English translation "but lately discovered" (meaning "only recently discovered") makes explicit the limiting aspect of this recency – that the discovery occurred *only* in the recent past and not at any earlier time. This shift from emphasizing the intensity of newness ("very") to the exclusivity of newness ("only") serves to spell out more sharply the novelty of the scientific information being presented.

The French "il a des Pays" (literally "he [Saturn] has countries") uses personification for the planet Saturn and implies that these countries are located on its surface. The English translation "Countreys in him" makes the location of these countries (i.e., on or as part of the planet Saturn) explicit by using the prepositional phrase "in him." This phrasing spells out the spatial relationship more directly than the French possessive construction "il a," subtly altering Fontenelle's personification by providing a more direct, physical description of the planet's features.

The French phrase "des quinze ans entiers" (fifteen whole years), describing the duration of a night on Saturn, uses the adjective "entiers" (whole, entire, complete) to emphasize the fullness of this 15-year period. The English translation "of fifteen years continuance" rephrases this by using the noun "continuance." This explicitly spells out the uninterrupted, continuous *state* or *nature* of this extraordinarily long night. The term "continuance" adds a layer of formal definition to the duration that is implied by "entiers" but made more prominent and specific in the translation, likely to enhance the reader's grasp of such a remarkable astronomical phenomenon.

chunks.source_manual: <P078>En verité, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <IIM>de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-mesme avec étonnement</IIM>, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroist bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Estres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas esté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'estoit pas la peine d'en donner à Venus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mesmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a <IIM>point de Lune</IIM>. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne sçavons pas. Vous avez veu des <SC>Phosphores</SC>, de ces matieres liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. <SC>Peut-estre Mars a-t-il</SC> de grands Rochers fort élevéz, qui sont des <SC>Phosphores</SC> naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumiere qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sçauriez nier que ce ne fust un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'alumer de toutes parts dés que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous sçavez encore qu'il y a en Amerique des Oyseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que sçavons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oyseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous costéz, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?</P078>
chunks.target_manual: <P072>Seriously and truly, says the Marchioness, with an Air of one astonish'd, all this is a work of great Order, it is very visible that Nature had in her eye the Necessities of every living Being, and that the Distribution of Moons was not a thing done at random. There's none share in it but the Planets farthest distant from the Sun, viz. the Earth, Iupiter and Saturn; for it was not worth the while to give them to Venus and Mercury, who receive but too much Light, whose Nights are short, and which they esteem a much greater benefit of Nature than their Days.</P072> <P073>But stay, says she, methinks Mars, who is father remov'd from the Sun than the Earth is, has no Moon. It cannot be deny'd, said I, he has none, and therefore he must have some other refuge in his nights than we know of. You have seen those Phosphores, of either dry or liquid matter, which receiving the Light of the Sun, imbibe it, and diffusing it in the dark, give a considerable light. Perhaps Mars has great Rocks high rais'd, which are natural Phosphores, and which in the day time make a provision of Light, which they disburse in the night. You cannot deny that it would be a delightful spectacle to see all those Rocks lighted at Sunset, and make magnificent Illuminations without any Art. You know likewise that there are in America certain Birds so luminous, that they give light enough to read by in the dark. How do we know but Mars has a great many of those Birds, which at nightfall disperse themselves every where, and create a new day?</P073>
source_segments: tout cela est d'un grand ordre
à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne
qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire
target_segments: all this is a work of great Order
viz. the Earth, Iupiter and Saturn
that they give light enough to read by
explanations: The French "En verité" (In truth, Indeed) is translated as "Seriously and truly." The addition of "Seriously" explicitly emphasizes the gravity and deep reflection in the Marquise's tone. While "En verité" conveys truthfulness, "Seriously" spells out an intensity of thought and earnestness implied by the context (her astonishment and reflection), making it more overt in the dialogue itself through this expansion.

The French "tout cela est d'un grand ordre" (literally, 'all this is of a great order', meaning it is characterized by great order) is translated as "all this is a work of great Order." The addition of "a work of" explicitly frames the "Order" as the result of a deliberate creative process or agency (implied to be Nature's), rather than simply a characteristic or state of being. This clarifies information about the origin of the observed order that was only implied in the original.

The source text lists specific planets, "à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne", as appositives to "Planetes éloignées du Soleil". The English translation introduces this list with "viz." (an abbreviation for videlicet, meaning "namely" or "that is to say"), as in "viz. the Earth, Iupiter and Saturn". This insertion explicitly signals that the listed planets are an enumeration or precise specification of the previously mentioned "Planets farthest distant from the Sun" that received moons. This connective relationship was implicit in the French apposition but is spelled out in English.

The French "des ressources" (resources, means), in the phrase "des ressources que nous ne sçavons pas" (resources that we do not know of), is rendered in the target text using the more specific noun "refuge" (within the phrase "some other refuge in his nights"). "Refuge" explicitly frames these unknown means as something providing protection, shelter, or a solution against the darkness or other adversities of night. This specific function was implied by the context ("pour ses nuits" - for its nights) but not directly stated by the general term "ressources."

The French "qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire" states that one can use the luminous birds to read. The English translation, "that they give light enough to read by," makes explicit the *enabling condition*: the birds provide sufficient illumination for reading. The French implies this sufficiency, but the English spells out that the quantity or quality of light ("enough light") is the reason they can be used for reading.

The French "vont répandre un nouveau jour" (literally "go to spread a new day") describes the birds' effect. The translation "create a new day" makes the transformative impact of the birds' light more explicit and definitive. While "répandre" (to spread, diffuse) suggests distribution, "create" emphasizes the act of bringing this "new day" into existence, highlighting a more powerful and originating agency for the birds which was more nuanced in the original phrasing.

chunks.source_manual: <P079>Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oyseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'estre joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse esté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fust point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vrayment, repliquay-je, si <LS><IIM>vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites</IIM></LS>, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de mesme pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous estions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos testes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horison, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroist une habitation trop irreguliere. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'estoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échapées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez miserables. Il leur donne de la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans la Groënlande, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.</P079> <P080>Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, au lieu que tantost vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, repliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extremitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.</P080>
chunks.target_manual: <P074>I am not satisfy'd, says she, neither with your Rocks nor your Birds; not but that it may be very pretty; but since Nature has given so many Moons to Saturn and Iupiter, 'tis a sign there is occasion for them. I should have been glad that all the Worlds far distant from the Sun had them likewise, but Mars I find makes a disagreeable exception. Ah! says I, <LS>if you look'd more into Philosophy than you do </LS>, you would accustom your self to find exceptions in the best Systems. There is ever something that agrees very well, and something that we make agree as well as we can, or else we let it alone, if we despair of succeeding well in it. Let us deal so with Mars: since he doth not favour us, let us e'en say no more of him. We should be sufficiently astonished if we were in Saturn, to see over our heads in the night that great Ring, which moving in form of a Semicircle from one end of the Horizon to the other, reflects the Light of the Sun, and performs the office of a perpetual Moon. And, says the Marchioness, laughing, must we not likewise have Inhabitants in that great Ring? Truly said I, however I may be bold enough to plant them every where else, I must confess, I dare not place any there, that Ring seems a habitation too irregular. But as for the five little Moons, I think we cannot well dispense with peopling them; if in the mean time that Ring be, as some suspect, no more than a circle of Moons that follow one another very close with an equal motion, and that the five little Moons are such as have made their escape from the great Circle, what an infinity of Worlds shall we have in that Vortex of Saturn? however it be, the people of Saturn, with all the help of that Ring, are miserable enough. It gives them light, but what sort of a light at that distance from the Sun? the Sun it self is to them but a small Star, pale and wan, and has only a little glittering and a feeble heat. Were they brought into the coldest of our Countrys, as Groenland or Lapland, you would see them melt and expire with heat. You give me, says the Marchioness, an Idea of Saturn that freezes me, as just now you heated me in your discourse of Mercury. It must needs be, says I, that two Worlds that are in the extermities of this great Vortex, should be opposite in all things.</P074>
source_segments: Mars ne nous fust point venu faire
explanations: The French "qu'il faut des Lunes" (that moons are needed/necessary) is rendered as "'tis a sign there is occasion for them." The English phrase "occasion for them" explicitly points to a purpose or specific need for the moons, whereas the French "il faut" is more general about the necessity. The translation spells out the implicit idea that the necessity arises from a particular "occasion" or functional requirement.

The French phrase "Mars ne nous fust point venu faire [une exception]" (Mars had not come to make [an exception] for us) implies a dawning realization or a situation that has become apparent. The English translation "Mars I find makes [a disagreeable exception]" makes this subjective realization or discovery explicit by adding "I find," highlighting the speaker's process of observation or conclusion which was only implied in the French.

The French idiom "d'en pouvoir venir à bout" (to be able to overcome it/get through it/manage it) is translated as "of succeeding well in it." The English phrase "succeeding well in it" explicitly clarifies the desired positive outcome (success) and the quality of that success ("well"), which is implied but not as specifically stated by the more general French expression.

The French "qui iroit" (which would go/travel), referring to Saturn's ring, implies movement across the sky. The English translation "which moving" makes this movement explicit by adding the present participle "moving," clarifying the dynamic visual appearance of the ring.

The French "feroit l'effet" (would produce the effect) is translated as "performs the office." The English phrase "performs the office" explicitly spells out the *function* or role of Saturn's ring (acting as a moon), which is more generally implied by the French phrase about producing an effect.

The French "Lune continuë" (continuous Moon) is translated as "perpetual Moon." The English "perpetual" expands on "continuous" by emphasizing an unceasing and everlasting nature, making the intended quality of the moon's constant presence more explicit and stronger.

The French "en envoyer" (to send some [referring to inhabitants]), in the context of populating worlds, is translated as "to plant them." The verb "plant" explicitly denotes the act of establishing inhabitants, akin to planting a colony, making the specific nature of "sending" more vivid and concrete, a meaning that was implied by the general verb "envoyer" in this context.

The French exclamation "que de Mondes!" (so many worlds! / what a lot of worlds!) expresses wonder at a large, unspecified number. The English "what an infinity of Worlds" makes this vastness explicit by using the term "infinity," thereby specifying the implicit idea of an extremely large, almost uncountable number of worlds.

The French rhetorical question/exclamation "quelle lumiere!" (what light! or what kind of light!) implies a query about the nature or quality of the light. The English "what sort of a light" makes this questioning of the light's characteristics explicit by adding "sort of a," directly focusing on the type or quality being discussed.

The French phrase "en me parlant de Mercure" (in speaking to me of Mercury / while speaking to me of Mercury) describes the action generally. The English translation "in your discourse of Mercury" makes explicit the formal or structured nature of the conversation by using "discourse," suggesting a more deliberate and extended talk, which aligns with the philosophical dialogue style of the book.

chunks.source_manual: <P081>Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde estoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne sçavent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique <IIM>trop badin & trop folâtre</IIM>. <NCE></NCE>.</P081> <P082>Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lens. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nostre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extremitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractere fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différens. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'estre icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.</P082>
chunks.target_manual: <P075>So then, says she, they must be wise in Saturn; for you told me, they are all fools in Mercury. If they are not wise in Saturn, said I, they are, at least in all appearance `very flegmatick: they are people that know not what it is to laugh, that require a whole day to answer to the least Question, and would look upon Cato of Vitica as a Buffoon or a Jack-pudding. I have a thought in my head, says she; all the Inhabitants of Mercury are lively, and all those of Saturn are dull; among us some are lively and some are dull, doth not this proceed from hence, that we being just in the middle between those other Worlds, participate of the extremities? There is no fixed and determinate Character for Man, some are fram'd like the Inhabitants of Mercury, others like those of Saturn, and we are a mixture of all species that are in the other Planets. I like that idea, said I, well enough, we make up so odd a kind of likeness, that it may be thought we are a Collection out of several different Worlds; and therefore 'tis convenient enough to be here, where we see all the other Worlds in compendium.</P075>
source_segments: on est bien sage dans Saturne
target_segments: they must be wise in Saturn
explanations: The French "on est bien sage dans Saturne" (one is/they are very wise in Saturn) presents the Marquise's conclusion as a statement of fact, although its inferential nature is implied by the preceding "Ainsi" (So/Thus) and the following "car" (for/because). The English translation "they must be wise in Saturn" makes this implicit logical deduction explicit by using the modal verb "must", directly encoding the inferential step into the main verb phrase rather than relying solely on contextual cues.

The French adjectival phrase "trop badin & trop folâtre" describes Cato as being perceived by Saturnians as possessing qualities of being 'too playful/jesting and too frolicsome/playful'. The English translation replaces these general qualities with "a Buffoon or a Jack-pudding," which are nouns referring to specific, culturally recognizable comic character types (particularly "Jack-pudding," a stock character in 17th-18th century England). This explicitation clarifies the *implied type* of unseriousness by providing concrete examples familiar to the target audience, thereby adding a layer of cultural specificity and vividness not directly present in the original's more abstract description.

chunks.source_manual: <P083>Du moins, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nostre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grace à la Nature d'estre Homme, & non pas Beste, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moy je veux luy rendre grace d'estre sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grace d'estre jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & <UP></UP> belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vostre Tourbillon, ou de la temperature de vostre Pays.</P083>
chunks.target_manual: <P076>At least, said the Marchioness, our World has one real convenience by the Scituation, that it is neither so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Iupiter or Saturn; and moreover we are seated just in a part of the Earth where we find excess neither of Heat nor Cold. Seriously, if a certain Philosopher gave thanks to Nature for making him a Man and not a Beast, a Greek and not a Barbarian, I for my share give her thanks for placing me in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in the most temperate place of that Planet. Believe me, Madam, said I, you may give her thanks that you are young and not old, young and fair, and not young and ugly; a young and fair French-woman, and not a young and fair Italian: these are things to be acknowledg'd as advantages as well as those you receive by the Scituation of your Vortex and the Temperature of your Countrey.</P076>
source_segments: d'estre sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers
target_segments: for placing me in the most temperate Planet of the Universe
things to be acknowledg'd as advantages
explanations: The French phrase "d'estre Homme" (of being a Man), in the context of "rendoit grace à la Nature d'estre Homme" (gave thanks to Nature for being a Man), implies Nature's responsibility for this state. The English translation "for making him a Man" makes Nature's active role or agency in bringing about this state explicit through the use of the verb "making."

The French phrase "d'estre sur la Planete" (of being on the Planet), in the context of giving thanks to Nature, implies Nature's role in this positioning. The English translation "for placing me in the...Planet" makes Nature's agency in actively situating the person on the planet explicit through the use of the verb "placing."

The French "sujets de reconnoissance" (subjects/reasons for gratitude/acknowledgment) is translated as "things to be acknowledg'd as advantages". The translator makes explicit the *nature* of these subjects of gratitude by specifying they are "advantages." While the act of being grateful for something implies it has a positive quality, the English translation spells out this quality ("advantages") which was only implied in the original French.

chunks.source_manual: <P084>Mon Dieu! repliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a esté donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considerables, un goust qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, repliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles Fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez veu jusqu'icy.</P084>
chunks.target_manual: <P077>Good God! said the Marchioness, let me acknowledge all, even to the Vortex where I am plac'd, the proportion of Happiness that has been measur'd out to us is very small, and we ought to be chary of it and lose none, and it is good to entertain such a relish and sense of even the most common and inconsiderable things, as may render them useful to us. If we desire only lively pleasures, we shall have few, stay long and pay dear for them. You will promise me then, said I, if I propose lively pleasures to you, you will remember me and my Vortices, and will be of our side. I will, said she, but you must provide that Philosophy still supply me with new pleasures. At least, said I, to morrow, I hope, you shall not fail of them. I have fixed Stars that will go beyond all that you have seen yet.</P077>
target_segments: we ought to be chary of it and lose none
explanations: The French "donnée" (given), in the context of "La mesure de bonheur qui nous a esté donnée" (The measure of happiness that has been given to us), is translated as "measur'd out". While "given" is general, "measur'd out" explicitly adds the information that the happiness was dispensed or allocated in a specific, determined, and possibly limited quantity, a nuance that is implied by "mesure" but not directly stated by "donnée" itself.

The French "il n'en faut rien perdre" (literally, "it is necessary to lose nothing of it") is an injunction to preserve happiness. The English translation "we ought to be chary of it and lose none" adds the phrase "be chary of it." This addition makes explicit the careful, frugal, or wary manner in which happiness should be preserved, a mode of action that is only implicitly suggested by the strong injunction in French to "lose none."

The French "un goust" (a taste, liking, inclination) is rendered as "a relish and sense." The translator expands this single noun by adding "and sense," thereby making explicit the idea that the "goust" for common things, in the context of "qui les mette à profit" (that puts them to use/profit), involves not only an emotional appreciation ("relish") but also a cognitive understanding or perception ("sense") of their value. This spells out a dual nature of "goust" that was implicit.

The French "vous vous borneriez à nous" (you would limit/confine yourself to us) suggests an exclusive commitment to the philosopher and his ideas. The English translation "will be of our side" rephrases this by making explicit the implied consequence of such limitation: actively taking a stance or siding with "us" (the philosopher and his Vortices) in the implied choice against other "lively pleasures." It spells out a relationship of allegiance or solidarity that was unstated but implied by "se borner à" (to limit oneself to).

chunks.source_manual: <P085>CINQUIEME SOIR.</P085>
chunks.target_manual: <P078>THE Fifth Evening.</P078>
explanations: The French heading 'CINQUIEME SOIR.' (Fifth Evening.) does not use a definite article, with definiteness being implied by the ordinal number and the sequential context of the work. The English translation 'THE Fifth Evening.' makes this implied definiteness explicit by adding the definite article 'THE'. While common in English for such headings, this addition explicitly marks a grammatical feature (definiteness) that is only implicitly present in the French phrasing, potentially giving the heading a slightly more formal or substantial feel than the unadorned French original.

chunks.source_manual: <P086><UP></UP>. La <IIM>Marquise</IIM> sentit une vraye impatience de sçavoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes, me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-estre, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sçauroient estre moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuës, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est rien par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumiere, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM> <UP></UP>; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumiere qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM>, eust cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.</P086>
chunks.target_manual: <P079>THe Marchioness was sensibly impatient to know what would become of the fixed Stars. Shall they be inhabited, says she, as the Planets are, or shall they not? or what shall we do with them? Perhaps, said I, you might guess, if you would; the fixed Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than some fifty millions of Leagues, and if you vex an Astronomer, he'l put them a great way further. The distance of the Sun from the most distant Planet, is nothing in comparison of the distance of the Sun or of the Earth from the fixed Stars, men do not take the pains to compute it. Their Light, as you see, is bright and lively enough. If they receive it from the Sun, they must needs receive it in a weak condition after a passage of fifty millions of Leagues, and they must return it to us through the same distance by a Reflection, that must yet much more impair the strength of it. It may seem impossible that a Light that is made by Reflection, and has travail'd twice fifty millions of Leagues, should retain that force and vivacity which we find in the fixed Stars. You see then they are all luminous in themselves, and in a word, are so many Suns.</P079>
explanations: The French 'encore plus loin' (even further/still further) indicates an additional, unspecified degree of distance. The English translation 'a great way further' makes explicit the qualitative assessment that this additional distance is substantial ('a great way'), adding a layer of semantic detail about the magnitude that was only implied in the French.

The French indefinite pronoun 'on' (one/they/people) in the phrase 'on ne prend pas la peine de la compter' is translated as 'men' in 'men do not take the pains to compute it'. While 'on' can refer to scientists (who were predominantly men in that era), its usage here is general and impersonal. The translation specifies the agent as 'men', making an implicit contextual assumption about the actors explicit within the text, and narrowing the broader, more abstract scope of the original 'on'.

The French verb 'l'affoibliroit' (would weaken it [the light]) from 'qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup' implies a reduction in the light's qualities. The English translation 'impair the strength of it' from 'that must yet much more impair the strength of it' explicitly specifies that it is 'the strength' of the light that is diminished. This spells out the particular aspect affected by the weakening, which is implicit in the more general French verb 'affaiblir' (to weaken).

The French presentative phrase 'Les voila donc' (So there they are / And so they are) in 'Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes' indicates that a conclusion is now apparent. The English translation 'You see then' in 'You see then they are all luminous in themselves' explicitly attributes the act of perception or understanding of this conclusion to the interlocutor (the Marquise, and by extension the reader). This makes the cognitive process of the listener/reader explicit, which was only implied by the presentational nature of 'voila' in the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P087>Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nostre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Nostre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis-je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé. <UP></UP>.</P087>
chunks.target_manual: <P080>I am not out of the way, cry'd the Marchioness, whether I go, or whether you lead me, you are going to tell me, That the fixed Stars are so many Suns, our Sun is the Center of a Vortex that turns about him, why should not every fixed Star be the Center of a Vortex that has likewise a motion about it? Our Sun has Planets which it inlightens, why should not every fixed Star have the like? I have no Answer, said I, but that of Phedra to Enone, 'Tis you have said it.</P080>
source_segments: ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener?
target_segments: whether I go, or whether you lead me,
explanations: The French phrase "ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener?" literally translates to "or if I see where you want to lead me?" This primarily focuses on the Marquise's perception of the philosopher's intended conversational direction, emphasizing his role in leading. The English translation "whether I go, or whether you lead me," makes explicit two distinct potential sources or modes of her understanding: her own independent deduction or arrival at the point ("whether I go"), or the philosopher's explicit guidance ("or whether you lead me"). This addition of her potential independent agency ("I go") spells out a distinction that is only implicitly suggested in the original, which centers more on her discerning his guidance.

chunks.source_manual: <P088>Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sçais plus où je suis, <RW>je ne suis plus rien</RW>. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-estre aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes? Tout cet espace immense qui comprend nostre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes? <UP></UP>. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moy, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le Ciel n'estoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles estoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte <UP></UP>, en la partageant en mille & mille <RW>Tourbillons</RW>, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & asseurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous costez les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde.<UP></UP>.</P088>
chunks.target_manual: <P081>But, says she, why there's the Universe so big that I am lost in it, I know not where I am, I'm nothing. What, shall all be divided into Vortices confusedly thrown one among another? Shall evero Star be the Center of a Vortex as big perhaps as that wherein we are? Shall all the immense space that comprehends our Sun and our Planets be no more than a little Spot of the Universe? This confounds, perplexes and astonishes me. And, said I, for my share, I am wholly at ease. Were Heaven no more than that blue Vault where the Stars are nail'd, the Universe would seem small and narrow to me, and I should find my self straighten'd and oppress'd. But now that this Vault is of infinite more extent and profundity, in dividing it into a thousand thousand Vortices, methinks I breath with more liberty, and am in a more open Air; and most assuredly the Universe has wholly another Magnificence. Nature spar'd nothing in making it, but made a profusion of her Riches wholly worthy of her. Nothing can be represented so beautiful as that prodigious number of Vortices in the Center whereof is seated the Sun turning the Planets about him. The Inhabitants of a Planet of one of those infinite Vortices, see on all sides the luminous centers of those Vortices which surround them, but they see not the Planets, which having but a feeble light borrowed from their Sun, do not propagate it beyond their World.</P081>
explanations: The French "Et moy," meaning "And I" or "As for me," is rendered in a way that includes "for my share" when introducing the philosopher's contrasting viewpoint. This addition explicitly frames the philosopher's subsequent statement ("cela me met à mon aise" / "I am wholly at ease") as his personal stake or specific part in the discussion, thereby spelling out the contrast with the Marquise's feelings more emphatically than the simpler "Et moy" implies.

The French "un plus grand air" literally translates to "a bigger air" or "a greater air," but idiomatically, in this context, it implies a sense of vastness and freedom, akin to "open air." The translation "a more open Air" makes this implied quality of unrestrictedness and spaciousness explicit, clarifying the specific characteristic of the "grand air" that provides comfort to the philosopher.

The French "ne la poussent point" (literally "do not push it at all"), referring to light from distant planets, uses the general verb "pousser" (to push, extend). The English translation uses "do not propagate it." "Propagate" is a more technical and precise term specific to the transmission of light (and other waves). This explicitation clarifies the implied scientific mechanism of light's travel by using a more specific scientific term, thereby enhancing the clarity of the scientific explanation for the English reader, in line with the work's popular science genre.

chunks.source_manual: <P089>Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de nostre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; apres eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les apperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous estes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis? <IIM>Nous mesmes, à qui la mesme expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sçauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes</IIM>. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. <IIM>Asseurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoist pas les Tourbillons</IIM>. <UP></UP>. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondray: Ah! si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas sceu, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'estoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fust dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eust-elle échappé à Aristote?) <UP></UP> mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eust esté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eust pas pû conquerir. A plus forte raison luy eust-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eust connus en ce temps-là; c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon vostre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.</P089>
chunks.target_manual: <P082>You offer me, said she, a kind of Perspective so long, that my eye cannot reach the end of it. I clearly see the Inhabitants of the Earth, and afterward you shew me those of the Moon and the other Planets of our Vortex, truly clearly enough, but less than those of the Earth, and after them come the Inhabitants of the Planets of other Vortices. I protest to you they are wholly drown'd, and with all that I can do to see them, they are still almost wholly indiscernable. And in effect, are they not almost annihilated by the expression you are fain to make use of in speaking of them, you are fain to call them the Inhabitants of one of the Planets of one of those infinite Vortices. <IIM>You must confess that you hardly know how to disingage us our selves, to whom the same expression agrees, from the midst of so many Worlds</IIM>. For my share, I begin to see the Earth so fearfully little, that from hence forward I shall have no value for any thing in it. <IIM>Certainly men are so earnest in the pursuit of Greatness, form Design upon Design, and turmoile themselves so much, only because they are ignorant of these Vortices</IIM>. These new Lights I intend shall apologize for me; and when any blame me for an unactive negligence, my Answer shall be, Ah! if you did but know what the fixed Stars are! Alexander, says, I, certainly knew nothing of them; for a certain Author, who holds that the Moon is inhabited, says seriously, that it was not possible that Aristotle should not be of an opinion so reasonable (for how could a Truth escape Aristotle?) but that he would say nothing of it for fear of displeasing Alexander, who would have fallen into despair to have seen a World that he could not conquer. The truth is, should any one have made a Mystery of the Vortices and fixed Stars, had they been known in those days, it had been an ill Complement to have told him of them. I my self, that know them, am not a little concern'd that I can make no profit by the Knowledge. They at best, in your opinion, cure only an unquiet and ambitious mind, which I am not troubl'd with; a little foolish inclination for the thing that's fair, is all my malady, and I doubt the Vortices can do me little kindness in that. The other Worlds, you say, make this seem little to you, but yet they obscure not the Lustre of your Eyes, nor spoil that pretty Mouth, those have still the same value in spight of all the Worlds.</P082>
source_segments: si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir
c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler
ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux
Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit
target_segments: I shall have no value for any thing in it
men are so earnest in the pursuit of Greatness
it had been an ill Complement to have told him of them
they obscure not the Lustre of your Eyes
The other Worlds, you say, make this seem little to you
explanations: The French "dans l'enfoncement" implies being deep in the background and indistinct. The English "wholly drown'd" makes this indistinctness more explicit and vivid by using a strong metaphor that clarifies the *manner* of their being lost to sight, as if submerged and overwhelmed by the vast distance.

The French "d'empressement pour aucune chose" (eagerness/keenness for anything) describes an internal feeling. The English "I shall have no value for any thing in it" makes explicit a related consequence or judgment: that things will hold no worth for the speaker. This clarifies the practical outcome of the loss of "empressement" by explicitly stating a shift in valuation.

The French "s'agrandir" (to aggrandize oneself/to grow bigger) is general. The English phrase "in the pursuit of Greatness" explicitly defines this urge in terms of a specific, ambitious social goal ("Greatness"), clarifying the nature of the "ardeur" (ardor) beyond mere expansion.

The French "mon indolence" (my indolence) is translated as "an unactive negligence." While "indolence" implies inactivity, the addition of "negligence" explicitly characterizes this inactivity as a blameworthy failure or lack of care, which is a specific interpretation not necessarily inherent in "indolence" alone.

The French "faire trop mal sa Cour" (to very poorly ingratiate oneself or manage one's standing with a superior) describes a general failure in courtly diplomacy. The English "an ill Complement" makes this more specific by explicitly labeling the act of telling Alexander as a particular type of social gaffe—an inappropriate or tactless remark—thus clarifying the nature of the diplomatic failure.

The French lists "l'ambition & de l'inquietude" (ambition and restlessness/anxiety) as abstract states or traits that are cured. The English "an unquiet and ambitious mind" makes it explicit that these are qualities embodied *within a mind*, and it is this overall state of mind that is cured, thus clarifying the subject of the cure.

The French "Un peu de foiblesse" (a little weakness) is translated as "a little foolish inclination." The adjective "foolish" is an addition by the translator, explicitly injecting a judgment about the nature of the "inclination" (itself an interpretation of "foiblesse") that is not overtly stated in the original term "weakness."

The French "ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux" (don't spoil your beautiful eyes) is a general statement. The English "they obscure not the Lustre of your Eyes" makes this more specific by explicitly stating *how* the eyes are not spoiled – by their lustre (brightness or radiance) not being diminished – thus adding clarifying detail about the preservation of their beauty.

The French "Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit" (The other worlds make this one small for you) is a direct statement by the philosopher. The English translation adds "you say," explicitly attributing the premise (that other worlds make this one seem small) back to the Marquise's previously expressed sentiment. This addition spells out the dialogical connection and clarifies that the philosopher is directly referencing and building upon her earlier point.

chunks.source_manual: <P090>C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez-moy franchement, vostre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-mesme comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sçauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien-tost aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De mesme accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-mesme il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez-vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroist, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroist point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empesche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune estoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nostre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous estes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grace. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nostre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.</P090>
chunks.target_manual: <P083>This Love, said the Marchioness, laughing, is a strange thing, it has a Salvo for all things and there's no System can do it harm. But tell me pray, and tell me freely, is your System true? Hide nothing from me, I promise you secrecy. To me it seems grounded only on a little Conveniency superficial enough. A Star fixed and luminous in it self like the Sun, ought consequently to be as the Sun is, the Center and Soul of a World, and to have Planets turning about him. Is not this of absolute necessity?</P083> <P084>Hark you, Madam, said I, since 'tis our humour to mix the Folly of Gallantry with our most serious Discourse, the Reasonings of Mathematicks are like those of Love; grant but a Lover the least thing, and you are presently ingag'd to make a farther Concession, and then another, and so to the Worlds end. In like manner grant a Mathematician the least Principle, he'l deduce a Consequence that you must likewise grant, and from that another, and whether you will or not he'l carry you so far as you hardly believe. These two sort of people take more than is given them. You allow, that when two things are alike in what appears to me, I may believe they are also alike in what appears not to me, if nothing otherways hinders me. From hence I concluded that the Moon is inhabited, because she resembles the Earth, and that the Planets are, because they resemble Moon. I find that the fixed Stars resemble our Sun, and I attribute to them all that is in him. You are now too far ingag'd to retire, you must e'en go on. But, says she, according to this Resemblance you make between the fixed Stars and our Sun, it must needs be that the people of another great Vortex do not see him but as a little fixed Star, which appears to them only in their night.</P084>
source_segments: Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë?
les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour.
& à la fin cela va loin.
les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune.
target_segments: it has a Salvo for all things
But tell me pray, and tell me freely
Is not this of absolute necessity?
the Reasonings of Mathematicks are like those of Love;
and so to the Worlds end.
and that the Planets are, because they resemble Moon.
explanations: The French phrase 'il se sauve de tout' (literally 'it saves itself from everything' or 'it gets away with everything') is translated as 'it has a Salvo for all things.' The English translation explicitly introduces the *means* by which Love achieves this ('a Salvo,' meaning an excuse or justification), clarifying information that was only implied in the more general French expression.

The French 'Mais aussi parlez-moy franchement' (But also/then speak to me frankly) is rendered as 'But tell me pray, and tell me freely'. The addition of 'pray' makes the Marquise's implied earnestness or urgent desire for a candid answer more explicit, adding a level of entreaty not directly present in the source.

The French 'une petite convenance bien legere' (a small, very slight/flimsy basis) is translated as 'a little Conveniency superficial enough'. By using 'superficial enough', the translator makes explicit a specific interpretation of 'bien legere' (very light/slight), specifying that the flimsiness of the 'conveniency' (basis/argument) is due to its lack of depth, information that was only implied.

The French question 'Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë?' (Is this of truly absolute necessity?) is translated as 'Is not this of absolute necessity?'. The use of the negative interrogative form in English makes the Marquise's underlying skepticism or her implied opinion that 'this is surely not of absolute necessity' more explicit than the neutral question in French.

The French 'les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour.' (mathematical reasonings are made like Love) is translated as 'the Reasonings of Mathematicks are like those of Love;'. The English translation explicitly clarifies that the comparison is to 'those [reasonings] of Love', spelling out the implied parallel aspect of Love (its persuasive processes or arguments) rather than just the abstract concept of Love.

The French phrase '& à la fin cela va loin' (and in the end that goes far) is translated as 'and so to the Worlds end.' The English idiom 'to the Worlds end' explicitly amplifies the extent implied by 'cela va loin', making the idea of an almost limitless progression or consequence far more vivid and hyperbolically explicit.

The French 'malgré vous-mesme' (despite yourself) is translated as 'whether you will or not'. The English phrase explicitly spells out the implication of being compelled or carried along against one's own volition, clarifying that one's will is irrelevant to the outcome, which is implied more subtly by 'malgré vous-mesme'.

The French clause 'les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune.' (the other Planets, because they resemble the Moon) elliptically omits the verb phrase '[sont habitées]' (are inhabited), which is understood from the preceding context. The English translation 'and that the Planets are, because they resemble Moon.' explicitly adds the verb 'are' (contextually meaning 'are inhabited'), thus expanding the condensed French structure and making the implied predicate explicit.

The French 'il faut que' (it is necessary that / one must) is translated as 'it must needs be that'. The addition of 'needs' (an archaic intensifier meaning 'of necessity') makes the sense of logical compulsion or inevitability more explicit and emphatic than the standard French expression.

chunks.source_manual: <P091>Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je. Nostre Soleil est si proche de nous en comparaison des Soleils des autres Tourbillons, que sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur. Nous ne voyons donc que luy quand nous le voyons, & il efface tout; mais dans un autre grand Tourbillon c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine, & il efface à son tour le nostre, qui n'y paroist que pendant les nuits avec le reste des autres Soleils étrangers, c'est à dire, des Etoiles Fixes. On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel, & il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau. Pour les Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, <NCP>nostre Terre, par exemple</NCP>, comme on ne les voit point de si loin, on n'y songe seulement pas. Ainsi tous les Soleils, sont Soleils de jour pour le Tourbillon où ils sont placez, & Soleils de nuit pour tous les autres Tourbillons. Dans leur Monde, ils sont les uniques de leur espece, par tout ailleurs ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre. Ne faut-il pas pourtant, reprit-elle, que les Mondes, malgré cette égalité different en mille choses, car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?</P091>
chunks.target_manual: <P085>No doubt on't, said I, our Sun is so near us, in comparison of the Suns of other Vortices, that his Light must have infinitely more of force upon our Eyes than theirs: so that we see him, and him only, when we see him; for he dazles all else. But in another great Vortex, another Sun prevails, and he takes his turn and dazles ours, which appears there only in the night with the other forreign Suns, that is, the fixed Stars, The people there seat him with them in the great Arch of Heaven, and there he makes a part perhaps of some Bull or Bear. As for the Planets that move about him, as our Earth, for example, they are not discerned so far off, and no body dreams of them. So all the Suns are Day Suns for the Vortices where they are placed, and Night Suns for all the other Vortices. In their World they are the only ones of their kind, every where else they serve only to make up the number of Stars.</P085> <P086>But yet, says she, notwithstanding this Equality, may not these Worlds differ in a thousand things? for a Resemblance in the main may admit of infinite varieties.</P086>
source_segments: il efface à son tour le nostre
On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel
ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre
target_segments: he takes his turn and dazles ours
The people there seat him with them in the great Arch of Heaven
they serve only to make up the number of Stars
explanations: The French 'il efface tout' (literally 'he erases all' or 'he blots out everything') is translated as 'he dazles all else'. The verb 'effacer' is more general, while 'dazles' explicitly states the mechanism by which the sun obscures other celestial bodies (i.e., by its overwhelming light), information that was only implied in the source text.

Similar to the previous instance, the French 'il efface à son tour le nostre' (he in turn erases/blots out ours) is translated as 'he takes his turn and dazles ours'. The translator again uses 'dazles' instead of a more general term like 'obscures' or 'blots out', thereby making explicit the light-based mechanism of obscuration which was implied in the source.

The French 'On l'attache' uses the impersonal pronoun 'On' (One/They/It is attached). The translation 'The people there seat him' explicitly identifies the agents as 'The people there' (i.e., the imagined inhabitants of the other vortex). This spells out who is performing the conceptual act of placing their sun in the sky, information that was left unstated or vague in the original French.

The French 'on n'y songe seulement pas' (one doesn't even think of them / they are not even thought of) uses the impersonal 'on'. The translation 'no body dreams of them' makes the negation more absolute and personal by specifying 'no body' (not a single person). This choice explicitly defines the scope of who is not considering the planets, moving from an impersonal statement to one affecting all individuals, and also changes 'songe' (thinks) to the more evocative 'dreams'.

The French phrase 'ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre' (they only serve to make up a number/add to the count) is a somewhat general idiom. The translation 'they serve only to make up the number of Stars' adds the specific clarifying information 'of Stars'. This makes explicit what these other suns contribute to when viewed from another vortex (i.e., they appear as stars), an idea strongly implied by the context but not directly stated in the French phrase itself.

chunks.source_manual: <P092>Assurément, repris-je, mais la difficulté est de deviner. Que sçay-je? Un Tourbillon a plus de Planetes qui tournent autour de son Soleil, un autre en a moins. Dans l'un il y a des Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour des Planetes plus grandes; dans l'autre il n'y en a point. Icy elles sont toutes ramassées autour de leur Soleil <UP></UP>, & font comme un petit peloton, au-delà duquel s'étend un grand espace vuide, qui va jusqu'aux Tourbillons voisins; ailleurs elles prennent leur cours vers les extremitez du Tourbillon & laissent le milieu vuide. Je ne doute pas mesme qu'il ne puisse y avoir quelques Tourbillons deserts, & sans Planetes, d'autres dont le Soleil, n'estant pas justement au centre, ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy; d'autres dont les Planetes s'élèvent ou s'abaissent à l'égard de leur Soleil par le changement de l'équilibre qui les tient suspenduës. Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez pour un homme qui n'est jamais sorty de son Tourbillon.</P092>
chunks.target_manual: <P087>Most certain, said I, but the difficulty is to guess what or how. What know I? one Vortex has more Planets that turn about his Sun, another has fewer. In the one there are subordinate Planets, which move about others that are bigger, in another ther's no such thing. Here they all crowd together about their Sun, and make, as it were, a little Ball, beyond which a great void space extends as far as the neighbouring Vortices. In another place they take their course toward the extremities of the Vortex, and leave the middle void. I doubt not likewise but there may be some Vortices desert, and without Planets; and others, whose Sun not being exactly in the Center, has a true motion, and carrys his Planets with him. Others that rise or fall in respect of their Sun, according to the change of the poise that sustains them. In fine, what more would you have? There's e'en enough for a man that was never out of his own Vortex.</P087>
explanations: The French 'de deviner' (to guess/to divine) implies figuring out the unknown nature of other vortices. The English translation 'to guess what or how' makes this implicit scope explicit by specifying the parameters of the speculation: 'what' different cosmic arrangements might exist and 'how' they might be structured or function, thereby adding clarifying detail to the act of 'guessing'.

The French 'il n'y en a point' literally means 'there are none of them,' with 'en' (of them) referring to the previously mentioned 'Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour des Planetes plus grandes'. The English translation 'ther's no such thing' expands this by referring not just to the numerical absence of these specific planets, but to the absence of the entire described 'thing' or phenomenon (subordinate planets orbiting larger ones). This makes the conceptual nature of the absence more explicit.

The French 'mesme' (even) in 'Je ne doute pas mesme' primarily functions as an intensifier, emphasizing the speaker's conviction or the extent of his speculation ('I don't even doubt...'). The English translation 'I doubt not likewise' replaces this intensification with 'likewise,' which explicitly spells out a logical connection of addition or similarity to the preceding speculations. This makes a relationship explicit that was previously implied by the discourse context and the intensifier.

chunks.source_manual: <P093>Ce n'en est guere, répondit-elle, pour la quantité des Mondes. Ce que vous dites ne suffit que pour cinq ou six, & j'en voy d'icy des milliers?</P093>
chunks.target_manual: <P088>That's not much, says she, for the Quantity of Worlds; what you say is not enough for above five or six, and I see here <IIM>a million </IIM>.</P088>
explanations: The French source text has the Marquise exclaiming/questioning "des milliers?" (thousands?) in response to the limited number of worlds (five or six planets) initially discussed. This use of "des milliers" (thousands) refers to the multitude of stars she sees, each potentially a sun with its own worlds. The implicit idea is her dawning realization of an immensely vast universe, a quantity far exceeding her initial understanding. The translator has rendered "des milliers?" as "a million." This is an instance of Explicitation as Re-writing because the translator changes the specific numerical scale from 'thousands' to 'a million'. In doing so, they are making the *implied concept of overwhelming vastness and multitude* more explicit and rhetorically impactful for the English reader. The 'Re-writing' aspect involves deliberately choosing a much larger, more striking number ('a million') to explicitly convey the immense, almost incomprehensible scale that the Marquise is now contemplating, thereby potentially enhancing the intended awe or the revolutionary scope of the ideas being popularized. The change from a potential question ('milliers?') to a declarative statement ('a million.') also makes her grasp of this amplified vastness more asserted.

chunks.source_manual: <P094>Que serait-ce donc, repris-je, si je vous disois qu'il y a bien d'autres Etoiles Fixes, que celles que vous voyez; qu'avec des Lunettes on en découvre un nombre infiny qui ne se montrent point aux yeux, & que dans une seule Constellation, où l'on en comptoit peut-estre douze ou quinze <RW></RW>, il s'en trouve autant que l'on en voyoit <UP></UP> auparavant dans tout le Ciel?</P094>
chunks.target_manual: <P089>What would it be then, said I, if I should tell you that there are many more fixed Stars than those that you see, and that wirh a Telescope an infinite number are discover'd that did not appear to the eye, and that in one sole Constellation, where we usually reckon perhaps twelve, or fifteen, there are found to be as many as were seen before in the whole Heaven.</P089>
explanations: The French "des Lunettes," in this astronomical context, refers to optical instruments for viewing distant stars. While "lunettes d'approche" or "lunettes astronomiques" were specific French terms for telescopes, Fontenelle's use of the more general plural "des Lunettes" (literally meaning "glasses" or "spectacles") might be a popularizing strategy to use a more common term. The English translation "a Telescope" makes the specific type of scientific instrument explicit. This choice clarifies for the reader that these are specialized optical devices for astronomy, not ordinary eyewear, thereby removing potential ambiguity and adding a level of precision not explicitly present in Fontenelle's choice of the broader term.

The French phrase "l'on en comptoit" combines the indefinite pronoun "on" (one/people) with the verb "compter" (to count) in the imperfect tense ("comptoit"). This construction typically implies a general, customary, or repeated past action (e.g., "one used to count," "people generally counted"). The English translation "we usually reckon" makes this habitual or customary nature of the counting explicit by adding the adverb "usually." While the French imperfect tense inherently carries this implication of a continuous or habitual state/action in the past, the addition of "usually" spells it out for the English reader, enhancing clarity regarding the regularity of the past practice described.

chunks.source_manual: <P095>Je vous demande grace, s'écria-t-elle, je me rends, vous m'accablez de Mondes & de Tourbillons. Je sçay bien, ajoûtay-je, ce que je vous garde ancore. Vous voyez cette blancheur qu'on appelle la Voye de Lait. Vous figureriez-vous bien ce que c'est? Une infinité de petites Etoiles invisibles aux yeux à cause de leur petitesse, & semées si prés les unes des autres qu'elles paroissent former une blancheur continuë. Je voudrois que vous vissiez avec des Lunettes cette Fourmilliere d'Astres, & cette graine de Mondes (si ces expressions sont permises.) Ils ressemblent en quelque sorte aux Isles Maldives, à ces douze mille petites Isles ou Bancs de Sable, separez seulement par des Canaux de Mer, que l'on sauteroit presque comme des Fossez. Ainsi les petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait sont si serrez, qu'il me semble que d'un Monde à l'autre on pourroit se parler, ou mesme se donner la main. Du moins je croy que les Oyseaux d'un Monde passent aisément dans un autre, & que l'on y peut dresser des Pigeons à porter des Lettres comme on fait icy dans le Levant. Ces petits Mondes sortent apparemment de la regle generale, par laquelle un Soleil dans son Tourbillon efface dés qu'il paroist tous les Soleils étrangers. Si vous estes dans un des petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait, vostre Soleil n'est presque pas plus proche de vous, & par consequent n'a pas sensiblement plus de force sur vos yeux, que cent mille autres Soleils des Tourbillons voisins. Vous voyez donc vostre Ciel briller d'un nombre infiny de feux, qui sont fort proches les uns des autres, & peu éloignez de vous. Lors que vous perdez de veuë vostre Soleil particulier, il vous en reste encore assez, & vostre nuit n'est pas moins éclairée que le jour, du moins la diference ne peut pas estre sensible, & pour parler plus juste, vous n'avez jamais de nuit. Ils seroient bien étonnez, les Gens de ces Mondes-là, accoûtumez comme ils sont à une clarté perpetuelle, si on leur disoit qu'il y a des malheureux qui ont de veritables nuits, qui tombent dans des tenebres tres-profondes, & qui quand ils joüissent de la lumiere, ne voyent mesme qu'un seul Soleil. Ils nous regarderoient comme des Estres disgraciez de la Nature, & fremiroient de l'horreur de nostre condition.</P095>
chunks.target_manual: <P090>Oh! cry'd the Marchioness, give me Quarter, I yield, you overwhelm me with Worlds and Vortices.</P090> <P091>I know, said I, what I have in store for you yet. You see that White, commonly call'd the Milky way. Can you imagine what it is? 'Tis an infinity of little Stars invisible to the eye, because of their smalness, and so thick set one by the other that they seem to form that continued Whiteness. I wish you saw with a Telescope that crowd of Stars, like Ants in their Hillock, that Grainery of Worlds (if I may be permitted the expression) they resemble in some sort the Maldivian Isles, those twelve thousand little Isles or Banks of Sand, separated only by little Chanels of the Sea, that a man may leap over as easie as so many Ditches. So the little Vortices of the Milky way are so close one to the other, that methinks from one World to the other they may hold discourse, and even shake hands; at least, I believe, the Birds of one World pass easily to another; and Pigeons that are taught to carry Letters, may be as useful there as here in the Levant.</P091> <P092>Those little Worlds are evidently an exception from the general Rule by which one Sun? when he appears in his Vortex, extinguishes all forreign Suns. If you are in one of those little Vortices of the Milky way, your Sun is hardly nearer to you, and consequently has not sensibly more of force upon your Eyes than an hundred thousand other Suns of the neigbouring Vortices. You see then your Heaven glittering with an infinite number of Fires, very near one to the other, and not far distant from you. When you have lost sight of your Sun, you have still enough remain, and your Night is as clear as the Day, or at least the difference is not sensible, and to speak better, you have no Night at all. The people of those Worlds, us'd as they are to a perpetual Light, would be much astonish'd to hear that there are unhappy people that have real Nights, that are bury'd in profound Darkness, and when they injoy the Light, 'tis only of one Sun: They would look on us as Beings curs'd by Nature, and would tremble with Horrour at our Condition.</P092>
source_segments: que l'on y peut dresser des Pigeons à porter des Lettres
target_segments: crowd of Stars, like Ants in their Hillock
so close one to the other
Pigeons that are taught to carry Letters, may be as useful there
explanations: The French "qu'on appelle" (that one calls / which is called), referring to the Milky Way, is translated as "commonly call'd". The addition of "commonly" makes explicit the widespread usage or general acceptance of the term, an aspect that is only implied by the impersonal French construction.

The French "Lunettes" in this 17th-century astronomical context could ambiguously refer to general viewing aids or, more specifically, a telescope. The translation "a Telescope" makes the specific scientific instrument explicit, removing the ambiguity of the original term and clarifying for the reader that a specialized instrument for astronomical observation is meant.

The French "Fourmilliere d'Astres" (anthill of stars) is a direct and condensed metaphor. The translation "crowd of Stars, like Ants in their Hillock" first uses a more general term "crowd of Stars" and then explicitly spells out the simile with "like Ants in their Hillock," thereby expanding and clarifying the components of the original metaphorical image for the reader.

The French "si serrez" (in "les petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait sont si serrez") means "so tight" or "so close-packed," implying the vortices are near each other. The translation "so close one to the other" (in "the little Vortices of the Milky way are so close one to the other") makes the reciprocal relationship of proximity explicit, spelling out that each entity is close in relation to another, a nuance less directly stated in the concise French.

The French "que l'on y peut dresser des Pigeons à porter des Lettres" (that one can train pigeons there to carry letters) focuses on the potential action of training. The translation rephrases this as "Pigeons that are taught to carry Letters, may be as useful there", making the pigeons' acquired characteristic of being trained ("that are taught to carry Letters") an explicit attribute before stating their usefulness, thus shifting the focus and expanding the description.

The French impersonal pronoun "l'on" (from "que l'on sauteroit presque comme des Fossez") translates to "one" or an unspecified person. The English translation "a man" (from "that a man may leap over as easie as so many Ditches") makes the agent more specific, typically implying a concrete human individual, thus adding a layer of specificity to the more general French pronoun.

The French conditional clause "si on leur disoit que..." (if one told them that...) introduces a hypothetical scenario. The English translation, by phrasing the reaction as they "would be much astonish'd to hear that...", makes the perceptual act of "hearing" the information explicit as the direct cause of their astonishment, a consequence that was only implied by the act of telling in French.

The French "Estres disgraciez de la Nature" (Beings disgraced by Nature / Beings who have fallen out of Nature's favor) is translated as "Beings curs'd by Nature." The word "curs'd" makes the implied severity and definitive condemnation by Nature more explicit and intense than the original "disgraciez," which could suggest a less permanent or less severe state of disfavor.

chunks.source_manual: <P096>Je ne vous demande pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, s'il y a des Lunes dans les Mondes de la Voye de Lait; je voy bien qu'elles n'y seroient de nul usage aux Planetes principales qui n'ont point de nuit, & qui d'ailleurs marchent dans des espaces trop étroits pour s'embarrasser de cet attirail de Planetes subalternes. Mais sçavez-vous bien qu'à force de me multiplier les Mondes si liberalement, vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté? Les Tourbillons dont nous voyons les Soleils, touchent le Tourbillon où nous sommes. Les Tourbillons sont ronds, n'est-il pas vray? Et comment tant de Boules en peuvent-elles toucher une seule?
